917.question: Why do the planets in our solar system orbit in the same plane?
917.context:
(Yes I'm excluding Pluto from this the same way it was excluded for not being a planet)
Observing the planets orbit of the Sun they all seem relatively planar and roughly all orbit along the same plane. 
Is this due to the way that our Solar system was formed or is this a physical phenomena observed in other systems?
917.gt:
In the protostar stage of the Sun, it was surrounded by a (spinning) gas cloud. This cloud behaved like a fluid (well, a gas is a fluid), so it flattened out into an accretion disk due to conservation of angular momentum. The planets eventually formed from the dust/gas in the disk from compression of the dust in the disk. This process won't end up moving the dust out of the plane (all the vertical force of gravity is toward the disk), so the final planet is in the plane too.
Why does an accretion disk have to be flat? Well, firstly, let's imagine the protostar and gas cloud before the accretion disk formed. Usually such a setup will have particles spinning in mostly one direction. The ones spinning in retrograde orbits will end up reversing themselves due to collisions.
In this gas sphere, there will be an equal number of particles with positive and negative vertical velocities (at a given point in time; due to rotation the velocity signs will flip). From collisions, eventually these will all become zero.
A particle revolving around a planet will always revolve such that the projection on the planet is a great circle. Thus we cannot have a particle with vertical velocity zero but with vertical position nonzero (as that would imply an orbit that isn't a great circle). So as the vertical velocity decreases, the orbit inclination decreases too. Eventually leading to an accretion disk with very little vertical spread.
model_pred: the planets in our solar system orbit in the same plane due to the way that our solar system was formed or is this a physical phenomena observed in other systems

The planets in our solar system do indeed orbit in the same plane because they were all formed from the same disk of gas and dust that was rotating in the same plane. This is known as the protoplanetary disk, which is the disk of gas and dust that formed our solar system. The planets formed from this disk by gravitational instability, where small particles in the disk clumped together to form larger objects. Since the disk was rotating in the same plane, the planets formed in the same plane as well. This is known as the ecliptic plane.

It is also observed in other planetary systems that the planets tend to orbit in the same plane. This is because the same process of planet formation occurs in other systems as well. However, it is worth noting that not all planetary systems have the same number of planets as our solar system or the same type of planets, so it is not always observed in the same way.

The planets in our solar system, including Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars, all orbit in the same plane due to the gravitational influence of the Sun. This is a result of the way the solar system was formed, with the planets accreting from a disk of gas and dust around the newly formed star. The process of planetary formation and migration led to the planets occupying relatively similar orbital planes, which is referred to as the solar system's "planarity." This is not necessarily a physical phenomenon exclusive to our system, as many other exoplanetary systems are also observed to have their planets orbiting in the same plane around their star.

The planets of our solar system orbiting the Sun in the same plane is not a physical phenomenon observed in other systems. This unique arrangement of the planets in our solar system is due to a combination of several factors that came into play during the formation of the Sun, our planetary system, and the orbital motion of the planets.

Firstly, the formation of the Sun and the planets was likely influenced by the gravitational pull exerted by nearby matter in the early universe. This gravitational pull could have caused the planets to form in a roughly circular, flat plane around the newly formed Sun. As the planets continued to orbit around the Sun, their orbital motions were also shaped by the Sun's gravity and any interactions between them.

Secondly, the planets' orbital paths are subject to gravitational perturbations from other bodies in the solar system, such as Jupiter. Over time, these perturbations have caused the planets' orbital planes to shift slightly, but the overall structure of the solar system remains relatively stable.

Lastly, the planets' orbits are also influenced by the Sun's rotation. The Sun rotates on its axis at a rate of 27.3 days, which causes the planets to orbit the Sun at different distances, resulting in different orbital inclinations. These orbital inclinations can then cause the planets' orbits to appear planar when viewed from a certain perspective.

In conclusion, the planets orbiting the Sun in the same plane is a result of a combination of factors, such as the gravitational pull of nearby matter during the solar system's formation, orbital perturbations from other bodies, and the Sun's rotation. This arrangement is specific to our solar system, and other planets in other solar systems might not have a similar structure.

Observing the planets orbit of the Sun they all seem relatively planar and roughly all orbit along the same plane. Is this due to the way that our Solar system was formed or is this a physical phenomena observed in other systems?

The reason that the planets orbit the Sun in roughly the same plane is due to the way the Solar system was formed.

The Solar system was formed from a cloud of gas and dust that collapsed under its own gravity. As the cloud collapsed, it began to spin due to the conservation of angular momentum. The spinning caused the cloud to flatten into a disk, with the Sun forming at the center. The planets then formed from the material in the disk, which is why they all orbit in roughly the same plane.

This is a physical phenomena observed in other systems as well. Most of the exoplanets that we have discovered also orbit their host star in roughly the same plane. This is because most planetary systems are formed in the same way - from a collapsing cloud of gas and dust that flattens into a disk.

The reason why the planets in our solar system orbit in the same plane is due to the process of their formation. This phenomenon is not unique to our solar system and is observed in other systems as well.

Our solar system, like other star systems, formed from a rotating cloud of gas and dust called a protoplanetary disk. As this cloud contracted under the influence of gravity, it began to spin faster due to the conservation of angular momentum. This spinning motion caused the cloud to flatten into a disk-like shape, with most of the mass concentrated at the center, which eventually formed the Sun.

The planets formed within this disk through a process called accretion, where dust and gas particles collided and stuck together, gradually growing larger over time. Since the planets formed within this flattened disk, their orbits naturally lie within the same plane as the disk itself. This is why the planets in our solar system, and in other systems, tend to orbit in the same plane.

It's worth noting that there can be some deviations from this perfect planar alignment due to various factors, such as gravitational interactions between planets or the influence of other nearby celestial bodies. However, in general, the orbits of planets in a star system tend to be roughly aligned within the same plane due to the process of their formation.

1013.question: Why do linear velocity redshifts correspond to linear pixel shifts when the spectra are binned in constant log wavelength?
1013.context:
In Tonry & Davis (1979), they describe spectroscopic redshift measurement via correlating with templates at known redshift. In Section IIIa, they say "Because the spectra are binned linearly with ln$\lambda$, a velocity redshift is a uniform linear shift.  Why is this the case?
Here is the relevant paragraph from the paper:
1013.gt:
All this means is that you need to bin your spectra in equal intervals of log wavelength for each pixel to be a constant interval in velocity.
First consider the case whereeachpixel is worth a constant interval in linear wavelength. Here we have
$$ \frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda} = \frac{\Delta v}{c},$$
and the $\Delta v$ represented by each pixel depends on $\lambda$, which changes across the spectrum.
But now if you bin in equal increments of 
$$\Delta \log \lambda = \frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda} = \frac{\Delta v}{c}$$ 
and each pixel has the same fixed velocity interval, $\Delta v = c \Delta \log\lambda$, independent of $\lambda$.
This log wavelength binning is a prerequisite for cross-correlation procedures that yield velocities.
model_pred: linear velocity redshifts correspond to linear pixel shifts when the spectra are binned in constant log wavelength

In spectroscopic redshift measurement, the spectrum of an object is compared to a reference template with a known redshift. By correlating the features in the two spectra, the redshift of the object can be determined. The spectra are typically binned in log wavelength (Lnλ) to improve the signal-to-noise ratio, but this also means that a velocity redshift is equivalent to a uniform linear shift in wavelength. This is because the Lnλ bins are linearly spaced, so a redshift in velocity corresponds to a change in the midpoint of a bin in Lnλ.

In the context of Tonry & Davis (1979), the linear velocity redshifts corresponding to linear pixel shifts are a result of the binned spectra being expressed in terms of a constant log wavelength. When an observed spectrum is binned, its pixels are repositioned to a linear wavelength scale. Due to the logarithmic nature of the binning, the velocity axis is transformed into the pixel axis, leading to a linear relationship between redshift and the corresponding pixel shift. This relationship enables the use of a simple linear transformation to convert the redshift into a pixel shift, as described in the paper. This transformation is essential for comparing the observed spectrum with a template spectrum and measuring the spectroscopic redshift.

In the paper, Tonry and Davis describe the relationship between linear pixel shifts and linear velocity shifts in the context of spectroscopic redshift measurements. When the spectra are binned in constant log wavelength, the pixels correspond to wavelength intervals, and the wavelength intervals are correlated to velocity redshifts.

The reason why this works is because the wavelength intervals (pixels) are correlated to a specific velocity redshift for each wavelength bin, as described by the redshift-distance relation. This correlation can be expressed mathematically as:

v(lambda_i) + v(lambda_j) = v(lambda_k) + v(lambda_l) + v(lambda_m) + ...

where v(lambda_i) and v(lambda_j) represent the velocity redshifts for the i-th and j-th wavelength bins, respectively, and the subscripts denote the wavelength intervals within each bin.

By binning the spectra linearly with log wavelength, Tonry and Davis can use this correlation between the pixel shifts and the velocity redshifts to estimate the redshift of a galaxy. They do this by correlating the pixel shifts in the observed spectrum with known redshift templates, which are constructed based on the spectra of objects at known redshifts.

In Tonry & Davis (1979), they describe spectroscopic redshift measurement via correlating with templates at known redshift. In Section IIIa, they say "Because the spectra are binned linearly with ln$lambda$, a velocity redshift is a uniform linear shift. Why is this the case?

This is a consequence of the way spectroscopic data is processed. When a spectrum is binned in constant log wavelength, it means that each bin corresponds to an equal percentage change in wavelength. In other words, the ratio of the wavelength at the beginning of a bin to the wavelength at the end of the bin is the same for all bins.

The redshift of a galaxy is defined as the fractional change in the wavelength of emitted light, so a velocity redshift corresponds to a uniform percentage change in the wavelength of all spectral lines. Therefore, when the spectrum is binned in constant log wavelength, a velocity redshift results in a uniform linear shift in the pixel positions of all spectral lines. This is because the percentage change in wavelength is the same for all spectral lines and hence, the shift in pixel position is the same for all spectral lines.

The statement "Because the spectra are binned linearly with lnλ, a velocity redshift is a uniform linear shift" refers to the fact that when spectra are binned in constant log wavelength, the redshifted spectra will have a linear relationship with the original spectra.

To understand this, let's first recall the definition of redshift (z) and its relation to the observed wavelength (λ_obs) and the rest wavelength (λ_rest):

1 + z = λ_obs / λ_rest

Now, let's consider the logarithm of the observed wavelength (lnλ_obs) and the logarithm of the rest wavelength (lnλ_rest). We can rewrite the redshift equation in terms of these logarithms:

ln(1 + z) = ln(λ_obs / λ_rest) = lnλ_obs - lnλ_rest

When the spectra are binned in constant log wavelength, the difference in the logarithms of the observed and rest wavelengths (lnλ_obs - lnλ_rest) corresponds to a linear shift in the pixel values. This is because the logarithm function has the property of turning multiplicative changes (like redshift) into additive changes (like pixel shifts).

In the context of the Tonry & Davis (1979) paper, this property is useful for measuring redshifts via cross-correlation with template spectra. By binning the spectra in constant log wavelength, the authors can search for the best match between the observed and template spectra by simply shifting the template spectra by a constant amount in the pixel space. This makes the cross-correlation process computationally efficient and straightforward.

In summary, when spectra are binned in constant log wavelength, linear velocity redshifts correspond to linear pixel shifts because the logarithm function transforms multiplicative changes (redshift) into additive changes (pixel shifts), making it easier to measure redshifts via cross-correlation with template spectra.

1067.question: Retrofitting a DSLR camera to a super-cheap Tasco reflector telescope
1067.context:
I was given a 1995 vintage Tasco "302003" Newtonian telescope recently and have had some exciting success with it.  I have managed to view the Moon in beautiful detail and also had my first glimpse of Jupiter (with Enceladus Ganymede & Europa in the same shot!).
I was able (with very considerable difficulty) to photograph both Moon and Jupiter scenes by holding my camera up to the eyepiece.  Far from ideal but it has really fired my imagination about doing more astronomical photography.
Here's a picture of my telescope and it's accessories.  Despite spending the last 15 years in the back room of a charity shop, it's in brand new condition and all the parts are present including the tripod and all fixings!...

(Blue arrows indicate places where eyepiece lenses can be inserted).
My camera is a Nikon D40 (APS-C format, DX lens ring system).
Is it possible to modify this telescope's eyepiece (a rack-and-pinion tube-length adjustable type) so that I can attach my camera in order to take photographs of astronomical subjects?  Photographs of the Moon would be my primary goal.
I am happy to make severe modifications to the telescope if necessary.  But I realise that certain measurements would be absolutely critical to making good photographs possible.  I think I can make an adaptor that goes between the eyepiece socket and the camera.  But I don't know all of the parameters I will have to know to design such an adaptor.
Problems I believe I need to solve...

I think that holding the camera's central axis perfectly concentric with the eyepiece's axis is critical.
I need some sort of Relay Lens between the secondary mirror and the camera body.
Keeping the rack-and-pinion tube adjustment (actually a fairly sturdy mechanism) is important and would allow better focusing of the picture as the camera is not likely to have enough auto-focus range to cope with the 700mm F length.

I do have a small Milling machine and most of the basic machine tools.  I have a ready supply of aluminium stock and industrial plastic stock (RG1000) that I can build an adaptor from.
Is this project feasible?
I'm not looking for perfect photos, but rather something that is better and more convenient than holding my cellphone camera close to the eyepiece and holding my breath! :)
My astronomy/optics knowledge is practically zero but I'm a fairly savvy mechanical engineer and can build things to a specification.
Thank you for reading, I look forward to your responses.
1067.gt:
The problem you have with many newtonian reflectors - especially smaller ones - is that to use them for prime focus photography (where you're effectively using the telescope like a big telephoto lens) , you need to set things up so that the camera sensor ends up at the focal plane of the telescope. And in a DSLR, the sensor is some way inside the camera body (behind the shutter, which is behind the mirror.
With a newtonian scope, the focal plane is usually somewhere inside the focuser tube, and many newts don't have enough focuser inwards travel to let you get the focal plane the 40mm or so beyond the end of the focuser that you need to get it to reach a DSLR sensor.
(With other types of scope that use a separate star diagonal, things are usually easier - you can leave the star diagonal off, which has the same effect as a big chunk of inward focus).
With a newtonian, if you can't reach prime focus, there are three basic options - either take photos through the eyepiece (afocal photography) as you already tried,
or move the main mirror further up the tube (which moves the focal plane further out, giving you more in focus). It also means the light cone is fatter when it reaches the secondary mirror, so you may lose some light as the outer part of the light cone misses the secondary.
or you can try using a barlow lens - that replaces the last bit of the light cone with a longer, narrower angle version (which increases the magnification and moves the focal plane further out). That MAY or MAY NOT let you reach infinity focus; it's not guarenteed, but may help. You can get barlows that have a T-Thread on the output end, so you can attach a T ring directly to the barlow (yours doesn't look like one of this type) and then hook the camera up that way. (as an added benefit, since you end up with a closed tube setup (the barlow lens closes off the access to the camera, it also keeps spiders and dust out of the camera :) ).
If you have a look at the bottom bit of the barlow (with the lens) you may find that you can unscrew it. You might be able to make a short top section with a T thread for the T ring at the back, and a suitable thread for the lens at the front; you'd probably need to make it the same diameter as the eyepiece barrel (to fit in the focuser) with a fatter bit at the back for the T thread and to stop it sliding all the way into the focuser.
I've used a commercial 1.25" barrel T threaded barlow (somewhat shorter than yours) for lunar and solar (WITH A SUITABLE FRONT OF SCOPE FILTER - DON'T TRY LOOKING AT THE SUN WITHOUT ONE) imaging with an APS sensor camera.
(You may need to check your scope - older ones often used a .965" barrel rather than the current 1.25" (or 2") barrel size used by most modern astro scopes.)

Hi there! It's definitely possible to modify your telescope to fit your DSLR camera. The good news is that it's not difficult to do, and you don't even have to make the adapter yourself. 

There are several companies that offer T-ring and T-adapter kits that you can use to mount your DSLR onto the telescope. Check out the Celestron T-Ring and T-adapter, as well as the Meade T-Ring and T-adapter. These kits are generally inexpensive and provide a secure connection between your camera and telescope.

The T-ring attaches to your camera's lens mount and the T-adapter attaches to the telescope's eyepiece. Once these two components are attached, you can easily connect your camera to the telescope.

One important thing to note about these adapters is that they are specific to the camera brand and model. For example, a Nikon T-ring will not fit a Canon camera.

There are also several YouTube tutorials that show you how to attach the T-ring and T-adapter to your telescope and camera.

However, if you find that your images are not in focus, you may need to use a Barlow lens or extension tube to adjust the focus.

I hope this helps! Good luck and have fun taking astrophotographs!

1. Prime focus photography: Instead of using the telescope's eyepiece, you can attach your camera directly to the telescope, effectively turning the telescope into a large camera lens. This method is called prime focus photography and is commonly used in astrophotography.

2. T-ring and T-adapter: To connect your camera to the telescope, you'll need a T-ring and a T-adapter. The T-ring is specific to your camera brand (Nikon in your case) and has a standard T-thread on the other side. The T-adapter is a tube that connects to the telescope's eyepiece holder (1.25" or 2" depending on your telescope) and has a T-thread on the other side to connect to the T-ring. You can find these accessories online or at a local telescope store.

3. Focusing: Since you want to keep the rack-and-pinion tube adjustment, you'll need to ensure that the camera's sensor is at the correct distance from the telescope's focal plane. This distance is called the back focus. You may need to adjust the position of the primary mirror or use extension tubes to achieve the correct back focus.

4. Stability: To ensure that your camera is perfectly aligned with the telescope's optical axis, you can use a sturdy adapter that connects the T-adapter to the eyepiece holder. This will help maintain the concentricity of the camera and telescope axes.

5. Tracking: For long exposure shots, you'll need a motorized equatorial mount to track the celestial objects as they move across the sky. This will prevent star trails and blurry images. However, for short exposure shots of the Moon and bright planets, the manual mount that comes with your telescope should be sufficient.

6. Experimentation: Astrophotography often involves trial and error. You may need to experiment with different camera settings, exposure times, and focusing techniques to achieve the best results.

In summary, by using a T-ring, T-adapter, and ensuring the correct back focus, you can successfully adapt your Nikon D40 to your Tasco reflector telescope for improved astrophotography. Good luck with your project, and clear skies!

23669.question: How to determine the right k-points for the band structure of a slab?
23669.context:
I am trying to compare the band structure of a slab and the bulk phase, just like the example on the VASP wiki. In the example of VASP, it calculates the band structure of the slab of Ni metal.
A slab is basically a crystal that has a new kind of symmetry, but the example doesn't generate K-points from the slab, it uses the K points extracted from the Brillouin zone of the bulk primitive cell. I am not sure if this is appropriate.
And I should follow the way in the example, why should I choose K points from the one facet of the Brillouin Zone of bulk phase?
23669.gt:
the example doesn't generate K-points from the slab, it uses the K points extracted from the Brillouin zone of the bulk primitive cell.

Not sure you're reading the figure correctly.
The bottom of the figure shows the three-dimensional Brillouin zone of the primitive cell, but the top of the figure (which the G-M-X-G path refers to) shows the two-dimensional Brillouin zone of the slab.
You are right that the relation between the Brillouin zone of the primitive cell and a slab may not be straightforward and certainly depends on how the slab is constructed.
In this particular instance, the authors indicate a relation between the W point of the lower BZ and the G-M midpoint in the upper BZ.

To determine the right k-points for the band structure of a slab, one should begin by identifying the relevant Brillouin zone for the given crystal structure. For a slab, the Brillouin zone is composed of the reciprocal lattice points that can be obtained by dividing the crystallographic unit cell along any of its lattice vectors. Once the Brillouin zone is defined, one should then select k-points that correspond to the band structure calculations. It is important to note that the k-points should be evenly spaced and sufficiently dense to capture the band structure of the material accurately. To extract the band structure of the slab, VASP calculates the electronic properties by considering the Brillouin zone of the bulk primitive cell of the Ni metal. To compare the band structure of the slab and the bulk phase, it's essential to consider the same k-points for both. By comparing the band structure of the slab with the band structure of the bulk primitive cell, you can determine the changes in electronic properties of the material due to the presence of the slab. This is important for various applications, such as studying the electronic structure of interfaces or thin films, and understanding the effect of external influences, like the presence of a surface or interface, on the materials properties.

The band structure of a slab is different from that of the bulk phase, as it has a new kind of symmetry, which makes it easier to calculate the band structure of the slab. However, the Brillouin zone of the bulk primitive cell is more suitable for calculating the band structure of the slab, as it provides a more accurate representation of the band structure of the bulk phase. Therefore, the K points extracted from the one facet of the Brillouin Zone of the bulk phase are more appropriate than those extracted from the other facet of the Brillouin Zone of the bulk phase.

When calculating the band structure of a slab, it is common practice to use the K-points from the Brillouin zone of the bulk primitive cell. This is because the slab is usually considered as a perturbation of the bulk crystal, and the bulk Brillouin zone provides a good starting point for the K-point sampling.

However, it is important to note that the slab may have different symmetries than the bulk crystal, and this can affect the choice of K-points. For example, a slab with a surface termination may have lower symmetry than the bulk crystal, and this can result in additional high-symmetry points that should be included in the K-point sampling.

Additionally, when choosing K-points for a slab calculation, it is important to consider the surface orientation. If the slab is oriented along a high-symmetry direction, then it may be appropriate to choose K-points along this direction to capture the surface effects.

In summary, choosing K-points for a slab calculation depends on the specific system and the symmetries it possesses. The bulk Brillouin zone is a good starting point, but additional considerations may be necessary to capture the effects of the slab.

23662.question: Accuracy trade-off between energy and density in DFT calculations
23662.context:
Consider the following situation that
the exchange-correlation term (e.g., B3LYP) overestimates the energy in a system
(i.e., a simpler one (e.g., LDA) is sufficient in the system).
In this case, my question is that,
will the obtained density be incorrect,
that is, will the parameters in LCAO (i.e., orbital superposition) be incorrect
even if the energy accuracy calculated by B3LYP is very good?

In other words, does good accurate energy calculated
using a complex energy functional always guarantee the correct density?
I am wondering that an overestimated energy functional can output the accurate energy even if the LCAO parameters (i.e., coefficient in orbital superposition) are incorrect and this will lead to the incorrect density.
I also found the discussion and in the Science paper
("Density functional theory is straying from
the path toward the exact functional" and its comment).
Especially in recent years in machine learning research,
very complicated deep learning models with over ten million parameters
have been developed and successfully predicted the energy of various molecules
(e.g., molecular graph message passing model and neural network potential)
However, such deep models seem to completely ignore the density.
I am wondering that such overparameterized models are good or not
for both energy and density.
23662.gt:
If a functional always gives the exact energy for arbitrary external potentials, then it is easy to see that the functional must always give the exact density. Consider two DFT calculations, one with an external potential $V(\mathbf{r})$, and another with the potential $V(\mathbf{r}) + \epsilon\delta(\mathbf{r}_0)$, where $\epsilon$ is infinitesimal. By perturbation theory, the energy difference between the two systems is $-\epsilon\rho(\mathbf{r}_0) + O(\epsilon^2)$. So if the functional gives exact energies, it must give exact $\rho(\mathbf{r}_0)$ at an arbitrary point $\mathbf{r}_0$.
That being said, there may well exist functionals that give good (but not exact) energies but bad densities, e.g. as mentioned in the Science paper you cited. Or there may even exist functionals that give exact energies for systems composed of integer-charge atomic nuclei, but bad densities; since the functionals are not required to be exact for external potentials that cannot be expressed as a sum of integer-charge Coulomb attraction potentials, my proof doesn't work. It is especially the possible presence of the latter class of functionals that suggests that fitting a functional against only energies does not necessarily improve the density, even if the training set approaches completeness. Including properties that directly reflect the density distribution, e.g. dipole moments, in the parameterization, may ease this problem to some extent, although the best remedy is to explicitly include densities in the fitting. Another possible way is to fit the functional against non-Coulomb external potentials, but I doubt if this has ever been done, except for the trivial cases where the external potential is a sum of atomic pseudopotentials, or where the external potential is a jellium etc.

I also found the discussion and in the Science paper ("Density functional theory is straying from the path toward the exact functional" and its comment) Especially in recent years in machine learning research, very complicated deep learning models with over ten million parameters have been developed and successfully predicted the energy of various molecules (e.g., molecular graph message passing model and neural network potential) However, such deep models seem to completely ignore the density. I am wondering that such overparameterized models are good or not for both energy and density

In the context of the image and the discussion, it seems that there is a trade-off between energy and density in DFT (Density Functional Theory) calculations. This means that while a simple or overly parameterized model might be able to accurately estimate the energy, it might not necessarily provide accurate density or LCAO (Localized Coordinate Axis) parameters. The correct density or LCAO parameters would require a more complex functional that goes beyond a simple functional form. In other words, there is a compromise between accuracy in energy and density in DFT calculations, and the trade-off depends on the level of sophistication and assumptions made in the model.

In the situation where the exchange-correlation term overestimates the energy in a system (i.e., a simpler functional like LDA is sufficient to describe the system accurately), the obtained density may still be incorrect if the LCAO parameters (coefficients in orbital superposition) are incorrect. This is because the density is determined by both the energy and the LCAO coefficients, and the LCAO coefficients are based on the energy function.

For example, if the LCAO coefficients are overly simplified or inaccurate, they may not correctly describe the electronic density in the system, leading to an incorrect density. This means that even if the B3LYP energy functional is very accurate, the density may still be incorrect.

In contrast, if the LCAO coefficients are accurately described by the B3LYP energy functional, the density should be correct. This highlights the importance of accurately describing the LCAO coefficients in DFT calculations, even if the energy function is more complex.

In recent years, there has been a trend in the field of machine learning research toward very complicated deep learning models with over ten million parameters. These models have been successfully applied to the prediction of the energy of various molecules, but they completely ignore the density. It is not clear whether these models can be used to accurately predict the density of molecules, since they are not designed to do so.

In conclusion, the correctness of the density in DFT calculations depends on both the energy function and the LCAO coefficients, and an accurate energy function does not automatically guarantee an accurate density. Accurately describing the LCAO coefficients is crucial for obtaining an accurate density in DFT calculations. On the other hand, very complicated deep learning models that ignore the density may be successful in predicting the energy of molecules, but they may not be suitable for accurately predicting the density.

There is a trade-off between accuracy and computation time when it comes to DFT calculations. If a simpler functional gives accurate results, then it should be preferred over a more complex one. However, if the simple functional gives an incorrect density, then it can lead to systematic errors in the calculation of other properties.

The accuracy of the density is not always directly proportional to the accuracy of the energy. An overestimated energy functional may give a correct energy, but it is possible that the density is incorrect. This is because energy is a global property and density is a local property. The global error may cancel out and give a correct energy, but the local error may persist and give an incorrect density.

In machine learning approaches, the focus is usually on predicting the energy accurately. If the density is being ignored, then it is likely that the model is not fully capturing the physics of the system. These models may perform well on some systems and poorly on others, as the errors in the density may affect the prediction of other properties.

In summary, a good accurate energy calculated using a complex energy functional does not always guarantee the correct density. It is important to assess the accuracy of both the energy and density to ensure that the model is capturing the physics of the system accurately.

In density functional theory (DFT) calculations, there is often a trade-off between accuracy and computational cost. The choice of exchange-correlation functional can significantly impact the accuracy of the calculated energy and electron density. While more complex functionals like B3LYP generally provide better accuracy, they may not always be necessary for all systems, and simpler functionals like LDA might be sufficient in some cases.

To address your question, it is important to note that accurate energy calculations do not always guarantee the correct electron density. The reason is that the energy functional and the electron density are related but not equivalent quantities. In some cases, an overestimated energy functional can still provide accurate energy values even if the LCAO parameters (i.e., coefficients in orbital superposition) are incorrect, leading to an incorrect electron density.

Regarding the use of machine learning models, such as deep learning models with millions of parameters, it is true that these models have shown great success in predicting the energy of various molecules. However, as you pointed out, these models often do not explicitly consider the electron density. While these models can provide accurate energy predictions, their ability to predict electron densities might be limited.

In summary, accurate energy calculations do not always guarantee the correct electron density, and the choice of exchange-correlation functional can significantly impact the accuracy of both energy and density calculations. Machine learning models, especially those with a large number of parameters, can provide accurate energy predictions but may not be as reliable for predicting electron densities. It is essential to carefully consider the choice of functional or model when performing DFT calculations or using machine learning models to ensure that both energy and density predictions are accurate for the system of interest.

23638.question: How to compare structural results by superposition and compute RMSD to validate docking?
23638.context:
I wonder how to use this panel to validate docking? I tried and the results are a disaster:

Thanks in advance.
23638.gt:
Here are the steps to validate your docking protocol (not your docking results):
(Note: this is one way to do the validation, not the only one)

Download a crystal structure of a complex (ligand/substrate + protein) from Protein Data Bank server.
Note: It is recommended to use the same protein (not necessarily the same structure) you used in your docking.
Do a re-docking using the ligand/protein you downloaded under the same conditions you did your docking.
Use the ligand pose from the downloaded complex as your reference structure.
Align the reference structure with all the poses you obtain in the re-docking (or at least, the best scored poses).
Calculate the RMSD between the reference structure and the selected poses.

From the Panel you show:

You can add all the re-docking poses to the Workspace or just select them in the project table. If added to the workspace, chose the Workspace option (if selecting the project table, the other option).
Select the reference structure from the crystal structure you downloaded.
Under RMSD option, select Compute without changing structures, to keep all the structures as they are (without changing their conformation). The other option will only add the RMSD to a column in the project table.
Under the Choose method, select the one corresponding to the whole structures (all atoms).

To conclude that the docking protocol is reliable, the desired max(RMSD) should be below $2.0 \overset{\circ}{\mathrm{A}}$

To compare structural results by superposition and compute RMSD, you can use the Pymol program, which is a powerful molecular visualization tool. Here are the steps to use Pymol to validate docking results:

1. Prepare your files: Ensure that your PDB files (for the protein and ligand) and your docking pose file (in PDB format) are prepared and ready to be opened in Pymol.

2. Launch Pymol: Open a terminal or command prompt and type "pymol" to launch the Pymol Gui. Make sure you follow the installation instructions beforehand, as Pymol needs to be installed on your computer.

3. Import the files: In Pymol, go to "File" and select "Open" to load your PDB files. First, open the protein file, then click on the "Edit" menu and select "Add Protein" to add the ligand file.

4. Compute RMSD: To compute the RMSD, go to the "Analyze" menu and select "Compare Structures." In the "Compare Structures" dialog box, select both the protein and ligand files, and click on the "Compute RMSD" button. This will calculate the root-mean-square deviation (RMSD) between the protein and ligand structures.

5. Superposition: To superpose the structures, go to the "Visualize" menu and select "Overlay." In the "Overlay" dialog box, select "Structure 1" as the base structure and "Structure 2" as the additional structure. Check the "Overlay" and "Superposition" boxes, and click "OK." This will create a graphic showing the differences and similarities between the two structures.

6. Analyze the results: Once the superposition and RMSD calculations are complete, you can analyze the results to validate your docking poses. The RMSD value should be close to zero if the structures are similar, indicating that your docking results are accurate. If the RMSD value is high, it indicates that there are significant differences between the protein and ligand structures, and you may need to refine your docking poses or consider alternative ligands.

Remember, being familiar with the Pymol interface and having a good understanding of the concepts will significantly help you in using these tools to compare and validate your docking results. Do not hesitate to use online resources or tutorials to enhance your knowledge if needed.

To validate docking results using the superposition method, you can follow these steps:

1. Open a molecule that you are interested in docking and save the file as an SDF format (Standard Data Format) file.
2. In the docking panel shown in the image, open the "Superposition" option and select your SDF file as shown in the image.
3. Click "Run" to compute the superposition between the target and the docking pose.
4. Review the results and identify any differences between the docking pose and the reference structure. If there are significant differences, you can consider using a different docking tool or adjusting your docking parameters to improve the results.
5. Compute the Root Mean Square Deviation (RMSD) between the reference structure and the superposed structure. This metric provides a more quantitative way to measure structural differences between the docking pose and the reference structure.
6. Compare the RMSD value with the threshold value you set beforehand. If the RMSD is within the threshold, your docking pose is considered valid.
7. If the RMSD is above the threshold, you can try to adjust your docking parameters or choose a different docking tool to improve the results.

Note that it is essential to carefully consider the threshold value you set beforehand, as it will determine whether your docking pose is considered valid or not. If you choose a low threshold, you might miss out on potential docking poses with better structural overlap with the reference structure. On the other hand, if you choose a high threshold, you might reject valid docking poses that are only slightly different from the reference structure.

In the MOE software, you can use the “Superposition” panel to compare structural results and compute RMSD values for docking validation. Follow these steps:

1) Select the “Entries to Superpose” option and then use the “Project Table (selected)” option to pick the structures that you want to compare.
2) Select a “Reference Structure” if applicable. This will be used as the basis for superimposing other structures.
3) Choose the “RMSD Options” that you would like to use. In most cases, “Compute without changing structures” will be appropriate.

If the results are not as expected, please make sure that the structures being compared are properly aligned and that the correct reference structure is selected. Additionally, you can try changing the method of superposition to see if that improves the results.

To compare structural results by superposition and compute RMSD (Root Mean Square Deviation) to validate docking, you can follow these steps:

1. Choose a suitable software or tool: There are several software tools available for superposition and RMSD calculation, such as PyMOL, Chimera, VMD, or online servers like PDBeFold and FATCAT. For this explanation, I will use PyMOL as an example.

2. Prepare your structures: Make sure you have the PDB files of the protein structures you want to compare. These could be the crystal structure of the protein and the docked structure obtained from your docking experiment.

3. Load the structures in PyMOL: Open PyMOL and load both structures using the "load" command or by dragging and dropping the files into the PyMOL window.

4. Align the structures: In PyMOL, you can use the "align" or "super" command to superimpose the structures. The "align" command performs a sequence-based alignment followed by a structural superposition, while the "super" command performs a structural superposition without sequence alignment. For example, if you have two structures named "protein1" and "protein2", you can use the following command to align them:

```
align protein1, protein2
```

5. Calculate RMSD: After the alignment, PyMOL will display the RMSD value in the output window. This value represents the average distance between the atoms of the two structures after superposition. A lower RMSD value indicates a better match between the structures.

6. Analyze the results: If the RMSD value is low (typically below 2 Å), it suggests that the docking results are in good agreement with the crystal structure. However, if the RMSD value is high, it indicates that the docking results may not be accurate. In such cases, you may need to optimize your docking parameters or try different docking algorithms.

7. Visualize the superposition: You can visualize the superimposed structures in PyMOL to further analyze the differences between the structures. This can help you identify regions with significant deviations and understand the possible reasons for the discrepancies.

Remember that RMSD is just one of the many metrics used to validate docking results. It is essential to consider other factors such as binding energy, ligand-protein interactions, and the overall quality of the docking pose.

If your results are not satisfactory, you may need to revisit your docking protocol, try different scoring functions, or explore alternative docking software. Additionally, it's essential to validate your docking results using experimental data, such as binding affinity measurements or crystallographic data, whenever possible.

23605.question: Can DFT be 'exact' in the limit of the uniform electron gas?
23605.context:
I was wondering if DFT (or specifically, LDA ?) can be exact in the limit of the homogeneous electron gas? In that case, shouldn't the self-interaction error perfectly cancel out? I realise that such a material might not exist, but in theory, is this true?
I am aware that nothing is perfectly exact without accounting for relativity, quantum electrodynamics, quantum gravity, etc. So by exact I just mean to say that the energy corresponding to this specific Hamiltonian is exact (meaning no self-interaction error):
23605.gt:
Let us represent the exact exchange-correlation (xc) energy as a sum of an exchange term (x) and a correlation term (c):
$$
\tag{1}
E_{xc} = E_x + E_c~ .
$$
For a uniform electron gas (UEG), we do have an exact expression for the exchange term:
$$
\tag{2}
E_{x} = - \frac{3}{4}\left( \frac{3}{\pi} \right)^{1/3}\int\rho(\mathbf{r})^{4/3}\ \mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\ ,
$$
but the correlation term is only known in the unphysical limit of infinitely strong or infinitely weak correlation, and for the spin-unpolarized case. In the case of infinitely strong correlation and no spin polarization, we have:
$$
\tag{3}
E_{c} = A\ln(r_{s}) + B + C\ln(r_{s})r_{s} + Dr_{s},
$$
in terms of the Wigner-Seitz radius, which I will give here for a 3D gas with a number density of $n$:
$$
\tag{4}
r_s = \left(\frac{3}{4\pi n}\right)^{1/3}.
$$
The expressions for $A,B,C$ and $D$ are not simple. For example, here is $C$ (from a 1956 paper by Gell-Mann and Brueckner) to second order in the logarithmic divergene and 4th order in perturbation theory:
$$
\tag{5}
C=\frac{2}{\pi^2}\left(1-\ln 2 \right)\left(\ \ln \left(\frac{256}{9\pi^{4}}  \right)^{1/3} - \frac{1}{2} + \frac{\int R(u)^2\ln R(u)\textrm{d}u}{\int R(u)^2\textrm{d}u } \right) + \delta,\\
\delta = \frac{3}{8\pi^5}\int\!\!\!\!\int\!\!\!\!\int \frac{\textrm{d}q\textrm{d}^3p_1\textrm{d}^3p_2}{q^2 + \textbf{q}\cdot \left( \textbf{p}_1 + \textbf{p}_2\right)} + \frac{6}{\pi^3}\int\!\!\!\! \int_0^1 \frac{R(u)^2}{q}\textrm{d}q \textrm{d}u.
$$
The integrals area obtained by numerically, so they are not exact, but they can be made exact to within floating-point error if desired.
For a spin-polarized UEG, further approximations are made, and for a UEG that is not in the infinitely strong (or infinitely weak) correlation limit, we again have to rely on approximations, such as the following: VWN (Vosko-Wilk-Nusair, 1980), PZ81 (Perdew-Zunger, 1981), CP (Cole-Perdew, 1982), PW92 (Perdew-Wang 1992), Chachiyo (2016).

I will now summarize the current limitations on "exact" xc-energy functionals for a uniform electron gas (UEG). The gas has to be:

spin-unpolarized
in the limit of infinitely strong correlation, or infinitely weak correlation

Even in these cases, the expressions are not entirely exact because:

they involve truncating an expansion for a logarithmic divergence (to second order, in the above example, but I suppose if one really wanted to, they could keep going until the sum of all remaining terms are deemed to not matter at machine precision),
they involve truncating an perturbation theory expansion (to fourth order, in the above example, but machine precision can probably be achieved as in the above point),
they involve numerical integrations, which also can in principle be done to within machine precision.

Conclusion: In theory there exists some exact functional for the UEG, but until now  we only know what it is for the special case just described, and even in this special case there are series that have to be truncated to get these formulas, and even after that, there's integrals that need to be done numerically.

23610.question: Interpretation of electronic band structure diagram
23610.context:
I want to understand the electronic band structure diagram of the following image, corresponding to $\text{MoS}_2$ (TMD):

I read about DFT (density functional theory).
DFT is based on solving the Schrodinger equation for a set of atoms. Through the Born Oppenheimer approach, it is possible to decouple the nuclear and electronic wave functions.
We just then need to solve the Schrodinger equation for electrons. Using the two Hohenberg and Kohn theorems, we obtain the Kohn Scham equations:
$$\bigg[-\frac{\hbar}{2m}\nabla^2+V(r)+V_H(r)+V_{XC}(r)\bigg]\psi_i(r)=\epsilon_i(r)\psi_i$$
Computationally the problem is solved as follows:
-Define n[r] (random)
-Solve Kohn Scham equation and find $\psi(r)$
-Calculate new n(r): $n(r)=2\sum\psi^{*}(r)\psi(r)$
-If n(r) calculated is equal to the original, the program will stop. If they're different, the program recalculate the Kohn Scham equation with n(r) calculated previously.
According to Hohenberg and Kohn's theorem 1, each electronic density uniquely corresponds to an energy in the ground state, therefore, once the program ends, knowing the electronic density, we know the energy in the ground state.
I don't understand how DFT relates to the various lines obtained from the graph and I don't understand what DFT is related to orbitals. How was the graph obtained based on the DFT?
23610.gt:
Started as a comment, turned into an answer. Someone else can give more detail and precision in the explanation, but here I'll just give a rough sketch of the general idea.
I think you may have conflated $\psi$ with the system wavefunction. In the Kohn-Sham equations, $\psi_i$ is an orbital and $\epsilon_i$ the energy of that orbital. Going from a molecular case to a periodic system, we can think of combining the orbitals of the monomers to create a crystal orbital, but this crystal orbital and its energy will depend on how we align the phase of the monomer orbitals.
The band structures in your post depict just that: each band corresponds to a monomer orbital and the band gives the energy of the crystal orbital (y-axis) with respect to the phase arrangement of the monomer orbitals (x-axis). The symbols on the x-axis are labels for particular points in k-space that define the phase with which the orbitals combine. For example, the $\Gamma$ point is the origin in k-space and corresponds to each monomer orbital having the same phase in the crystal orbital. Another point might mark that the phase of the orbitals changes by $\pi/2$ for each monomer unit.

23635.question: How to set different exchange correlational functionals in VASP?
23635.context:
I want to test different exchange correlational functional on Magnesium silicide to investigate the electronic properties. For example, if I have the POTCAR library for various pseudopotentials of Mg and Si where we can specify the type of functional from the title/header let's say PBE. How can I change this PBE to PW91 in INCAR to see the effect? The following screencast is my INCAR for structure relaxation.

Thanks!
23635.gt:
How can I change this PBE to PW91 in INCAR to see the effect?


According to the element order of your POSCAR, concatenate the different POTCARs in the GGA pseudopotentials library to generate the final POTCAR.

Set the GGA tag in INCAR (All other tags in your screencast is OK to me.):

PBE (default):
GGA=PE


PW91
GGA=91


PBEsol:
GGA=PS





More settings can refer to this link: https://www.vasp.at/wiki/index.php/GGA
Hope it helps.

2. Look for the line containing the GGA tag. If it's not present, you can add it.
3. Set the GGA tag to PW91 by adding or modifying the line as follows:

GGA = PW91

4. Save the changes to the INCAR file and run your VASP calculation.

Here's an example of an INCAR file for structure relaxation with the PW91 functional:

```
SYSTEM = Mg2Si
ISTART = 0
ENCUT = 500
EDIFF = 1E-6
EDIFFG = -1E-3
NSW = 100
IBRION = 2
ISIF = 3
ISMEAR = 0
SIGMA = 0.05
GGA = PW91
```

Please note that changing the exchange-correlation functional may also require you to use a different set of pseudopotentials (POTCAR files) that are compatible with the chosen functional. Make sure to use the appropriate POTCAR files for the PW91 functional when running your calculations.

By following these steps, you can investigate the electronic properties of Magnesium silicide using different exchange-correlation functionals and compare the results to understand their effects.

23654.question: One-to-one correspondence between electron density and external (Coulomb) potential
23654.context:
I calculated the electron density of a molecule by a DFT software (Gaussian 16) with a standard setting in terms of the basis set and hybrid functional. After that calculation, I viewed the plot about the correspondence between the obtained electron density $\rho$ and the external potential $V$ by Coulomb (i.e., $V(r) = -\sum_{i=1}^{M} \frac{Z_i}{||r-R_i||}$, where $Z$ is the atomic number and $R$ is the atomic position) on some grid points $r$ in the molecule.
The Hohenberg-Kohn theorem shows the one-to-one correspondence between $\rho$ and $V$; however, my calculation result did not show it. The following figure shows that the same density values provided different potential values or the same potential values provided different density values.
My calculation might be wrong, but I have tried to calculate many times, and the result seems to be correct. Why did I get such a result that seems to contradict the Hohenberg-Kohn theorem?
23654.gt:
This situation does not contradict the Hohenberg-Kohn theorems:

the same density values provided different potential values or the same potential values provided different density values.

The first Hohenberg-Kohn theorem refers not to pointwise correspondence, but rather to correspondence between entire functions. It tells us that if I give you the full density—the entire function, not just values at a few points—you can (in principle) determine the shape of the full potential. However, the relationship is complex: the density at a single point will likely depend on the potential at all nearby points, and vice versa.

23687.question: Artificial intelligence is a hot topic, but should I pursue it if I'm interested in Matter Modeling?
23687.context:
Since my previous question seems to have a large number of views, I would like to ask my central question.
 I am a student now and should decide my major to research soon. AI/ML is a very hot research field and I am very interested in it, but I have some doubts before I study AI/ML.
For example, a paper that my professor told me is a famous research and has about 300 citations in two years. However, I found the GitHub issue of this paper, and the high-accurate ML model (called DimeNet, which is a graph neural network model) can not predict the energy of hydrogen molecule at all (the error is over 100 kcal/mol!). The reason, according to the author of this paper, is that the training dataset (this paper used the benchmark QM9) does not include the hydrogen molecule. (It feels like an AI can not translate the sentence "I like cats" into German because "Ich liebe Katzen (I like cats)" does not exist in the training dataset.)
I have examined the QM9 benchmark dataset and display some molecules and their energies as follows.

As shown in this figure, many data samples have very similar molecular structures and energies, so I believe that even children can easily guess the right-side (test) molecular energy by looking at the left-side (training) ones. Of course, the children has not solved the Kohn-Sham equation; the children just look and guess. That is, this is just a pattern matching and I think this seems not to be physics at all.
As I have posted the previous question, I now understand that transferring to different properties is a very difficult task. However, I believe that a physically-meaningful AI/ML model should be able to be transferred to various physical properties; such a model is called "foundation model" in recent AI/ML. However, current research can not predict the hydrogen molecular energy if the training dataset does not include the hydrogen molecular energy.
23687.gt:
"I am a student now and should decide my major to research soon. AI/ML is a very hot research field and I am very interested in it, but I have some doubts before I study AI/ML."

AI is indeed a hot topic, and there's plenty of reasons to have doubts before committing yourself 100% to a field, but:

"I found the GitHub issue of this paper, and the high-accurate ML model (called DimeNet, which is a graph neural network model) cannot predict the energy of hydrogen molecule at all (the error is over 100 kcal/mol!). The reason, according to the author of this paper, is that the training dataset (this paper used the benchmark QM9) does not include the hydrogen molecule."

But this is what the author actually said:

"From a physical perspective the H2 molecule is certainly the simplest molecule there is, but from the QM9 data perspective this is an extreme outlier. There are no H-H bonds in the QM9 dataset"

Saying that a dataset does not involve "any H-H bonds" is different from saying that it "does not include the hydrogen molecule".
You're making it seem like machine learning doesn't work unless it has been trained on exactly the same system for which you want to make a prediction, which is not true. For example, to predict the energy for C2, the author is not claiming that you would need C2 to be in the training set, as long as enough molecules with C-C bonds (like most organic molecules) were to be in the training set.

"I believe that even children can easily guess the right-side (test) molecular energy by looking at the left-side (training) ones."

Perhaps that's true in this one very specific case from a cherry-picked paper. It does not mean that all machine learning papers demonstrate no more than what "children" can predict on their own.
AI is a very hot field for a good reason. AI more than just machine learning. Machine learning is also more than just pattern recognition. For example reinforcement learning is what was used when AlphaGo beat a human at Go, and has applications in self-driving cars and other autonomous vehicles (the University of Waterloo already offers people on campus an autonomous bus).
In terms of matter modeling, DeepMind (the same company that made AlphaGo) made AlphaFold for protein folding, and AlphaFold has won competitions. DeepMind also made FermiNet which does seem to calculate variational electronic ab initio energies of some systems, which are lower than any other energies calculated (using for example variational Monte Carlo, or diffusion Monte Carlo, or direct full-configuration-interaction solvers). This is truly state-of-the-art research and its thanks to the enormous wealth of valuable insight that artificial intelligence researchers have brought to the world in recent years. Many other examples of applications can be found in our machine-learning tag.
Finally, I do very much appreciate that there's still reasons to be skeptical about how useful AI will be to matter modeling, but I would not at all discourage you from entering the field of AI. Jobs in AI are far more abundant than jobs in matter modeling and often pay 10x more (it is no exaggeration that a lot of AI researchers at Google, Apple, OpenAI and other places earn more than \$1 million/year). Even someone as young as Ian Goodfellow, who did not have a single paper published before 2009, had a salary of \$800,000/year almost immediately after completing his PhD.
Even outside of science, people working in law, education, writing, finance, and many other fields are increasingly using AI, and in many ways it's becoming a form of literacy. Saying that you're too skeptical about it would be like saying you're skeptical about learning math, or computer programming.

It's a good question, and I think what you are experiencing here is the limitations of deep learning models: they can only learn from the data they have been trained on. If the training data does not cover a certain molecule or property, the model will not be able to accurately predict it.

However, this does not mean that AI/ML is not useful in Matter Modeling. It's great to see that you're considering your research interests and potential major. Matter modeling and artificial intelligence (AI) / machine learning (ML) are both exciting fields with a lot of potential for growth and impact. Your concerns about the limitations of current AI/ML models in matter modeling are valid, and it's important to recognize these limitations when deciding on your research focus.

It's true that many AI/ML models, like the DimeNet example you mentioned, can struggle with predicting properties of molecules that are not well-represented in the training dataset. This is a known limitation of data-driven models, and it highlights the importance of having diverse and representative training data. Regarding your concern about the "physically-meaningful" aspect of AI/ML models, it's important to understand that AI/ML models are not meant to replace traditional physics-based models or simulations. Instead, they can be seen as complementary tools that can help accelerate the discovery process and provide insights that may not be easily obtained through traditional methods. In some cases, AI/ML models can even help improve our understanding of the underlying physics by identifying patterns and relationships that were previously unknown.

As a student deciding on a research focus, you have the opportunity to contribute to the development of more robust and physically-meaningful AI/ML models for matter modeling. This could involve working on improving the generalizability of models, incorporating more physical constraints into the models, or developing new methods to combine AI/ML with traditional physics-based simulations.

In summary, if you're passionate about both AI/ML and matter modeling, there is a lot of potential for you to make a significant impact in this interdisciplinary field. While there are limitations and challenges, these can also be seen as opportunities for you to contribute to the advancement of the field and help shape its future.

23642.question: What does this temperature & total free energy profile mean (obtained from VASP NVT molecular dynamics simulations)?
23642.context:
In order to obtain molecular dynamics (MD) simulations trajectory for computing phonon dispersion relation at finite temperature, I performed NVT MD simulation using VASP for my target system.
Here is the temperature & total free energy profile I obtained (temperature in the unit of Kelvin, and total free energy in the unit of eV, the simulation timestep is 1 fs).

Clearly, there is something wrong with my simulation, the temperature keeps fluctuating over a wide range, while the total free energy is constantly decreasing. I have optimized my structure using the standard conjugate gradient method before MD simulation (under the same accuracy level).
What does this temperature & total free energy profile mean? Should I let it run for a bit longer until the total free energy converges?
23642.gt:
In principle, temperature fluctuations are perfectly normal at the nanoscale. In fact, fluctuations are intrinsic to any ensemble. The magnitude (variance) of the fluctuations of the kinetic energy in the NVT ensemble is inversely correlated with the number of degrees of freedom, and if you have a small system, these will necessarily be large, even at equilibrium. You can, however, monitor the average temperature to check if it corresponds to the desired value.
The total and potential energy should also fluctuate around some average value. If they do not do this, the system is not yet in equilibrium. I cannot directly see what is happening in your system, but a decreasing energy is not strange per se. Even if you minimize a structure, this only guarantees you start from a local minimum. There's no reason the MD run finds no new, deeper minima.
model_pred: the total free energy is constantly decreasing, while the temperature keeps fluctuating over a wide range, while the total free energy is constantly increasing
Certainly, while the total free energy profile should mean something is wrong here. Maybe a bit too long.

While the temperature is expected to change within a certain range during the simulation, the total free energy should remain constant, as it is a conserved quantity in the simulation. The fact that the total free energy is decreasing over time indicates that there might be something wrong with your simulation setup, boundary conditions, or the way you have defined your system. It is essential to identify and fix the problem in your simulation to obtain accurate results. By addressing these issues and letting the MD simulation run longer, you should be able to obtain a more reliable temperature & total free energy profile for your target system.

There are a few potential issues that might be causing the oscillating temperature and decreasing free energy in your MD simulation.

1. The initial temperature of the system might be too high, causing the atoms to have high kinetic energies and leading to larger fluctuations in temperature. This could be resolved by starting the simulation at a lower temperature and slowly increasing it to the desired temperature.

2. The system could be experiencing a large amount of strain or stress, which is causing the decrease in free energy. This could be resolved by optimizing the structure further or using a different optimization method.

3. The simulation timestep could be too large, leading to unrealistic atomic movements and energies. This could be resolved by decreasing the timestep.

It might be beneficial to let the simulation run for a bit longer to see if the free energy converges, but if it continues to decrease, it is likely that one of the above issues is causing the problem.

The temperature and total free energy profile you obtained from your NVT molecular dynamics (MD) simulation using VASP can provide insights into the behavior of your target system at finite temperatures. However, based on your description, it seems that there might be some issues with your simulation.

1. Temperature fluctuations: It is normal for the temperature to fluctuate during an NVT MD simulation, as the system is maintained at a constant number of particles (N), volume (V), and temperature (T). However, if the fluctuations are too large, it could indicate that the thermostat settings are not optimal, or there might be issues with the initial configuration or simulation parameters.

2. Decreasing total free energy: In an NVT MD simulation, the total free energy should ideally reach a steady state after a certain period of time. A constantly decreasing total free energy could indicate that the system is not properly equilibrated, or there might be issues with the force field parameters or simulation settings.

To address these issues, you can try the following:

1. Check your thermostat settings: Make sure you are using an appropriate thermostat for your system, and that the coupling constant is set to a reasonable value. You can try adjusting the thermostat settings to see if it improves the temperature fluctuations.

2. Increase equilibration time: It is possible that your system has not reached equilibrium yet. You can try running the simulation for a longer time to see if the total free energy converges.

3. Check your force field parameters and simulation settings: Make sure that you are using appropriate force field parameters for your system, and that your simulation settings (e.g., time step, cutoffs, etc.) are set correctly.

4. Start from a different initial configuration: If the issues persist, you can try starting your MD simulation from a different initial configuration, such as a higher- or lower-energy structure, to see if it improves the results.

In summary, the temperature and total free energy profile you obtained might indicate issues with your simulation. You should investigate the thermostat settings, equilibration time, force field parameters, and simulation settings to address these issues. Running the simulation for a longer time might help, but it is essential to ensure that the other parameters are set correctly to obtain reliable results.

12208.question: Is there a widely accepted reason for the formation of tafoni?
12208.context:
Expansion of tafoni seems to be based on weathering (seems reasonable enough.) But what creates them in the first place? There are a number of explanations online (Wikipedia lists eight plausible causes!) Many websites trying to give a simplified explanation simply say "salt weathering", but from a brief search it's clear that salt weathering is not always the cause of tafoni [0]. They develop on a wide range of rock types, from granite to sandstone to tuffs and conglomerates, and in many situations where they'd be expected to develop they don't.
From what I can tell, they seem somewhat mysterious, and there are explanations that make sense in some cases but not every case of tafoni is well explained. Is there a widely accepted explanation for the formation of tafoni?
Picture of tafoni (Martin Sharman, Wikipedia):

[0] for example: page 75, Arid and Semi-Arid Geomorphology, Andrew S. Goudie
12208.gt:
I had a good geomorphology teacher. He was so good that I bought his book, published on Prentince Hall at 2008. He is an aged an experimented geomorphologist, so I totaly trust there is not an agreement about the physical origin of tafonies (or at least there wasn't an agreement at 2008 when his book was published).

"Its origin [tafonis] is controversial (Twidale and Vidal Romaní, 2005). Some authors differentiate between wall tafonis and basal tafonis, linked to the processes of basal undermining (Smith, 1978, Bradley et al., 1978). It is agreed that the dominant processes are those related to the movement of water with salts close to the surface, which correspond to haloclastism and wetting and drying. Thermoclastism, cryoclasty, dissolution of carbonated cements and wind erosion are also mentioned (Evans, 1969-70, Mustoe, 1983, Young, 1987, Robinson and Williams, 1992). In addition to these subaerial processes, some taphonis can be generated by weathering under the soil surface and subsequent exhumation by erosion (Dragovich, 1969)."
Source: Geomorfología, Prentince Hall (2008), page 152. 
  Translated from spanish by Google.

-Gutiérrez Elorza, M. (2008) "Geomorfología". Ed Prentince Hall.
-Twidale, C. R.; Bourne, J.A., y Vidal Romaní, J.R. (2005): "Beach etching and shore platforms" Geomorphology 67, 47-61.
-Smith (1978) "The origin and geomorphic implications of cliff foot recesses and tafoni on limestone hamadas in the northwest Sahara" Zeitscrift für Geomorphologie, 22, 21-43.
-Bradley, W.C.; hutton, J.T., y Twidale, C.R.(1978). "Role of salts in development of granitic tafoni, South Australia". Journal of Geology 86, 647-654.
-Evans, I.S. (1969-70) "Salt crystallization and rock weathering: a review" Revue de Géomorphologié Dynamique, 19,153-177.
-Mustoe, G.E.(1983)"Cavernous weathering in the Capitol Reef Desert, Utah" Earth Surface Processes and Landforms 8, 517-526
-Young, R.M. (1987) "Salt as an agent in the development of cavernous weathering" Geology 15, 962-966.

While there is no single widely accepted explanation for the formation of tafoni, multiple theories propose different mechanisms that contribute to their creation. Tafoni are commonly found in arid and semi-arid environments and can develop on various rock types, such as granite, sandstone, tuffs, and conglomerates. Some of the proposed explanations include:
