Focus on engaging your core muscles to maintain an upright posture while leaning slightly forward. This will help you maintain stability and control over the stroller. Additionally, pushing the stroller can provide a good upper body workout, as you'll be using your arms, shoulders, and chest muscles more than you would in regular running.

4. Footstrike and stride: ChiRunning emphasizes a midfoot strike and a shorter stride to reduce impact on your joints. When pushing a stroller, you may need to shorten your stride even more to maintain control and stability. Focus on keeping your feet under your center of gravity and avoid overstriding, which can cause you to lose balance or control of the stroller.

5. Safety considerations: Make sure your stroller is designed for running and has appropriate safety features, such as a wrist strap, hand brake, and locking front wheel. Always be aware of your surroundings and adjust your speed and technique as needed to ensure the safety of your children and yourself.

By making these adjustments to your ChiRunning technique, you can continue to enjoy running while pushing a stroller and maintain proper form to minimize the risk of injury.

48646.question: Is a car seat safe to use if the internal styrofoam is broken
48646.context:
I have a car seat that was loaned to a family member and returned with the internal styrofoam structure (under the fabric) broken on one side (see picture)

Is the seat safe to use or do I need to get a new one?
48646.gt: No. I would not risk it.  Usually the manual will say not to use the unit if it's damaged, or even to use it if it's older than a few years.  Parts may look just little bit damaged, but that little bit can cause a failure during an accident that will leave your little one hurt.  Of course, like everything else, there's a tradeoff between cost (in this case free) and safety, but I personally would never use a damaged safety seat.  Save money elsewhere, like by buying less plastic toys they get tired of after a day. :-)
model_pred: yes it is safe to use if the internal styrofoam structure is not broken

A car seat with a broken internal styrofoam structure is not safe to use, as it compromises the seat's structural integrity and effectiveness in protecting the child during a car accident. The broken support may not hold up during impact, potentially resulting in the child being thrown around inside the vehicle and increasing the risk of injury. It is advisable to replace the damaged car seat with a new one to ensure the safety of the child. If you have concerns about the installation or fit of the car seat, you may also want to consult a professional, such as a certified car seat technician, for help with proper installation and ensure the seat is functioning correctly.

It depends on the severity of the damage to the styrofoam structure. If the damage is minor and does not affect the strength and safety of the seat, you may still be able to use the seat. However, it is recommended to have the seat inspected by a certified car seat technician for proper installation and safety. They can determine the extent of the damage and whether it poses a risk to your child's safety. If the damage is significant and compromises the seat's strength or integrity, it would be safer to replace the seat with a new one.

48654.question: Why do Heinz's Honey packets say not to give them to children under 12 months?
48654.context:
I was getting tea today and noticed those cute little honey packets made by Heinz. At the bottom of the packet it says:
 DO NOT FEED TO CHILDREN UNDER 12 MONTHS OLD - why?
48654.gt:
Honey is not recommended at all for babies under one year of age because of the risk of infant botulism. The risk isn't big, but if it happens, it can be life-threatening. Avoiding honey until the child is older is an easy way to prevent this.

To protect your baby from infant botulism:

Don't offer honey. Wild honey is a potential source of C. botulinum spores. Avoid giving honey — even a tiny taste — to babies under the age of 1 year


Source: Mayo Clinic
As Stephie points out, the spores are very heat-resistant and require heating to more than water's boiling point to kill.
model_pred: honey has a lot of sugar in it

The warning "Do not feed to children under 12 months old" is included on Heinz's Honey packets to ensure the safety of young children. Honey is a natural sugar source, but it also contains small amounts of vitamins, minerals, and trace elements. Although honey is generally safe, it is not recommended for children under 12 months because their digestive systems may not have developed enough to process it properly. Additionally, the risk of a child getting an upset stomach or diarrhea from honey is higher in children under 12 months, as their immune systems are still developing and may not be able to handle it effectively. The warning is a precautionary measure taken by the company to prevent any potential adverse effects and ensure the safety of young children.

The warning label on the honey packet from Heinz is a safety precaution to ensure young children do not accidentally ingest the honey. Honey, like most sugary substances, can be harmful to infants under the age of 12 months. This is because their digestive systems have not fully developed, which can make it difficult for them to break down and process honey, leading to potential adverse effects.

Honey can also contain spores of botulism bacteria, which are harmless to adults but can be deadly for young children. To minimize the risk of exposure, it is recommended that children under 12 months old do not have any unpasteurized honey or honey products, which may contain these spores. Additionally, honey should never be given to children under 1 year old if the honey has a high sugar content or if it contains any other potential allergens.

This is because of the risk of infant botulism. Honey can contain spores of the bacterium Clostridium botulinum, which can multiply in a baby’s immature digestive system and produce dangerous levels of toxins. 

Infant botulism is rare, but it can be extremely serious, leading to muscle weakness, paralysis and difficulty breathing. It can even be fatal. 

Babies under 12 months old are at a higher risk for infant botulism because their digestive systems are not fully developed and they are not able to fight off the bacteria as effectively as older children or adults. 

So as a precaution, it is recommended not to give honey, or any products containing honey, to infants under 12 months old.

The warning on Heinz's honey packets about not feeding honey to children under 12 months old is due to the risk of infant botulism. Infant botulism is a rare but serious illness caused by the ingestion of Clostridium botulinum spores, which can be found in honey. These spores are generally harmless to older children and adults, as their digestive systems can handle and eliminate the spores before they cause any harm.

However, the digestive systems of infants under 12 months old are not yet fully developed, making it difficult for them to process the spores. When ingested by infants, the spores can germinate and produce a dangerous toxin that can cause muscle weakness, difficulty breathing, and even paralysis. In severe cases, infant botulism can be life-threatening.

To minimize the risk of infant botulism, it is recommended that parents and caregivers avoid giving honey or any honey-containing products to children under 12 months old. Once a child is over 12 months old, their digestive system is typically mature enough to handle the spores, and it is safe for them to consume honey.

48641.question: Is it ok for my baby to sleep in his swing?
48641.context: I have a Fisher-Price baby swing that my 7-week-old is spending a lot of time in :) I've found that I often put him in wide awake, and a short while later he's soundly sleeping. Is it ok to leave him asleep in the swing? Is there any reason to move him to a crib or bassinet?
48641.gt:
I'll offer two replies, depending on how your baby swing looks and works:

The user Swati wrote that a hammock-style swing is common in Indian culture. It's apparently not toddler-proof in the way that a crib is, but at 7 weeks that is not a concern.
When our son was an infant, he loved to swing in the infant car seat (safely suspended in a door frame using hooks and ropes), and often fell asleep in it. Since the infant car seat is made to provide a safe and comfortable position for the baby, we had no concerns about him sleeping in it. But we often moved him from the seat to his crib in the bedroom once he was sleeping deeply, mostly out of practical considerations - the car-seat-swing blocked the doorway :) and we had to be rather quiet.

Updates: 

The swing you're linking to in your comment provides a somewhat upright position. Be aware that most physiotherapists (source: I'm married to one) will tell you that infants should not be upright until they can sit on their own - before that, the spine and upper body is not sufficiently developed to support the weight of the head and body. So if your swing allows leaning the child back to (almost?) flat, it would be better.
The infant car seat also has a somewhat upright seating position, so we tried to make sure it was leaned as far back as possible.
How flat is flat? That depends on how much you believe the physio arguments. Again based on my wife's comments, I'd say the spine/back should be angled no more than 15-20 degrees above level, but this is not at all an exact statement! I think the underlying idea is to avoid a lengthwise compression in the spine.
model_pred: no, it's not a good idea to leave a baby sleeping in a swing

It is generally considered safe for a baby to sleep in a swing, as long as it is placed in a stable and secure position. In the image, the baby is asleep in a Fisher-Price baby swing, which is a common and reputable brand known for their baby products. It is essential, however, to ensure that the swing is appropriately set up, and the baby is in a proper and secure position to avoid any accidents or risk of falling.

Parents might choose to move the baby to a crib or bassinet when they feel the baby is ready for a more structured sleeping environment, or when they want to reduce the risk of the baby becoming too dependent on swinging to sleep. It is important to follow safe sleep guidelines and consult with pediatricians or other experts for personalized advice on baby sleep safety and transitioning to other sleeping options as the baby grows.

It is generally recommended that babies under 4 months old do not sleep in swings or other baby equipment. While it's true that babies can fall asleep while in a swing, they need to be placed in a safe sleep environment when they are awake, such as in a crib or bassinet, to ensure their safety.

The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends that babies sleep alone on their backs, with no pillows or soft bedding, to reduce the risk of SIDS (Sudden Infant Death Syndrome). Swings may create a sense of being rocked or swayed, which could lead to the development of poor or unstable sleep habits.

In addition, sleeping in a swing or similar equipment can make it difficult to monitor the baby's breathing or to respond to any potential problems quickly. It's always better to place the baby in a safe sleep environment when they are awake, and only then transition them into a swing or other equipment for play.

In conclusion, it's recommended for babies under 4 months to sleep in their crib with no other equipment. If a baby is already used to sleeping in a swing for playtime, they may be able to adapt to sleeping in their crib once they are older and ready to transition from swing to crib.

The Fisher-Price baby swing can be a great option for your baby to sleep in. However, it's important to remember that the swing is not a crib or bassinet, and should not be used as a substitute for a crib or bassinet. If your baby falls asleep in the swing, you should move him to a crib or bassinet immediately.

While it is generally safe for babies to sleep in their swing for short periods, it is not recommended as a long-term or primary sleeping location. There are a few reasons for this:

1) The American Academy of Pediatrics advises that babies should always sleep on their backs, on a flat and firm surface, to reduce the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). A swing does not offer a flat and firm sleeping surface, and the baby may shift into an unsafe position while sleeping.

2) If the swing is not properly secured or malfunctioning, it could potentially tip over or collapse, causing injury to the baby.

3) Prolonged time in the swing can cause a baby's head to develop a flat spot, also known as positional plagiocephaly. This is because the baby's head is resting against the same spot for extended periods of time.

If your baby falls asleep in the swing, it is recommended to move them to a crib or bassinet once they are in a deep sleep.

I am not a medical professional, but I can provide you with some general information on this topic. It is generally recommended that babies sleep on a firm, flat surface like a crib or bassinet for their safety. While it may be tempting to let your baby sleep in a swing, it is not considered the safest option for sleep.

The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends that babies sleep on their backs on a firm, flat surface without any loose bedding or soft objects. This is to reduce the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) and other sleep-related hazards.

Swings, car seats, and other inclined devices may not provide the necessary support for a baby's airway, which could potentially lead to suffocation. Additionally, prolonged time in a swing may cause a baby's head to become misshapen (positional plagiocephaly) due to the pressure on one side of the head.

It is generally fine for your baby to spend some awake time in the swing, but it is best to move them to a crib or bassinet once they fall asleep. If your baby has difficulty transitioning from the swing to a flat surface, you can try swaddling, using white noise, or creating a consistent bedtime routine to help them adjust.

Always consult with your pediatrician or healthcare provider for personalized advice and recommendations regarding your baby's sleep and safety.

48659.question: Is a Rubik's cube an appropriate gift for a 15-month-old child?
48659.context: I am planning to buy some meaningful toys (puzzles, learning toys) to my friend's daughter. She has completed 15 months. Would it be appropriate to buy Rubik's cube. I would appreciate other toy suggestions as well
48659.gt:
At 15 months old, a rubik's cube would not be appropriate.
First, it's kind of a complex puzzle.  Most adults can't solve it.  A 15 month old is going to see it as a brightly colored cube and nothing more.  She will get entertainment value out of it by probably trying throw it or eat it (the stickers aren't good to eat and the individual block pieces are choking hazards).  She won't even understand the goal of a rubik's cube, much less be interested in accomplishing it.
Second, most rubik's cubes I've seen are small enough the fit comfortably in an adult's hand.  Being so small, she won't have the muscle control to really handle it properly.  She won't be able to precisely turn the sides of the cube, much less line it up to be able to turn another side.
Kids at that age generally need bigger toys that require less fine motor skills.  Go google toddler toys.  That should give you a better idea what to look for.
model_pred: yes, a rubik's cube is an appropriate gift for a 15-month-old child

Instead, you might consider gifting age-appropriate puzzles or learning toys that are designed to help children develop problem-solving skills, hand-eye coordination, and fine motor skills. Some examples of such toys include shape sorters, stacking cups, or wooden puzzles with larger pieces that are easier to handle and understand. As the child gets older and demonstrates an interest in puzzles and brain games, a Rubik's cube can be introduced to provide a more challenging and engaging experience.

Instead, you can consider other toys, such as puzzles or learning toys that focus on colors, numbers, or shapes. These toys can be more age-appropriate and provide a fun, engaging experience for the child. - Wooden blocks or stacking toys
- Shape sorters

- Board books with textures or flaps to lift
- Musical instruments such as shakers or drums.

A Rubik's Cube may not be an appropriate gift for a 15-month-old child, as it is a complex puzzle that requires advanced problem-solving skills and fine motor control. At this age, children are still developing their basic motor skills, hand-eye coordination, and cognitive abilities. It is essential to choose toys that are age-appropriate and help them develop these skills.

Here are some toy suggestions for a 15-month-old child:

1. Stacking toys: Stacking rings, cups, or blocks can help develop hand-eye coordination, fine motor skills, and spatial awareness.

2. Shape sorters: These toys help children learn about different shapes and colors while improving their problem-solving skills and hand-eye coordination.

3. Simple puzzles: Large-piece puzzles with knobs or pegs are great for developing fine motor skills and cognitive abilities.

4. Activity cubes: These multi-sided toys offer various activities that help develop fine motor skills, hand-eye coordination, and cognitive abilities.

5. Soft building blocks: Soft, squeezable blocks are perfect for young children to build and create without the risk of injury.

6. Musical toys: Instruments like drums, xylophones, or maracas can help develop a child's sense of rhythm and encourage creativity.

7. Board books: Sturdy, colorful books with simple stories and illustrations can help develop a child's language skills and love for reading.

8. Push and pull toys: Toys that can be pushed or pulled, like a toy lawnmower or a wagon, can help develop gross motor skills and balance.

Remember to consider the child's interests and developmental stage when choosing a toy. It's essential to select toys that are safe, engaging, and promote learning and development.

48640.question: How can firearms be secured from children?
48640.context: How can firearms be secured from children, preferably without locking them away in a full size safe where they would be completely inaccessible in an emergency?
48640.gt:
For babies and toddlers, setting it on a high shelf should be sufficient.  Also, choosing a pistol with a grip safety is a great move -- little hands simply don't have the span to hold it down properly while pulling a trigger (as opposed to "thumb safeties" which are buttons or switches easily manipulated by small hands before firing).  Additionally, unlike thumb safeties, trigger locks, etc. a grip safety does not increase the time it takes to bring the firearm to bear in the emergency.
While your child is very small, it is important to teach firearm safety.  In homes where this is done properly and consistently, the child(ren) in the house don't need to have guns kept away from them, because guns have no mystery any more, and the child(ren) understands the consequences of mishandling, he/she/they will have no urge to use them improperly.
Here's what we did with my (now 8yo) son:

From birth, my son was accustomed to tactical knives, firearms, and other weaponry as part of everyday life.  When he was born, we lived on the military base where my then-husband served.  I'm a practicing martial artist (and now, so is he).
When my son was a toddler, I made a point of leaving training knives (rubber mock-ups of my tactical knives used for sparring practice) within his reach.  My son was allowed to touch them and even pick them up, but only when he handled them with all the care due real blades, something in which I instructed him regularly.
When my son had the rules down, I began leaving my real knives out from time to time, surreptitiously observing to be sure that they were handled properly.
By the time he was three years old, my son could be trusted around blades of any kind.  He asked before picking up a "sharp knife" (i.e. butter knives, putty knives, etc are safe without asking), and when he did use any knife he kept the blade away from his body, cut away from people, and was careful of surfaces that could be damaged.  He NEVER treated a knife like a toy.
At four, my son began cleaning firearms with my brother and father, learning how they work, etc.  He's seen them fired (and what one can do to an angry coyote).
At five, my son began studying martial arts.
I'd like him to have begun learning marksmanship by now, however my son has hypersensitive hearing, so until we are done building an outdoor range at my parents' home, he won't have the opportunity to do so.

Responsible use of weapons (be they fists, knees, feet, knives, guns, swords, or anything else) is one of the basic values my son was raised with.  It is re-enforced daily by our Sensei, by me, by my extended family, and by the other adults in my son's life.  That is more powerful protection than any mechanical measure ever devised.

48639.question: Is there any research on the effects of PG cartoon violence on small children?
48639.context:
Our son is now at the age where we let him watch a moderate amount of children's videos to entertain himself -- all firmly G rated stuff.
I have also been allowing him to watch some recent animated features such as Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (PG) and Megamind (PG) and the Incredibles (PG), with mild levels of cartoon / action violence.
I also rented some classic "Looney Tunes" and "Tom and Jerry" cartoons, remembering how much I enjoyed them as a child. But after auditioning a few, I was kind of shocked how much actual, real cartoon violence they contain, and I quickly backed off those. You see where Groening got his inspiration for the Itchy and Scratchy parody from, it's shocking how violent old cartoons really are!

However, even at the MPAA PG level, I am worried that I might be exposing my son to too much cartoon violence, and I am concerned what effects it might have.
Should I be concerned? Is there any research documenting the effect on children in the 2-4 year age range of watching a moderate amount of G-rated children's videos versus a moderate amount of PG-rated children's videos? 
(Note that I am not asking for the effect of no video, just how risky is it, per any published research on the matter, to deviate from moderate amounts of children's videos at G versus PG)
48639.gt:
Some google-fu got me to the paper Cartoon violence and aggression in youth (pdf) from 2006:

Across the early and middle childhood, laboratory experiments
  using cartoons with comedic violence
  have consistently failed to
  demonstrate significant differences in
  person-oriented aggression. [...] Field
  experiments have consistently shown
  that aggressive behavior towards peers
  increases following the viewing of
  non-comedic violent cartoons.

.

45614.gt:
This method I have found works and can be found at Using GnuCash

As of GnuCash 2.6.15, the Tutorial & Concepts Guide contains a Reports
  chapter. Please refer to the Guide for details about the reports
  included with GnuCash. 
A single report that shows summary amounts for multiple months for multiple accounts
To create a single report that shows summary amounts for multiple
  months for multiple accounts (for example, monthly totals for expense
  accounts over the course of a year), you can use the Transaction
  Report

Choose your Accounts as the Accounts source in the Accounts tab, e.g. highlight "Expenses" and click "Select children"
Set sortkeys in the Sorting tab: Primary key is Account Name, Primary subtotal is enabled. Secondary key is Date, secondary subtotal
  for date key is Monthly
Enable Subtotal table in the Display tab

--Provided by Anthony Dardis

I also recommend In the General Tab, enable Table for Exporting.
This will allow you to copy and paste the multi-column table including totals and the Averages column into a spreadsheet program
This is desirable because there is no way presently to disable the pages long detail lines that display below the table.
This is an example of one I produced.

45453.question: Would you withdraw your money from your bank if you thought it was going under?
45453.context:
The Texas Ratio attempts to measure how well a bank can cover its losses on nonperforming loans.  A ratio over 100 indicates the bank is in trouble.
I cross referenced the texas ratio for banks obtained from here (last updated 10/2009) with the latest list of bank failures from the FDIC (last updated 8/2010).
The ratio does appear to be a fairly good indicator of banks that go belly up.

If my bank has a ratio over 100 I would move my money to a safer bank.  Especially since the FDIC is broke.
Would you move your money?
What Texas Ratio threshold would you tolerate?
Would you leave your money in a high texas ratio bank if the amount was covered by FDIC?
UPDATE:
Many of you will be happy to know that the FDIC is looking to provide UNLIMITED coverage (instead of the current $250,000 limited coverage) for checking accounts.  Of course, the FDIC is still broke but why let that stop them.
UPDATE (12/10/2010):
Bank closures continue to rise and bring the FDIC to it knees:

The 151 closures nationwide so far this year tops the 140 shuttered in all of 2009 and is the most in a year since the savings-and-loan crisis two decades ago.
The growing bank failures have sapped billions of dollars out of the deposit insurance fund. It fell into the red last year, and its deficit stood at $8 billion as of Sept. 30.
45453.gt:
There's obviously a lot of discussion surrounding your question, but if I thought a bank was going under, then yes, absolutely I would withdraw my money.
Now, we can debate whether me thinking the bank was going under was foolish or not, but if I truly believed it, I can't see why I would sit around and do nothing.

45711.question: How safe it is in the long run to regularly invest in the stock market?
45711.context:
I keep seeing the advice of "do not time the market and invest regularly you will eventually be winning over time". 
This advice is often illustrated by a graph of different index funds and show that over a 10-20 year period you end up earning money no matter what happened to the market in the short-term.
But when I take a look at some indexes like the Nikkei 225:

It looks like if you invested between 1990 and 2000 you are still barely getting your money back. And It does not seem to compensate for inflation (but maybe the index funds are updated each year to take inflation into account?).
I've read a few questions about timing the market, and I do agree that you can't beat the market and that you can't really time it accurately. My question is about how safe it is in the long run to regularly invest in it. And if there's a response for situations like the Nikkei's one.
Is the response to invest in multiple indexes funds and it averages out as a win? I've been working for a couple of years and my money is just sitting in low return accounts (~0.5% to 2% a year), as inflation is quite low nowadays it does not really matter but I've been wondering what to do to start investing.
45711.gt:
It's not pretending to be bulletproof advice. You'll certainly lose money some of the time. That's just how it is in the stock market. "Don't try to time the market" is advice that an average Joe can't possibly consistently know how the market will do and always make the right decision. If you buy consistently, sometimes you will be buying high and sometimes you will be buying low. But assuming the stock market moves up most of the time, you'll come out ahead. 
Let's take your chart as an example. The money put into the market in the '90s would have suffered a loss of value. But if you stuck with the plan and continued investing consistently, you would also have put money in the market in 2003, 2011, and other local minima. Investments from lows in 2003 and 2011 would be up 250% at this point. Over time, you'll catch the good points and the bad points but overall you'll win.

Investing in the stock market over the long run can be quite safe and rewarding. Despite short-term volatility, stocks have historically provided higher returns than bonds and other investments. By regularly investing in a diversified portfolio of index funds, as the graph in the image suggests, an individual can benefit from the market's long-term trends and overall growth. It is important to stay disciplined, avoid timing the market, and maintain a well-balanced portfolio to maximize returns and minimize risks. Inflation-adjusted returns can be achieved through investing in index funds that track inflation-sensitive indicators or by holding a mix of stocks and bonds in the portfolio. Additionally, investing in a dollar-cost-averaging manner can help an individual to avoid trying to time the market and instead benefit from the compounding effect of regular investments.

While it is generally a safe idea to invest regularly in the stock market over the long term, it is important to understand the context of the market and the specific index that you are referring to. As you pointed out, the Nikkei 225 index had a significant decline during the 2000s.

In general, it is important to understand that past performance does not guarantee future returns, and investing in the stock market can be highly volatile. This is why it is essential to have a long-term approach and to diversify your investments. By spreading your investments across different sectors and industries, you can reduce the risk of losing money due to the performance of a single stock or index.

Additionally, investing regularly is important to take advantage of compound interest, which can have a significant impact on the overall returns of your investments. However, it is still important to be cautious and not to overextend yourself.

In conclusion, while investing in the stock market regularly can be a good idea in the long term, it is crucial to understand the market and choose the right index or combination of indices to minimize risk and maximize returns.

It is important to remember that there is no form of investment that is entirely risk-free. Investing in the stock market is a good example of this. However, as the adage goes, the greater the risk, the greater the reward. 

The Nikkei 225 is a good example of how you can still lose money in the long run despite regularly investing in the stock market. However, it is important to note that the Nikkei 225 is an outlier in terms of stock market performance. In fact, the Nikkei 225 is often called the "Lost Decade" because of its poor performance from 1990 to 2002. 

Most stock markets around the world have performed much better than the Nikkei 225. For example, the S&P 500, which is the index of the largest companies in the US, has consistently performed well over the past 20 years. If you had regularly invested in the S&P 500 over the past 20 years, you would have seen a significant return on your investment.

Investing in multiple index funds can help to mitigate some of the risks associated with investing in the stock market. By doing this, your portfolio is more diversified and less likely to be impacted by a downturn in one particular market.

In conclusion, investing in the stock market is not risk-free, but if done correctly, it can lead to significant returns in the long run. Diversifying your portfolio by investing in multiple index funds can help to mitigate some of the risks associated with investing in the stock market.

Investing in the stock market regularly over the long run is generally considered a safe and effective strategy for building wealth, especially when compared to keeping money in low-return accounts. However, it's important to understand that there are risks involved, and past performance is not a guarantee of future results.

The example you provided of the Nikkei 225 is a valid concern. It demonstrates that investing in a single index or market can expose you to specific risks associated with that market. To mitigate these risks, diversification is key. By investing in multiple index funds or a globally diversified portfolio, you can spread your risk across different markets and reduce the impact of any single market's poor performance.

In addition to diversification, there are a few other factors to consider when investing in the stock market for the long run:

1. Time horizon: The longer your investment horizon, the more likely you are to experience positive returns. Historically, stock markets have trended upwards over long periods, despite short-term fluctuations.

2. Dollar-cost averaging: By investing a fixed amount regularly, you can take advantage of market fluctuations and reduce the impact of market timing. This strategy helps you buy more shares when prices are low and fewer shares when prices are high, potentially lowering your average cost per share over time.

3. Rebalancing: Periodically reviewing and adjusting your portfolio to maintain your desired asset allocation can help you manage risk and stay on track with your investment goals.

4. Inflation: While it's true that some index funds may not fully account for inflation, investing in stocks has historically provided better returns than cash or bonds, which can help you outpace inflation over the long term.

5. Risk tolerance: It's essential to understand your risk tolerance and invest accordingly. If you're uncomfortable with the potential for short-term losses, you may want to consider a more conservative investment strategy.

In summary, regularly investing in a diversified portfolio of index funds can be a relatively safe and effective strategy for building wealth over the long run. However, it's important to be aware of the risks involved and to manage your investments according to your risk tolerance and financial goals. Consulting with a financial advisor can help you develop a personalized investment plan that meets your needs.

45523.question: How to bump up my credit for buying a house in a year (open another card or not)
45523.context:
Here's a rough breakdown of my non detailed credit report. 
I want to buy a house well condo in a year. I am in the 28% tax bracket. I have 20% or more down to avoid PMI. 
My question is this credit too low to pull it off? The reason my utilization is so high is because I put all my expenses on the card and pay them off each month. 
The only thing I can change is the available limit. Capitol one denied increasing my 4.5K card but they didn't run a real report. Should I try and open another credit card to increase my credit score (only have 2 and a 2 years paid off out of 3 year car loan). 
My total credit won't increase so I was wondering if it makes sense to open another credit card. I will have another inquiry which is a minus but will have maybe 3-5k more credit. Should I do that or stick and hold at my current situation? 
Mind you I know before getting the mortgage to pay for everything in cash so I am utilizing 0% of my available credit. I could pay off my car loan early but I enjoy the extra leverage for investing.
45523.gt:
The question Should I keep recently opened Credit Cards that I don't use? will provide some useful details for you, including an elaboration of the comment from VBCPP regarding zero usage. 
686 isn't bad. I am a real estate agent, and find that banks are typically looking for 640 or higher for their loans. 
Your scorecard is a great way to understand what you can work on. Keep paying on time (of course), the new card - it depends on how many existing accounts you have. If your 2 year average is 24 months/2 accounts, and you add one right now, in one year, you'd be at 16 months/3 accounts. There's not much else you can do for that one except to allow time to pass. Of course, there's the improvement to showing more accounts open, but the hit from a recent credit inquiry. Utilization, discussed in the linked article, can be finely tuned by making small payments mid cycle, i.e to pay enough before the bill is cut to drop the utilization. This easily gets utilization to an "A" and you can try this sooner than later to see the effect.
model_pred: stick and hold at my current situation

To increase your credit score, it is important to understand how credit scores work and the factors that influence them. It is not necessarily the case that having more credit cards will improve your credit score. In fact, too many credit card applications in a short period may have a negative impact on your score.

To improve your credit score, it is better to focus on paying off existing debts, making payments on time, and reducing the utilization rate on your credit cards. Additionally, you can maintain a healthy credit score by avoiding new credit card applications and focusing on building a strong credit history through consistent and responsible credit use.

It might be helpful to consult with a financial advisor or credit expert to develop a personalized plan to improve your credit score and increase your chances of obtaining a mortgage. Remember that it is essential to maintain a good credit score to benefit from lower interest rates and better loan terms when buying a house.

To bump up your credit for buying a house in a year, you could open another credit card and use it to make small purchases or pay down your existing debt. However, opening a new credit card may have a negative impact on your credit score in the short term, as it may lower your credit utilization.

You should also consider making more responsible financial decisions and reducing your debt to increase your credit score. This may involve paying off your car loan or making on-time payments on all your existing debts. By doing so, you can improve your credit score and have a better chance of qualifying for a mortgage with a lower interest rate.

In addition to these steps, you may want to work on building a strong credit history by using your existing credit cards responsibly. Pay down your credit card debt regularly, and avoid making late payments or missing payments altogether.

It is always a good idea to work with a financial advisor or mortgage broker to understand your options and make informed decisions about your financial goals, including buying a house.

There are several steps you can take to bump up your credit score for buying a house in a year:

1. Pay down your credit card balances.  I see that you're paying off your balances each month but your credit utilization is still high at 27%. Try to reduce that number to below 20%.

2. Don't close any credit card accounts. Closing a credit card account lowers your credit score.

3. Keep your oldest credit line open.  The length of your credit history is a factor in your credit score, so it's important to keep your oldest credit line open.

4. Don't apply for new credit.  New credit inquiries will lower your credit score and could be seen as a sign of financial stress.

5. Pay all your bills on time.  On-time payment history is the most important factor that affects your credit score.

6. Check your credit report and fix any errors.  You can get a free credit report once a year from AnnualCreditReport.com.  If there are any errors, it's essential to dispute them with the credit bureau.

Overall, I don't think you need to open a new credit card to improve your credit score. You should focus on paying down your existing balances and making sure your credit report is accurate.

It's great that you're planning ahead for buying a condo and considering your credit situation. Based on the information you provided, here are some suggestions to help improve your credit score within a year:

1. Keep your credit utilization low: Since you mentioned that you pay off your credit card balance each month, it's essential to keep your credit utilization below 30%. This means that if your total credit limit is $10,000, try not to have a balance of more than $3,000 at any given time. You can achieve this by making multiple payments throughout the month or reducing your expenses charged to the card.

2. Consider opening a new credit card: Opening a new credit card can increase your overall credit limit, which can help lower your credit utilization ratio. However, it's important to remember that applying for a new card will result in a hard inquiry on your credit report, which can temporarily lower your credit score. If you decide to apply for a new card, choose one with no annual fee and potentially one that offers rewards or cashback to maximize the benefits.

3. Maintain a good payment history: Make sure to pay all your bills on time, including credit cards, loans, and other obligations. Late payments can significantly impact your credit score.

4. Keep your existing accounts open: The length of your credit history is an essential factor in your credit score. By keeping your older accounts open and in good standing, you can demonstrate a longer credit history, which can positively impact your score.

5. Monitor your credit report: Regularly check your credit report for any errors or discrepancies. If you find any inaccuracies, dispute them with the credit bureaus to ensure your report accurately reflects your credit history.

6. Limit hard inquiries: As you mentioned, hard inquiries can negatively impact your credit score. Try to limit the number of credit applications you submit within a short period.

7. Consider paying off your car loan early: While you mentioned enjoying the extra leverage for investing, paying off your car loan early can reduce your overall debt and potentially improve your credit score. However, weigh the benefits of paying off the loan early against the potential returns from your investments.

By following these steps and closely monitoring your credit, you should be able to improve your credit score within a year. Remember that lenders consider various factors when approving a mortgage, including your credit score, income, and debt-to-income ratio. By focusing on improving your overall financial health, you'll be in a better position to secure a mortgage for your condo.

Typically in the US, you can easily get quotes for both the interest rate and the APR of a loan. While the figures are similar, the APR gives you a better indication of the total cost of the loan, since it essentially combines the interest rate and the closing costs into a single figure, which makes it a good way to compare different loan offers.
So, the simplest way to see if the closing costs you are being quoted are reasonable or not is to shop around and see how this loan compares to others.
If you know a realtor you trust, you can ask for recommendations for local loan officers, and shoot each of them a quick email with a general outline of the kind of loan you're looking for and some general details about the loan. I did this when I bought my house, and I got responses within a day or two from most of them, although you might not get as fast of a response right now, as a lot of people are also currently refinancing given the low interest rates.

I also didn't need to pay a fee for biweekly payments, or pay separate underwriting fees
The appraisal fee is twice what I paid, but the other fees in that section are in line
The settlement fee is ~$300 more than what I paid

Evaluating the meaning and fairness of closing costs for a refinance can be tricky as each lender has different fees and charges. However, you can break down the costs into a few categories and compare them with other lenders to get a better idea of whether the fees are reasonable or not.

The first category is origination charges - this is where lenders make their money, and where you will see the most variation between lenders. Origination charges typically range from 0.5% to 2% of the loan amount, so if you are being charged more than that, it may be worth shopping around for a better deal.

The second category is service fees, which include appraisal, title, and credit report fees. These fees are typically non-negotiable and will be similar across lenders, so unless they are significantly higher than what you have seen elsewhere, they are likely fair.

The third category is prepaids, which include homeowner's insurance and property taxes. These are typically not negotiable and will vary depending on the location of the property.

The final category is escrow fees - this is what the lender charges for managing your escrow account. Again, these fees are typically non-negotiable and will be similar across lenders.

In general, a total closing cost of 2%-5% of the loan amount is considered reasonable. If your closing costs are higher than that, it may be worth shopping around for a better deal. Additionally, you can ask your lender for a breakdown of the fees and see if there are any that you can negotiate or have them remove.

Evaluating the fairness of fees on a refinance can be a bit challenging, but it's essential to ensure you're getting a good deal. Here's a breakdown of the fees you've listed and some guidance on what's reasonable, unchangeable, negotiable, or outrageous.

A. Origination Charges: These fees are charged by the lender for processing and underwriting the loan. They can be negotiable, but they typically range from 0.5% to 1.5% of the loan amount. In your case, the total origination charges are around 1.46% of the loan amount, which is within the typical range.

B. Services You Cannot Shop For: These fees are for services that the lender chooses, and you cannot shop around for them. They include appraisal fees, credit report fees, flood certification, and tax service fees. These fees are generally non-negotiable, but you can compare them with other lenders to see if they are reasonable.

C. Services You Can Shop For: These fees are for services that you can shop around for, such as title-related fees. You can compare these fees with other title companies to see if they are reasonable. Some of these fees may be negotiable, such as the lender's title insurance and settlement fees.

D. Total Loan Costs: This is the sum of A, B, and C. In your case, the total loan costs are around 3.08% of the loan amount, which is within the average range of 2% to 5%.

E. Taxes and Other Government Fees: These fees are non-negotiable and are determined by the local government.

F. Prepaids: These are expenses that you'll have to pay upfront, such as prepaid interest and homeowner's insurance. These costs are generally non-negotiable, but you can shop around for homeowner's insurance to find the best rate.

G. Initial Escrow Payment at Closing: These are funds that will be held in an escrow account to cover future property taxes and homeowner's insurance. These costs are non-negotiable, as they are determined by your property taxes and insurance premiums.

H. Other: No fees listed in this category.

I. Total Other Costs: This is the sum of E, F, G, and H. In your case, the total other costs are around 1.68% of the loan amount.

J. Total Closing Costs: This is the sum of D and I. In your case, the total closing costs are around 4.76% of the loan amount, which is within the average range of 2% to 5%.

Overall, your closing costs seem to be within the average range. However, it's essential to compare these fees with other lenders to ensure you're getting a fair deal. Some fees, such as origination charges and services you can shop for, may be negotiable. Don't hesitate to ask your lender for clarification on any fees you're unsure about and negotiate where possible.

45685.question: Money type for dad's partial distribution from 401k?
45685.context:
My dad is 66, retired,  and has around $75k in his  401k with ADP. He wants to pull $5k out of his account.  ADP sent a form to fill out and I am helping him since he has some questions. On the form there are two sections A and B:

I assume that I should I skip section A and go right to section B. I can click the first check box for a “partial distribution” and enter the distribution amount of $5k. I assume under “payment options” in section B that I should select the first box that says “pay me 100% of the Partial Distribution amount in a cash distribution“. Is this correct? I assume that 100% means  100% of the $5k that  I entered.
I'm confused about the last section which asks about “money type election”.  It gives me two choices: ”pre tax rollover” and ”after tax rollover”. I don't understand which one to pick or even if I have to select one at all (it says select money type below if desired when I check the box). Can anyone shed some light on what I need to select?
All I want to do is get $5k out of his 401k.  I do not want to fill out this form incorrectly, delaying the withdrawal.  Do I need to check a money type or just leave this empty? Has anyone ever filled something like this out? I assume he would get a check in the mail?
45685.gt:
You would choose the "cash distribution" (I am assuming he's wanting the cash and not rolling it to a different retirement account). The other options are to roll over the entire amount you entered, or to do a combination (roll some over, take some in cash)
The last two check boxes determine how much of that $5K will be considered income (and possible taxable). 401(k)s are almost always funded with "pre-tax" money and is taxable when it is withdrawn. They can be funded with "after-tax" funds, which means that the contribution is taxable at that time rather than deferred, and you do not pay tax on the growth either. 
It is rare to have "after-tax" funds in a 401(k) (his quarterly statement would show if there are), so most likely all of it is "pre-tax" and you can either leave them blank or check the "pre-tax" box.  Note that withdrawal of pre-tax funds will be added to his income when he files taxes and might increase your tax due. It might be worth talking to an accountant to see if you need to pay estimated taxes and avoid underpayment.
If he does have after-tax funds in the 401(k), then checking the "after-tax" box would save some money when he files taxes.

I assume he would get a check in the mail?

Do they have some sort of ACH option where he can enter a routing number and account number for direct deposit? That would be faster than a paper check. Otherwise, yes he would probably get a check in the mail.

Based on the image, you should fill out the form by selecting the "pre tax rollover" option under the money type election, as this is typically the default choice for 401k distributions. Based on the information provided, the form appears to be for a partial distribution from your father's ADP 401k. It's a common procedure for retirees to withdraw a portion of their retirement savings in order to cover expenses such as healthcare costs, housing, or other living expenses. The form has two sections, Section A and Section B:

1. Section A: This section is typically used for withdrawal of an entire account balance. Your father does not want to withdraw the entire account balance and only needs to take a partial distribution, so you can skip this section.
2. Section B: Section B contains the information needed to make a partial distribution. Your father should check the first box for a Partial Distribution and enter the amount he wants to withdraw (i.e., $5,000). He should also select the payment option that matches his preference, either a cash distribution (100% of the withdrawal amount) or a rollover to his own IRA or other tax-advantaged account. 45699.question: How to tell the IRS about Roth IRA gains on early withdrawal?
45699.context:
I had to give some of my Roth IRA to my ex-wife, and didn't do it in the wisest manner.
How now do I tell the IRS that only about $80 of the $3,570 that I sent to her are taxable and penalizable gains?
45699.gt:
Typically you'd file Form 8606 with your tax return to determine how much of your distribution is taxable. Specifically, Part III deals with distributions from Roth IRA's. However, the instructions indicate:

Don’t include on line 19 any of the following. .....
Distributions that are incident to divorce. The transfer of part or
  all of your Roth IRA to your spouse under a divorce or separation
  agreement isn’t taxable to you or your spouse.

Then again, divorce related transfers shouldn't be reported on a 1099R in the first place, per Form 1099R instructions:

Transfer of an IRA to spouse. If you transfer or re-designate an
  interest from one spouse's IRA to an IRA for the other spouse under a
  divorce or separation instrument, the transfer or re-designation as
  provided under section 408(d)(6) is tax free. Do not report such a
  transfer on Form 1099-R.

Perhaps that's what you meant by "didn't do it in the wisest manner"? Based on your 1099R, the IRS will expect Form 8606 to accompany, so unless you can get a corrected 1099R I'd imagine you should add Form 8606.
I'm familiar with the Roth IRA distribution side, less so with the twists that divorce adds other than what shows up in the instructions.

To inform the IRS about the Roth IRA gains on the early withdrawal, you should file a Form 8621, "Deposit of Returning Child Support Payments." In this case, you should report the $80 of taxable and penalizable gains as child support received. Attach a statement or a letter to explain the reason for the early withdrawal and detail the amount of gains being reported. Furthermore, you may need to attach a copy of the check or the financial statement showing the withdrawn amount. Make sure to keep a copy of the form and any accompanying documentation for your records, and consult a tax professional to ensure the accurate reporting of the gains and any potential tax implications.

If you have made Roth IRA withdrawals that are subject to taxation and potential penalties, you should report them to the IRS on Form 5329, Additional Taxes on Qualified Dividends and Capital Gains. The form provides a space to report the amount of taxable and penalizable gains, along with the corresponding taxes paid. Additionally, you may want to consult with a tax professional or review IRS publications for more information on how to report these transactions accurately and timely.
The image shows a copy of a tax form for an early withdrawal from a Roth IRA.

You can report this information on Form 1099-R, Distributions From Pensions, Annuities, Retirement or Profit-Sharing Plans, IRAs, Insurance Contracts, etc. 

In Box 1, Gross distribution, you would enter the full amount of $3,570. In Box 2a, Taxable amount, you would enter the $80 that is taxable and subject to penalty. Be sure to also check the box for "Early distribution, no known exception" in Box 7. This will let the IRS know that only a portion of the distribution is taxable and subject to penalty.

You should also include a statement with your tax return explaining the situation and why only a portion of the distribution is taxable.

I'm not a tax professional, but I can try to provide some general guidance on this topic. If you need to report an early withdrawal from your Roth IRA, you'll typically need to fill out Form 1099-R and Form 8606. Here's a general outline of the process:

1. Obtain Form 1099-R: You should receive a Form 1099-R from the financial institution that manages your Roth IRA. This form will report the total amount of the distribution you took from your account.

2. Complete Form 8606: You'll need to fill out Form 8606, "Nondeductible IRAs," to report the taxable portion of your Roth IRA distribution. In Part III of this form, you'll calculate the taxable amount of your distribution and any applicable penalties.

3. Report the taxable amount on your tax return: The taxable portion of your Roth IRA distribution, as calculated on Form 8606, should be reported on your Form 1040 or 1040-SR. You'll include this amount on Line 4b, "Taxable amount."

4. Report the penalty on your tax return: If you're subject to the 10% early withdrawal penalty, you'll need to complete Form 5329, "Additional Taxes on Qualified Plans (Including IRAs) and Other Tax-Favored Accounts." You'll report the penalty on Line 59 of your Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

5. Attach the necessary forms to your tax return: When you file your tax return, make sure to include Form 8606 and Form 5329 (if applicable) along with your Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

Keep in mind that this is just general information, and your specific situation may require additional steps or documentation. It's always a good idea to consult with a tax professional to ensure you're accurately reporting your Roth IRA distribution and any associated taxes or penalties.

45525.question: What is this option offering me on my loan repayment?
45525.context:
I was just updating my auto-repayment for my student loan, when I was given the following option:

((Note: The image highlights two options: "Apply as Refund" and "Apply as Payment"))
I am not sure what the difference is here between these two options - why would allowing interest to capitalize be a good idea?  What exactly does it mean by a 'refund'?  And by "payments you make within 120 days", does it mean payments other than my automated payments?  
I have currently completed my studies for the foreseeable future, and am now in the process of paying my loan off.  Ideally, I would like to be paying the least amount of interest over time, and have the total amount still due on my loan paid off as soon as possible, so what exactly would the better option be here?  
Additionally, for those curious, the loan organization is Great Lakes.
45525.gt:
This election only applies to payments that you make within 120 days of your having received loan money. These wouldn't be required payments, which is why they are called "early" payments. For example, let's say that you've just received $10,000 from your lender for a new loan. One month later, you pay $500 back. This election decides how that $500 will be applied. 
The first choice, "Apply as Refund," means that you are essentially returning some of the money that you initially borrowed. It's like you never borrowed it. Instead of a $10,000 loan, it is now a $9,500 loan. The accrued interest will be recalculated for the new loan amount. 
The second choice, "Apply as Payment," means that your payment will first be applied to any interest that has accrued, then applied to the principal. While you are in school, you don't need to make payments on student loans. However, interest is accruing from the day you get the money. This interest is simple interest, which means that the interest is only based on the loan principal; the interest is not compounding, and you are not paying interest on interest. After you leave school and your grace period expires, you enter repayment, and you have to start making payments. At this point, all the interest that has accrued from the time you first received the money until now is capitalized. This means that the interest is added to your loan principal, and interest will now be calculated on this new, larger amount. To avoid this, you can pay the interest as you go before it is capitalized, which will save you from having to pay even more interest later on. 
As to which method is better, just as they told you right on the form, the "Apply as Refund" method will save you the most money in the long run. 
However, as I said at the beginning, this election only applies if you make a payment within 120 days from receiving loan funds. Since you are already out of school and in repayment, I don't think it matters at all what you select here. 
For any students reading this and thinking about loans, I want to issue a warning. Student loans can ruin people later in life. If you truly feel that taking out a loan is the only way you'll be able to get the education you need, minimize these as much as possible. Borrow as little as possible, pay as much as you can as early as you can, and plan on knocking these out ASAP.
Great Lakes has a few pages that discuss these topics:

How Payments Are Applied
Understand Interest to Avoid Capitalization

A large sudden jump (or dip) and instantaneous recovery in a stock price can be attributed to various factors, such as the release of earnings reports, sudden market changes, or unexpected news events. These events can cause a rapid shift in investor sentiment, leading to fluctuations in stock prices. An earnings report, for example, may show better-than-expected results, prompting a rally in the stock price. Alternatively, a disappointing report may lead to a sell-off. Market changes or unexpected news events can also cause short-term volatility as investors react and adjust their positions accordingly. It is essential for traders and investors to closely monitor these events and market movements to make informed decisions and effectively manage their portfolios.

The stock price of the PFIZER INC. (NYSE: PFE) experienced a large sudden jump (or dip) and an instantaneous recovery on the same day. It went down by 20% in a matter of minutes and recovered to its previous level within minutes as well. This type of volatile movement is often caused by news, rumors, or market events that can impact investors' perceptions and trading behaviors. In the case of PFIZER, the sudden dip might have been due to the announcement of a negative development, such as an adverse court ruling, a negative earnings announcement, or a significant product launch delay. The recovery might have happened because investors' initial negative reaction to the news was quickly overshadowed by positive news, market sentiment, or other factors that drove the stock price back to its previous level. Overall, the volatile movement suggests that PFIZER's stock can be sensitive to various external factors and investors need to be cautious when making investment decisions in this stock.
A large sudden jump (or dip) and instantaneous recovery in a stock price refers to a sudden increase or decrease in the price of a stock, followed by an instantaneous recovery.

This is typically referred to as a "flash crash". 

Flash crashes occur when there is a sudden and rapid decline in a stock's price, typically due to a large sell order being placed. This can be triggered by human error or algorithmic trading which can create a snowball effect causing the stock to plummet.

The instantaneous recovery usually occurs when a circuit breaker is triggered, which is designed to prevent extreme market volatility. Once the circuit breaker is triggered, trading is halted and the stock is given a chance to stabilize, allowing the price to recover.

In summary, a flash crash is a temporary and short-lived market anomaly where a stock experiences a rapid decline and recovery. It does not necessarily reflect the underlying fundamentals of the company and is often caused by technical factors such as high-frequency trading or human error.

A large sudden jump or dip followed by an instantaneous recovery in a stock price is often referred to as a "flash crash" or "flash spike." This phenomenon occurs when a stock's price experiences a rapid and significant decline or increase, only to recover to its previous level within a short period of time.

There are several reasons why a stock price might experience a flash crash or spike:

1. Market liquidity: A lack of liquidity in the market can cause sudden price movements. If there are not enough buyers or sellers at a particular price level, even a small trade can cause a significant price change.

2. High-frequency trading (HFT): High-frequency trading firms use algorithms to execute trades at extremely high speeds. These algorithms can sometimes cause rapid price movements if they react to market data or execute large orders in a short period of time.

3. Fat-finger errors: A fat-finger error occurs when a trader accidentally enters an incorrect order, such as buying or selling a large number of shares at the wrong price. This can cause a sudden price movement as the market reacts to the unexpected order.

4. Market manipulation: In some cases, unscrupulous traders may attempt to manipulate the market by placing large orders to create the appearance of high demand or low supply, causing the price to move rapidly. Once the desired price movement has occurred, the manipulator cancels the orders and takes advantage of the price change.

5. News and events: Sometimes, a sudden price movement can be triggered by a news event or a rumor that affects investor sentiment. In these cases, the price may recover quickly if the news turns out to be false or less significant than initially thought.

When a stock price experiences a flash crash or spike, it can be an opportunity for traders to profit from the rapid price movement. However, it can also be a source of risk, as the sudden price change can lead to significant losses if a trader is caught on the wrong side of the move. It's essential for investors to be aware of the potential causes of flash crashes and spikes and to have a risk management strategy in place to protect their investments.

21599.question: How to determine the chances of inheriting an autosomal recessive disease if the carrier status of parents is unknown?
21599.context:
My question is about determining the carrier chances of an autosomal recessive disease without actually testing for it and to validate my understanding about autosomal recessive disorders.
In order to clarify my question I've drawn the following example scenario:

In this example the carrier status of only one of the family members is confirmed (child 1) as that child is confirmed to be affected by a autosomal recessive disease. To my understanding that makes it 100% certain that both parents have been carriers.
With the understanding that both parents are carriers, child 2 has naturally a 25% chance of being affected, 50% of being not affected but being a carrier and 25% of not being a carrier at all. As we can exclude child 2 from being affected in this example, there are three options left for child 2. To my understanding: a 66% chance of child 2 being a carrier and a 33% change of not being a carrier.
The three grandchildren (children of child 2) are all unaffected but their carrier status is unknown too. The carrier status of partner 1 and partner 2 of child 2 are also unknown. Let's say that the families of partner 1 and partner 2 have no history of similar autosomal recessive disorders and we can therefor assume but not exclude (by natural mutation chance) they are not a carrier.
Is it correct to therefor assume the following about the grandchildren:

If child 2 is a carrier (66% chance): The chances of the grandchildren being a carrier are 50%.
If child 2 is not a carrier (33% chance): The chances of the grandchildren being a carrier is still 33% as they are not affected but the carrier status of the partners is unknown.

So, what are the overall chances for the grandchildren to be carrier? 50%? Is my understanding and are my assumptions correct in this example?

So, 0.66 * .50 + 0.33 * 0 = 33% chance that they are carriers.
You may want to consider de novo mutation or that partner 1/2 are carriers depending on expected frequencies of those events, and not all genetic conditions are quite so perfectly Mendelian so that may also affect estimates a bit.

21544.question: Why does the package leaflet of Ferrograd C advise not to use in the first 13 weeks of Pregenancy
21544.context:
When looking at the advice for iron supplements in pregnancy its seems to be safe if needed, but in all that information the line "Do not take Ferrograd C tablets during the first thirteen weeks of pregnancy appears" why is this? and possibly why is it safe later. 
Link to Package leaflet
21544.gt:
There has been some concern that iron supplementation early in pregnancy might increase the risk for infections, and hypertension.  
However, the current Cochrane review of iron and folic acid supplementation does not find this

We included 61 randomised trials in the review with 44 trials involving 43,274 pregnant women contributing to the analyses. The use of iron or iron and folic acid supplements was associated with a reduced risk of anaemia and iron deficiency during pregnancy. There was some indication that maternal iron supplements during pregnancy could improve outcomes for babies (birthweight and preterm birth) but the evidence for this was not of high quality.There is no evidence that iron supplementation increases placental malaria.

http://www.cochrane.org/CD004736/PREG_effects-and-safety-preventive-oral-iron-or-iron-folic-acid-supplementation-women-during-pregnancy
And if we look at the method of supplementation with intermittent vs daily iron supplementation concludes

Overall, for women receiving any intermittent iron regimen (with or without other vitamins and minerals) compared with a daily regimen there was no clear evidence of differences between groups for any infant primary outcomes: low birthweight (average risk ratio (RR) 0.82; 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.55 to 1.22; participants = 1898; studies = eight; low quality evidence), infant birthweight (mean difference (MD) 5.13 g; 95% CI -29.46 to 39.72; participants = 1939; studies = nine; low quality evidence), premature birth (average RR 1.03; 95% CI 0.76 to 1.39; participants = 1177; studies = five; low quality evidence), or neonatal death (average RR 0.49; 95% CI 0.04 to 5.42; participants = 795; studies = one; very low quality). None of the studies reported congenital anomalies.
For maternal outcomes, there was no clear evidence of differences between groups for anaemia at term (average RR 1.22; 95% CI 0.84 to 1.80; participants = 676; studies = four; I² = 10%; very low quality). Women receiving intermittent supplementation had fewer side effects (average RR 0.56; 95% CI 0.37 to 0.84; participants = 1777; studies = 11; I² = 87%; very low quality) and were at lower risk of having high haemoglobin (Hb) concentrations (greater than 130 g/L) during the second or third trimester of pregnancy (average RR 0.53; 95% CI 0.38 to 0.74; participants = 2616; studies = 15; I² = 52%; (this was not a primary outcome)) compared with women receiving daily supplements. There were no significant differences in iron-deficiency anaemia at term between women receiving intermittent or daily iron + folic acid supplementation (average RR 0.71; 95% CI 0.08 to 6.63; participants = 156; studies = one). There were no maternal deaths (six studies) or women with severe anaemia in pregnancy (six studies). None of the studies reported on iron deficiency at term or infections during pregnancy.

http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD009997.pub2/full

21579.question: Why is prothrombin time not used to monitor the effects of heparin?
21579.context:
Unfractionated heparin (UFH) is an anticoagulant that main works "by inactivating thrombin and activated factor X (factor Xa) through an antithrombin (AT)-dependent mechanism".
Prothrombin time (PT) is an coagulation assay that measures the "extrinsic and final common pathways of the coagulation cascade (factors VII, II (prothrombin), V, X, and fibrinogen)".
Why is PT not routinely used to measure the anticoagulation effects of heparin?
21579.gt:
Most PT assays contain polybrene, which neutralizes heparin. According to "Coagulation assays and anticoagulant monitoring":

Polybrene is a positively charged material that will neutralize UFH, and this is a component of many clot-based reagents. Polybrene is added to the majority of PT reagents (clinicians may want to confirm that the PT reagent used in their laboratory contains polybrene) and is also present in many assays used in the detection of a LA (lupus anticoagulant), such as the dilute Russell's viper venom time (dRVVT) and Staclot LA (Diagnostica Stago) kits.

Theoretically, a high enough dose of Heparin to overcome polybrene neutralizing activity can prolong PT, but this is not consistent enough to warrant monitoring with PT.
Heparin activity can instead be monitored with activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) or anti-factor Xa activity

Prothrombin time (PT) is not routinely used to measure the anticoagulation effects of heparin because heparin does not affect the extrinsic coagulation pathway, which is the pathway measured by PT. Unfractionated heparin (UFH) works by inactivating thrombin and activated factor X (factor Xa) through an antithrombin (AT)-dependent mechanism which is not measured by PT.
UFH has a dose-dependent effect on activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) and international normalized ratio (INR) which are used to monitor the anticoagulation effects of heparin.

Prothrombin time (PT) is not routinely used to measure the anticoagulation effects of heparin because it primarily focuses on assessing the intrinsic coagulation pathway, while heparin functions by activating antithrombin (AT) and inactivating thrombin and factor Xa. PT may not provide accurate or reliable information about the efficacy of heparin in activating AT and preventing the formation of clots. Instead, other assays like the activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) or the International Normalized Ratio (INR) are more suitable for monitoring the effects of heparin, as they take into account the extrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade. In the image, the diagram represents the pathways that make up the classical coagulation cascade, highlighting the differences between PT and other suitable assays for monitoring heparin's anticoagulation effects.

The main reason for not using prothrombin time (PT) to monitor the effects of heparin is that it is not as effective in measuring the anticoagulant effects of heparin as compared to activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). PT measures the extrinsic and final common pathways of the coagulation cascade, which are primarily regulated by factors VII and X and fibrinogen. Heparin, on the other hand, primarily works by inactivating thrombin and factor Xa, which are regulated by different mechanisms and are not measured by PT. Therefore, aPTT is a more reliable and effective tool for monitoring the anticoagulant effects of heparin.

It is important to note that PT does have other uses and limitations. For example, it can be used to monitor the effects of warfarin, a blood-thinning medication that inhibits vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. However, warfarin's anticoagulant effects take longer to develop and are more consistent than those of heparin, making aPTT a more reliable measure of warfarin dosage.

In conclusion, PT is not routinely used to monitor the effects of heparin due to its limited ability to accurately measure the anticoagulant effects of heparin. aPTT is a better tool for this purpose, as it measures the primary targets of heparin, thrombin and factor Xa.

Additionally, UFH has a variable effect on PT, making it an unreliable indicator of the anticoagulant effect of heparin. 

Instead, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is used to monitor the effects of UFH, as it is a more sensitive assay for measuring the inhibition of factors Xa and IIa (thrombin) by UFH.

Prothrombin time (PT) is not routinely used to monitor the effects of heparin, particularly unfractionated heparin (UFH), because it is not sensitive enough to the specific anticoagulant effects of heparin. Heparin mainly works by enhancing the activity of antithrombin (AT), which in turn inactivates thrombin and factor Xa. This action primarily affects the intrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade.

PT measures the extrinsic and final common pathways of the coagulation cascade, which involve factors VII, II (prothrombin), V, X, and fibrinogen. Although factor X is involved in both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways, PT is not sensitive enough to detect the changes in factor Xa activity caused by heparin. This is because PT is more influenced by the extrinsic pathway, which is not the primary target of heparin.

Instead, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is used to monitor the anticoagulation effects of UFH. aPTT is more sensitive to the intrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade, which are the primary targets of heparin's anticoagulant effects. By measuring aPTT, clinicians can more accurately assess the effectiveness of heparin therapy and adjust the dosage as needed to achieve the desired level of anticoagulation.

In summary, PT is not routinely used to monitor the effects of heparin because it is not sensitive enough to the specific anticoagulant effects of heparin on the intrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade. Instead, aPTT is used as it provides a more accurate assessment of heparin's anticoagulant effects.

21598.question: Meaning of "Depletion of methyl-donor pool glycine, serine, and histidine" in a review article

From a review titled Cerebral Folate Deficiency Syndrome: Early Diagnosis, Intervention and Treatment Strategies, from Table 1:

V. Conditions affecting folate metabolism in the brain

Hereditary conditions
Depletion of methyl-donor pool glycine, serine, and histidine


I don't understand the meaning of the line in bold. How could glycine, serine and histidine be related to "depletion of the methyl donor pool"? Are they donors of methyl groups? I googled, and it does not seem so.
A snapshot of the table, with my highlighting:
21598.gt:
THF (Tetrahydrofolate) is the active form of folic acid. THF serves as an acceptor and donor of one carbon units and acts as a coenzyme in such reactions. One carbon metabolism helps in the synthesis of various important compounds like purines, pyrimidine which are used in DNA synthesis and various amino acids. One carbon units are attached to it's 5 and 10 position.

I  don't understand the meaning of the line in bold. How could glycine, serine and histidine be related to "depletion of the methyl donor pool"? Are they donors of methyl groups? I googled, and it does not seem so.

Well, they  don't actually donate methyl groups but are indirectly related. They donate different one carbon units.

Glycine and tryptophan donate formate group which combines with THF to form N10-formyl THF. During conversion of serine to glycine, THF gets converted to methylene-THF.
Histidine after a series of reactions get converted to FIGLU (Formiminoglutamate). THF acts on FIGLU to form N5-formimino THF and glutamate.

These forms of THF are interconvertible. From methylene-THF, methyl-THF is formed which is the abundant form in circulation and acts as a methyl donor.
