21597.question: Does this paper report miscalculated metrics?
21597.context:
During a literature search I stumbled upon this paper, which evaluated the diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonography for the detection of gallstones (compared to the gold standard cholecystectomy).
Their data looks as follows:

TP: 1549
FP: 274
FN: 0
TN: 46


According to wikipedia, sensitivity is calculated as TP / (TP + FN) and specificity as TN / (TN + FP). So if we plug in the numbers, we get:

Sensitivity = 1549 / (1549 + 0) = 1
Specificity = 46 / (46 + 274) = 0.14375

Yet in the abstract they state that they found a

sensitivity of 0.85 and a specificity of 1 for ultrasound in the
identification of gallstones

Is this just wrong or am I missing something? Would be glad if somebody could help!
21597.gt:
As the other answer points out, the authors here have clearly calculated the positive and negative predictive values (PPV and NPV) rather than sensitivity/specificity. They report these clearly in their results section, but everywhere else use the words sensitivity and specificity.
There is a reason that it might not make a lot of sense to consider sensitivity and specificity in this study. Those measures are meant to be real-world measures that are most meaningful when you consider them in light of actual prevalence.
However, look at prevalence here: only 320 people didn't have gallstones, and 1549 did! This is kind of ridiculous - about 80% of people have gallstones! How can this be? Well, the other problem with their study is that they're relying on a gold standard metric that simply isn't available for most people without gallstones.
Why? Their sample is people underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy - they had their gallbladders removed. Specificity is always going to be terrible in this sort of selected group, because you're missing all the people who didn't have their gallbladders removed, most of whom likely would have been negative on the ultrasound.
My guess is that they calculated specificity and sensitivity to start, got numbers that didn't agree with the literature, and went to a statistician or colleague for an explanation. Someone told them that PPV and NPV are likely better measures for this particular situation, and they sloppily edited the paper without changing the other sections, perhaps because they didn't realize (or it was explained incorrectly to them) that these are actually different than sensitivity/specificity.
I'll note that based on their affiliations, the authors seem likely to be physicians. They probably have minimal training in research and statistics; it's possible one or both were even medical students when they wrote the paper.

21537.question: Protection against Flu - in 1957?
21537.context:
I came across a cartoon by Giles from the Daily Express of 28 August 1957. There was controversy about US Armed Forces being stationed in the UK at the height of the cold war. Giles, an acute observer of humanity, was making fun of the fact that US forces in the UK were given "Anti-Asiatic-Flu" injections not available to the people that lived here.

What were these people given in 1957? A vaccine? An antiviral? Would it have done any good at all?
21537.gt:
Probably the flu vaccine. 
The first flu vaccine was developed in 1937, it only protected against one strain of the virus (we now vaccinate against three or four), but by 1942, another strain was added. The US Army even carried out the trials to test the vaccine and used it during WW2.
Was it effective? Yep, at least in 1944. 

During the 1943–1944 season when the epidemic started in early November, the trial was repeated and 6,263 subjects were vaccinated.[10] This time the results showed that only 2.2% of the vaccinated subjects had clinically assessed influenza disease compared with 7.1% of those not vaccinated, an efficacy of 69%.

That's a really good number for a flu vaccine. The study was conducted over a four week period, comparing two groups who used either a Sonicare AirFloss or a WaterPik, in addition to regular brushing. The study found that:

21581.question: Does a unilateral total obstruction of the carotid artery cause brain damage?
21581.context:
The brain receives oxygenated blood from both the internal carotid arteries and the vertebral arteries, which are connected through the Willis circle (Circulus arteriosus cerebri).

Obstruction of terminal vessels such as the A. cerebri media obviously leads to neurological symptoms, but is the Willis circle able to compensate the unilateral total occlusion of any of the 4 main sources of oxygen to the brain?
21581.gt:
Unilateral carotid compression (Carotid Compression Test) is an important procedure before performing vascular surgery for either of the carotid arteries, because during the surgery, they need to be compressed upstream for obvious reasons.
Numbers vary, but in 6%1 to 26%2 of patients, the compensation through the circle of willis was insufficient:

Forty five patients showed no changes during the carotid compression. Two cases showed both weakness of the contralateral side and altered consciousness within 10 seconds of compression. A third patient developed profound altered consciousness with no discernable lateralizing signs. In all 3 cases, these findings were completely reversed within 5 seconds of release of digital compression.


1: Naraynsingh V, Harnarayan P, Maharaj R, Dan D, Hariharan S. Preoperative digital carotid compression as a predictor of the need for shunting during carotid endarterectomy. Open Cardiovasc Med J. 2013;7:110-112. Published 2013 Nov 15. doi:10.2174/1874192401307010110
2: Hetzel A, von Reutern G, Wernz MG, Droste DW, Schumacher M. The carotid compression test for therapeutic occlusion of the internal carotid artery. Comparison of angiography with transcranial Doppler sonography. Cerebrovasc Dis. 2000;10(3):194-199. doi:10.1159/000016056

The Willis circle (Circulus arteriosus cerebri) is an anatomical structure in the brain that connects the two internal carotid arteries and the two vertebral arteries. It allows blood to circulate from the heart to the brain, and also allows for some degree of compensation in case of obstruction of any of the four main sources of oxygen to the brain. However, if there is a unilateral total obstruction of any of the internal carotid artery, it will cause brain damage, and the Willis circle will not be able to fully compensate for it.

A unilateral total obstruction of the carotid artery can indeed lead to brain damage, as it compromises the supply of oxygenated blood to the brain. An obstruction in any of these vessels would negatively affect the brain's ability to receive adequate oxygenation, which could result in a range of neurological symptoms, including weakness, numbness, vision problems, and even stroke. However, the Willis circle itself is designed to compensate for such situations to some extent, as it connects the two major arteries and redistributes the blood flow to the brain, mitigating the risk of severe brain damage. Nonetheless, quick medical intervention is crucial to address and prevent any complications that could arise from an obstructed carotid artery.

However, the ability of the Willis circle to compensate for a blocked artery depends on several factors, including:

- The extent of the blockage: If the internal carotid artery is completely blocked, the Willis circle may not be able to provide enough blood flow to make up for the loss.
- The presence of other blockages: If other arteries in the Willis circle are also blocked or narrowed, the network may not be able to provide sufficient blood flow to the brain.
- The health of the blood vessels: If the blood vessels in the Willis circle are damaged or weakened, they may be less able to provide adequate blood flow to the brain.

In summary, while the Willis circle may be able to compensate for a unilateral total obstruction of the carotid artery in some cases, it is not a guarantee. As you mentioned, the Circle of Willis (Circulus arteriosus cerebri) is an important anastomotic network of blood vessels at the base of the brain that connects the internal carotid arteries and the vertebral arteries. In some cases, the Circle of Willis can compensate for a unilateral total occlusion of one of the four main sources of oxygen to the brain. This is because the collateral circulation provided by the Circle of Willis can redistribute blood flow to the affected area, preventing or minimizing brain damage. However, this compensation is not always sufficient, and the effectiveness of the Circle of Willis in maintaining adequate blood flow depends on the individual's specific vascular anatomy and the presence of any pre-existing vascular abnormalities.

Neosporin is a topical antifungal medication that is commonly used to treat skin infections, including opened blisters. It contains neomycin, a type of antibiotic that works by killing the bacteria that cause infections. It also contains polymixin B, which helps to soften and remove dead skin cells. Neosporin can be applied directly to the skin and is typically recommended for the treatment of small, localized infections such as blisters.

When using Neosporin for opened blisters, it is important to follow the instructions on the label carefully. This typically involves cleaning the affected area with soap and water, allowing the blister to dry, and then applying a thin layer of Neosporin to the area. It is recommended to repeat this process twice a day until the blister is completely healed.

It is important to note that opened blisters can be very contagious, and therefore it is important to avoid touching the blister or the surrounding area. In addition, it is important to not use Neosporin on large or very painful blisters, or on blisters that are located on the face, groin or genitals. If you have a question about the use of Neosporin for opened blisters, it is best to consult with a healthcare professional for guidance.

1. Clean the area: Gently wash the blister and the surrounding area with mild soap and water. Be sure to remove any dirt or debris that may have entered the wound.

2. Apply antibiotic ointment: After cleaning the area, apply a thin layer of Neosporin or another antibiotic ointment to the opened blister. This will help prevent infection and promote healing.

3. Cover the blister: Use a sterile bandage or gauze to cover the blister. This will protect the wound from further irritation and help keep it clean.

4. Change the dressing: Replace the bandage or gauze daily, or whenever it becomes wet or dirty. Be sure to clean the area and reapply antibiotic ointment each time you change the dressing.

5. Avoid further irritation: Try to avoid activities that may cause further friction or pressure on the blister until it has healed.

6. Monitor for signs of infection: Keep an eye out for any signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, pus, or a foul odor. If you notice any of these symptoms, consult a healthcare professional for further evaluation and treatment.

Remember, it's always a good idea to consult a healthcare professional if you have concerns about a wound or its healing process.

44773.question: Durability of chrome rims vs aluminum alloy
44773.context:
We have a Japanese car that recently developed a slow leak in the right rear tire.  One tire shop told us that we needed new tires on the back, but the justification sounded weak so I drove it for a while longer until I got fed up with pumping air into the tire every weekend.
When I took the tires to another shop, the technician pointed out chrome that was coming off the bead seat of the rim.  These are factory stock rims on a six-year-old luxury sedan, so I didn't expect these kind of problems.

Some might contend that this could have been mechanical damage during a tire replacement, or residual issues after someone tried to seal the tire against the flaking rim (only causing more damage later); regardless of the cause, I'm loosing my desire to continue using chrome rims.
That said, are there disadvantages of going with aluminum alloy rims?  I hope to pull some off a similar model from a junkyard if possible, but I want to be sure I'm not getting a different kind of problem going this route.
44773.gt: My experience is that Chrome is the worst possible case, either aluminum/alloy or steel should be much better.  :-)
model_pred: aluminum alloy rims are more durable than chrome alloy rims

44988.question: Why Does Coolant Flow Through the IAC and Throttle Body
44988.context:
On many engines I've seen coolant is circulated through the Idle Air Control valve and the throttle body. One such example is the Mazda 2L 4 cylinder FS used in the 626.  The IAC is ECU controlled, and there is a coolant temperature sensor, so what would be the purpose of running coolant through the IAC?
You can see in this diagram for example that it flows in the IAC then out through the Throttle Body ( or maybe the opposite direction, I'm not sure ):

There is a great picture here which shows exactly how the coolant flows through the IAC to the TB.
44988.gt:
More than likely it's not flowing through the IAC, but rather around the throttle body. In most cases this is done to keep the throttle plates from freezing when it's cold outside. The coolant running through there can provide a lot more heat than is normally available without it, even with a cold vehicle. 
They had the same type thing on the 4th Gen Camaro. Owners would typically bypass this as when the coolant is hot, it actually provides heat to the intake system, which brings down HP somewhat. In most cases you'd want to bypass this instead of blocking off both ends so the coolant continues to flow correctly. If you chose to plug this up, coolant isn't going the directions it normally would and might cause cooling issues or coolant backups. While this isn't likely to happen, there is the possibility of it happening, especially for weaker cooling systems.
Where you live, I'd suspect freezing throttle plates are not a worry.

The purpose of running coolant through the IAC and TB is to help cool down the intake air before it enters the engine. The coolant absorbs heat from the intake air as it flows through the IAC, which helps to reduce the temperature of the air before it enters the engine. The coolant then flows out of the TB and into the intake manifold, where it mixes with the incoming air. This helps to further reduce the temperature of the air and help to improve combustion efficiency.

Coolant is circulated through the IAC and throttle body to prevent overheating and maintain optimal engine performance. The coolant system helps in removing heat generated by the engine during operation, which is crucial to ensure the longevity and efficiency of the engine. By flowing through these critical components such as the IAC and throttle body, the coolant maintains a stable temperature and prevents damage to the engine due to excessive heat. The circulation of coolant also ensures that these components function properly and offers protection against corrosion and wear. In the case of the Mazda 2L 4 cylinder FS engine in the 626, proper coolant flow through the IAC and throttle body can help improve fuel efficiency and reduce emissions, ensuring the vehicle operates at its peak performance.

Coolant flowing through the IAC (Idle Air Control) and the Throttle Body on an engine serves several purposes, including maintaining engine efficiency, controlling engine temperature, and reducing emissions.

The IAC valve is responsible for controlling the air flow into the engine, which affects the engine's performance and fuel economy. By controlling the air flow, the IAC valve helps to optimize the air-fuel ratio and improve combustion efficiency. Additionally, coolant running through the IAC helps to cool the air entering the engine, thereby improving engine performance, reducing emissions, and increasing engine durability.

Meanwhile, the Throttle Body serves as the entry point for incoming air into the engine, and it is responsible for controlling the airflow during acceleration. By controlling the airflow through the throttle, the engine is able to produce power more effectively, resulting in better acceleration performance. Additionally, coolant flowing through the throttle body helps to keep the throttle body and the surrounding components cool, which in turn helps to improve the overall engine performance and durability.

In conclusion, the coolant flowing through the IAC and Throttle Body on many engines serves to improve the engine's performance, reduce emissions, and increase engine durability. This arrangement allows for optimal air-fuel ratio control, cooling, and efficient air intake.

There are a few reasons why coolant is sometimes circulated through the IAC and Throttle Body. The main reason is to prevent icing or condensation from forming on the cold metal components. The coolant helps to keep the components warm and prevents moisture from affecting their operation.

Another reason is that the coolant can help regulate the temperature of the IAC and throttle body, which is beneficial for more precise idle control. The IAC and throttle body are responsible for regulating the airflow into the engine, so having a consistent temperature is helpful for maintaining consistent airflow.

Finally, in some cases, the coolant can also help to cool the IAC and throttle body if they are located near hot components such as the exhaust manifold. This will prevent the components from overheating and potentially causing problems.

To sum up, the presence of coolant in the IAC and Throttle Body can help prevent icing, regulate temperature, and prevent overheating.

The primary reason for circulating coolant through the Idle Air Control (IAC) valve and the throttle body is to regulate and stabilize the temperature of these components. This helps to ensure consistent and optimal performance of the engine under various operating conditions. There are a few specific benefits to this design:

1. Preventing icing: In cold weather conditions, moisture in the intake air can freeze and cause ice to form on the throttle plate and inside the IAC valve. This can lead to poor idle quality, stalling, and reduced engine performance. By circulating warm coolant through these components, the risk of icing is minimized.

2. Improved cold start performance: When the engine is cold, the ECU may need to adjust the idle speed to compensate for the increased friction and reduced efficiency. By warming up the IAC and throttle body with coolant, the ECU can more accurately control the idle speed, leading to smoother and more efficient cold starts.

3. Consistent idle speed: As the engine warms up, the temperature of the IAC and throttle body can change, which can affect the idle speed. By maintaining a consistent temperature through the use of coolant, the ECU can more effectively control the idle speed, resulting in a smoother and more stable idle.

4. Reduced emissions: A stable and consistent idle speed can help reduce emissions, as the ECU can more accurately control the air-fuel mixture. This is particularly important during the engine warm-up phase when emissions are typically higher.

In summary, circulating coolant through the IAC and throttle body helps to maintain consistent temperatures, prevent icing, improve cold start performance, and reduce emissions. This design choice contributes to the overall efficiency and reliability of the engine.

45000.question: Why has white powder formed on metal parts after cleaning with degreaser and what can I do about it?
45000.context:
I just cleaned much of my engine compartment with Abro Heavy Duty Degreaser, and I noticed that on certain metal parts like the valve cover, thermostat housing and transmission housing a white powder has formed:

I left the degreaser on for maybe 30 seconds to a minute, and in some cases agitated it with a brush, then pretty thouroghly rinsed it with a water hose.
This powder won't blow off, but it rubs off pretty easily with my finger as can be seen in the picture.  This did not occur with other metal parts such as the engine block, and various metal pipes and connectors, nor did it happen on hoses or painted parts.  I think the parts it did happen on may all be made of aluminum.

Why did this happen?
How can I easily clean this?
How can I prevent this from happening in the future when I clean?
45000.gt:
Believe it or not, that is corrosion. You are correct in your assumption that the Valve Cover is certainly cast aluminum. Aluminum can be damaged by many de-greasers that are too aggressive. This happens due to a chemical reaction by the cleaner with aluminum parts. Steel or painted parts will not have this oxidation occur. Usually you can avoid this by thoroughly rising or washing the parts provided that the cleaner is not so aggressive that it is etching the parts.
Most notably, oven cleaners/degreasers contain Sodium Hydroxide which actively eats aluminum surfaces unless deactivated relatively quickly by a thorough washing or rinsing.
Failure to do so results in this oxidation occurring once it dries.
The best way to clean this is with a light dishwashing detergent and a stiff nylon bristle brush. More stubborn areas may need a more aggressive cleaner, however since you mentioned it comes off with a touch, it's likely easily removed with just some mild agitation and elbow grease.
Preventing it from happening going forward, avoid using harsh chemicals on your Aluminum. Find Aluminum safe degreasers, or just thoroughly rinse them before they dry out. Never bake out degreaser on aluminum parts. Many degreasers instruct you to work on a warm motor, this is fine for steel parts, but with Aluminum, you should only clean it when it's cool and make sure to rinse it thoroughly.

You can also avoid scrubbing metal components with brushes or agitating them with other abrasive materials, as this may cause further damage. Instead, use a gentle spray and allow it to sit on the metal components for a few minutes, before gently rinsing them with water.

The white powder that forms on certain metal parts after cleaning with degreaser can be caused by a variety of factors, including the type of degreaser used, the amount of degreaser applied, and the temperature of the engine compartment. These factors can contribute to the formation of the white powder, which can be easily removed with your finger or a soft cloth. However, it's important to note that this white powder will not blow off, but it rubs off pretty easily with your finger as can be seen in the picture. This powder won't blow off, but it rubs off pretty easily with my finger as can be seen in the picture. This did not occur with other metal parts such as the engine block, and various metal pipes and connectors, nor did it happen on hoses or painted parts. I think the parts it did happen on may all be made of aluminum. Why did this happen? How can I easily clean this? How can I prevent this from happening in the future when I clean?

The white powder is likely aluminum oxide, a commonly occurring compound on aluminum parts that have been exposed to water and air. When you clean with a degreaser, the protective layer of oil and grime is stripped away, exposing the bare metal to the elements. This causes the aluminum to quickly react with oxygen and water, forming the white powder you see.

There are a few things you can do to fix this:

1. Use a less aggressive cleaner. Instead of a heavy-duty degreaser, try a mild soap and water or a dedicated aluminum cleaner that won't strip away the protective layer.

2. Don't leave the cleaner on for too long. This can cause the degreaser to etch the metal, making it more susceptible to oxidation.

3. After cleaning, apply a thin layer of oil or wax to the surface of the aluminum. This will help to protect it from the elements and prevent future oxidation.

4. Use a microfiber cloth to gently wipe away the white powder. Be careful not to rub too hard, as this can cause further damage to the aluminum.

In summary, the white powder is a common issue when cleaning aluminum parts, but it can be avoided with proper cleaning techniques and by protecting the metal afterwards.

The white powder you're seeing on certain metal parts after cleaning with a degreaser is likely due to a reaction between the degreaser and the aluminum components. The degreaser may contain alkaline or acidic compounds that react with the aluminum, causing oxidation and resulting in the formation of aluminum oxide or aluminum hydroxide. This appears as a white powdery residue on the surface of the metal.

To clean the white powder off the metal parts, you can try the following steps:

1. Mix a solution of equal parts water and white vinegar.
2. Dampen a soft cloth or sponge with the solution and gently rub it on the affected areas. The mild acidity of the vinegar should help dissolve the white residue without damaging the metal.
3. Rinse the area thoroughly with clean water to remove any remaining vinegar solution.
4. Dry the metal parts completely with a clean, soft cloth to prevent any further oxidation.

To prevent this from happening in the future, consider the following tips:

1. Choose a degreaser specifically designed for use on aluminum or sensitive metal surfaces. These degreasers usually have a neutral pH and are less likely to cause oxidation.
2. Test the degreaser on a small, inconspicuous area before applying it to the entire engine compartment. This will help you determine if the degreaser is safe to use on your specific metal components.
3. Do not leave the degreaser on the metal parts for too long. Follow the manufacturer's instructions for the recommended application time, and rinse the degreaser off thoroughly with water.
4. Dry the metal parts completely after cleaning to prevent any moisture-related oxidation.

By following these tips, you should be able to prevent the formation of white powder on your metal parts when cleaning with a degreaser in the future.

44818.question: How can I fix a slow indicator on a Honda Hornet?
44818.context:
My Honda Hornet 250 right-hand indicator often takes up to 5 seconds to start flashing, especially when it's cold. The left seems to be fine. When I flick the switch I can hear the bimetallic strip going very fast (several times a second) then it slows down when the indicator starts. The part is shown below - it doesn't seem possible to get into it to clean the contacts, etc.
Is there anything else I can do? If I buy a new part will this fix the problem or is there a chance it's something else?
44818.gt:
There's a chance the relay needs to be replaced. There's a couple steps you could try beforehand though.  

Check resistance between all the wires from the light controls to the relay to the light bulb itself. As long as there's zero to very little resistance you know all your wiring is ok.
You can clean the contacts. Use some steel wool and/or sandpaper to clean any contacts that are exposed, fold up some sand paper to clean any contacts that might be hard to get to.
Once they're clean, and if that does the trick, put a little dieletric grease on all the terminals.

If that all fails just replace the relay, as long as they're available they're probably really cheap. I doubt it could be attributed to anything else. Wouldn't be a bad idea to just take a quick look at your bulbs and bulb sockets.

First, it's important to check that all the indicator bulbs and wiring are in good condition. If there are any faulty connections or bulbs, this can cause the indicator to function poorly.

Unfortunately, it is not possible to open and clean the contacts on this type of relay, so you will need to replace it. Replacing the relay should fix the problem, but if the issue persists, there may be an underlying electrical issue that will need to be addressed by a mechanic.

It sounds like the issue could be related to the flasher relay, which is responsible for controlling the blinking rate of the turn signals. The bimetallic strip you mentioned is part of the flasher relay, and it's possible that it's worn out or has a poor connection. Here are a few steps you can take to troubleshoot and potentially fix the problem:

1. Check the bulb: Before diving into the flasher relay, make sure the right-hand indicator bulb is in good condition. A faulty bulb can cause slow or irregular blinking. Replace the bulb if necessary.

2. Clean the connections: Corrosion or dirt on the electrical connections can cause poor performance. Locate the flasher relay (usually under the seat or near the battery) and disconnect it. Clean the connectors with a contact cleaner or a small brush, and then reconnect the relay.

3. Inspect the wiring: Check the wiring for any signs of damage, wear, or loose connections. Repair or replace any damaged wires or connectors.

4. Test or replace the flasher relay: If the issue persists after checking the bulb, connections, and wiring, it's likely that the flasher relay is the culprit. You can try testing the relay with a multimeter to confirm its functionality. If it's not working properly, you'll need to replace it with a new one.

Purchasing a new flasher relay should fix the problem if it's indeed the cause. However, it's essential to go through the troubleshooting steps mentioned above to rule out any other potential issues. 44986.question: Modding Honda Ridgeline cigarette lighter to power USB ports
44986.context:
I am doing a project in my '06 Ridgeline where I am taking out the iPod / Aux add-on and putting in a Bluetooth / Aux add-on at the back of the radio. In the process I will be removing the left cigarette lighter and replacing it was a USB and Aux port.
I've also been thinking about putting in some USB ports for charging and data transfer in the car and I figured that since I'll be taking the dash apart anyway, this is the perfect time to put those USB ports in. 
I have chosen to put in a powered USB 3.0 hub which requires 12v. Therefore, I found an automotive DC to DC buck-boost regulator which is rated to output 12v at the appropriate wattage over the expected operating range of the vehicle's battery. Also, the input to the DC to DC buck-boost is appropriately fused. My idea was to take the now unused 12v outlet and wire it to my DC to DC regulator which ultimately powers my USB hub for glorious charging and data transfer.
My question is this: What is the connector at the back of the cigarette lighter and where can I buy a mating connector to make my own wiring harness that plugs into my DC to DC regulator? Alternatively what resources should I go to to find the information myself preferably without taking apart the dash.
Pardon me if this is the wrong forum.
UPDATE:
I have found a cigarette lighter replacement at the following link. I'm assuming I'm looking for the mating connector that fits the wiring shown on the left. It's unnumbered so I'm stuck again.

http://parts.sonshonda.com/showAssembly.aspx?ukey_product=1470290&ukey_assembly=275911

To replace the bulb, follow these steps:

1. Open the hood of the car.
2. Locate the daytime running light housing, which is located in the lower part of the headlight assembly.
3. Remove the screw that secures the housing to the assembly.
4. Pull the housing out, then rotate the bulb holder counterclockwise and remove it from the housing.
5. Remove the old bulb from the holder by gently pulling it out.
6. Insert the new bulb, making sure it is securely seated in the holder.
7. Reinstall the bulb holder into the housing, turning it clockwise to secure it.
8. Reinstall the housing into the headlight assembly, making sure to tighten the screw.

23365.question: How can I clean a double-layer tea filter?
23365.context:
I have a double-layer tea filter like this one: 

I use it to filter rooibos tea, which can have very fine particles. The problem I have is that over time, many tiny particles have become trapped between the two mesh layers, shown by the arrow.
The only way I can think of to remove them is by burning them using a blowtorch. However, since the mesh wire is so fine this would probably destroy it.
Is there a better method?
23365.gt:
No doubt, by now, you have rapped, tapped, blown, washed, rinsed, and repeated.
You gave me the idea about burning them, but not with a blowtorch—with chemicals.
If nothing else has worked, you can Try a household oven cleaner to "burn" the particles from between the screens. Lye, from a hardware store, will work faster; but, would cost more than replacing the tea filter.
Follow instructions on the label. "oven" cleaners contain corrosive alkalis that will have a very similar effect on the tea leaves as a blowtorch would. It just takes longer.
After overnight treatment, neutralize the stuff as suggested (in cool water), wash and rinse thoroughly. Better? Repeat.

There are a few options you can try to clean the double-layer tea filter:

1. Use a fine-bristled toothbrush or a small wire brush to try to brush out the trapped particles. Be gentle when using these tools, as you don't want to damage the mesh wire.
2. Soak the filter in a mixture of equal parts water and white vinegar. Let it soak for a few minutes, then scrub the filter with a brush or your hands to remove any particles.
3. Use a small amount of baking soda to create a paste, then rub it into the filter with a sponge or your hands. Let it sit for a few minutes before rinsing it off with water.
4. You could also try using a small amount of baking powder to create a paste, then rub it into the filter with a sponge or your hands. Let it sit for a few minutes before rinsing it off with water.

It is important to note that the filter should be cleaned regularly to prevent the buildup of particles.

23384.question: Damaged Gears from a Paper Shredder
23384.context:
I have a paper shredder with some damaged gears, which are from the CD shredding slot.

There are some info over the web about how to repair plastic gears with resin. However, I'm not comfortable whether such repairs would handle the strength required.
And looking for new ones, I've found out a plethora of gears suppliers. However, it seems very unlikely to find out one with the same specifications.
Any recommendation on how to repair these gears?

Gear Measurements

Gear 1

Number of teeth: 24
Outside Diameter: 40.0mm
Pitch height: 3~4mm
Pitch thickness: 5.6mm


Gear 2

Number of teeth: 25
Outside Diameter: 40.5mm
Pitch height: 3~4mm
Pitch thickness: 5.1mm
23384.gt:
I honestly doubt you'll find replacement parts for 2 reasons:

Most people don't bother repairing any appliances anymore because buying new is cheaper than paying for repairs.
Manufacturers don't want you to repair broken appliances because they only make money from sales of new appliances, not from sales of spare parts.

What you could do is:
Browse ebay or a local market platform for someone offering a used paper shredder of the same model. I suspect most people only use the paper slot so you may be able to scavange the gears from the used machine.
Or order these specific gears to be 3D printed or laser cut according to your specifications. There are several tools available online that can digitally design gears of the same dimensions as the ones you want to replace.
If you go for 3D print, the gears must be resin printed to be able to withstand force. The cheaper extrusion prints don't form strong enough bonds between layers and would probaly break at the first test run. Resin printers print a whole layer in one go and the layers adhere to one another very strongly. Make sure your digital gear is completely filled in the center (to form a strong solid body) or the printer may replace all that material with a grid pattern, which is sufficient for most applications but not what you want.
Laser cuts offer insane precision and a wide range of materials that can be cut, but I'm afraid you'd have to go for steel (more expensive) because acryllic sheets (cheaper) are known to be brittle, especially at sharp angles, and I doubt wood (cheapest) would do much better.

23391.question: How to flip the page without causing too much noise?
23391.context:
I am living on the same floor with a person going to bed early (around 11pm) while I normally work till 2 am. So, I try to reduce the sound of flipping the page. Could you please give me some tricks?
I normally read the page on the page-standing as in the picture because it gives me the good angle to focus and I do not need to bend my neck too much.
23391.gt:
Do What The Professionals Do… [a How To, and WHY]
Professional broadcasters (radio announcers, voice actors, etc.) read material from different sources such as news stories, scripts, public service announcements, and commercials printed on sheets of paper.
These sheets of 'copy' are usually placed within view in close proximity to a sensitive microphone.
Any irrelevant sounds/noise(s) generated inside the studio are minimized and any production with background noise is considered unprofessional.
Early in a successful audio announcer's training is the technique to deal with sounds of handling paper:

All pages are printed on one side only.
Pages are stacked, loose, in reading order.
No pages are attached to each other.
Each page has a 'dog-eared' lower-right hand corner** so that it can be grasped individually.

In practice, the voice artist grasps the uppermost dog-eared corner and the top-most page is lightly (AND SILENTLY) slid from the pile onto a secondary 'read-it' pile to the side- facing upwards to avoid handling noise. Pros NEVER flip a page.Only amateurs and untrained public speakers turn pages.
** This technique has the added benefit of easily continuing on to the starting point of the new page as you finish reading the top page as you slide it away.[mini 'reading direction' tutorial… English (& LTR reading language) readers start a page at the top left corner of the text block and continue reading to the bottom right. As the reader gets near the end of the top-most page, it is pulled slowly, and slightly downward and to the right, while reading, to reveal a few lines at the top corner of the next page. Now, when the end of the text is reached, the eye can quickly jump to the beginning of the next page—without a pause—as the previous page is put with the pile of pages already read.Rinse and repeat until the end of the narrative.]
Good luck.

23394.question: How to fix sticky plastic?
23394.context:
I have a music keyboard (Korg PA-3x) and it’s been at the corner of my living room for a year or so without touching it. One day I realised the plastic parts around the screen and the area where the joystick is located is very sticky. The plastic used to be a bit soft and now it’s sticky as if it’s covered with oil residue.
At first I thought it’s really oil fron the cooking landed on it but when I try to wipe it, I can collect a layer of oily stuff but underneath is still sticky.
Because I’m not using the keyboard I want to sell it but with this issue people are hesitant to buy it or they bid a very low price.
I tried to wash it with a mixture of vinegar and baking soda but no luck. The layer seems to be very thick and because if the shape of the plastic it’s hard to wash it.

Does anyone know what happened to the plastic and how to clean it?
23394.gt:
This is a problem that has been discussed on Korg forums:
Where to get replacement joystick bezel and LCD bezel?

As many have noted, the joystick bezel and the bezel around the LCD on the PA3x have a tendency to oxidize, become sticky, and degrade in humid environments. I would like to replace these (as I suspect others would also). Can anyone direct me to where these parts can be purchased? Thank you!


Solution 1: buy another panel

I have located the part names and numbers as follows: Joystick panel: KEYBOARD SIDE PANEL PA3X SILKSCREEN PLAL001024

Here is a video showing how to make the replacement
KORG Pa3X - wymiana panelu joysticka (side panel)

Solution 2: clean off the sticky mess

I can confirm that rubbing with a methylated spirits soaked cloth (might be called denatured alcohol in US) worked well for me and the problem is gone. You should weigh up the risk of doing this (rub too hard and you could remove some printing) vs the risk of damaging the unit in removing the bezels.

As noted, don't overdo it

Sadly the previous owner overdid the job and destroyed the lettering.

This is a common issue with certain types of plastic, particularly softer plastics. What happens is that over time, the chemicals in the plastic break down and react with the air, creating a sticky, oily residue on the surface.

There are a few methods you can try to clean this off. 

- Try using a dilute solution of rubbing alcohol and water (about 50/50) and gently wiping the surface with a cloth or sponge. This can help dissolve the residue and remove it from the surface.
- Another option is to use a mild soap or detergent and warm water. Again, gently wipe the surface with a cloth or sponge, being careful not to apply too much pressure and damage the plastic.
- If neither of these methods work, you can try using a product specifically designed for removing sticky residue, such as Goo Gone. Be sure to follow the instructions on the product label and test on an inconspicuous area first to make sure it doesn’t damage the plastic.

Once you have removed the residue, you may want to apply a protectant, such as a silicone-based spray, to help prevent the issue from reoccurring.

The sticky residue you're experiencing on your Korg PA-3x keyboard is likely due to the plasticizers in the plastic material breaking down over time. This can be caused by exposure to heat, sunlight, or even just the natural aging process of the plastic. The plasticizers are added to the plastic to make it more flexible and soft, but when they break down, they can create a sticky surface.

To clean the sticky residue from your keyboard, you can try the following steps:

1. First, unplug the keyboard and remove any batteries to ensure safety while cleaning.

2. Use a soft cloth or sponge dampened with isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) to gently wipe the sticky areas. Isopropyl alcohol is effective at breaking down the sticky residue without damaging the plastic. Make sure not to use too much alcohol, as it can seep into the keyboard and cause damage to the electronics.

3. If the isopropyl alcohol doesn't completely remove the stickiness, you can try using a mild dish soap mixed with warm water. Use a soft cloth or sponge to gently scrub the sticky areas, being careful not to let any water seep into the keyboard.

4. After cleaning with either isopropyl alcohol or dish soap, use a clean, damp cloth to wipe away any residue, and then dry the surface thoroughly with a soft, dry cloth.

5. If the stickiness persists, you may need to consider using a plastic-safe cleaner or degreaser, such as Goo Gone or WD-40. Apply a small amount of the cleaner to a soft cloth and gently rub the sticky areas. Be sure to follow the manufacturer's instructions and test the cleaner on a small, inconspicuous area first to ensure it doesn't damage the plastic.

6. Once the sticky residue is removed, you can use a plastic protectant or conditioner, such as 303 Aerospace Protectant, to help prevent future stickiness and protect the plastic from UV damage.

Remember to be gentle while cleaning and avoid using abrasive materials or harsh chemicals that could damage the plastic or the electronics inside the keyboard.

23271.question: Open a suitcase with a numeric lock when you forgot the key code
23271.context:
I have heard that there are ways to open a numeric locks commonly found in suitcases even when you have forgotten the code.  This could be ways to open the lock (without breaking it obviously) and other ways of of solving the situation of the suitcase being locked.
Can you come up with hacks including e. take stuff out of a suitcase without opening the lock in such scenarios or such other hacks.

Image courtesy:http://www.maletasviaje.com/
23271.gt:
Anaximander's answer to a question on travel.SE explains the biro technique:

If your suitcase closes with a zip, then it can be opened with a normal biro (the ubiquitous cheap Bic office biro works particularly well). Simply hold the biro so it points parallel to the zip, with the nib end pointing into the zip teeth (I find about 60 degrees works). Then press down. The pen disengages the teeth of the zip, and you can pull them apart by running the pen or your finger along the zip.
To reclose, simply pull the zipper over the opened part, and then back again. This works even on those suitcases with two zip pulls that lock together. Travel security like this method because it's fast, basically undetectable, and doesn't require any special tooling or any co-operation from the lock manufacturers.

This could be a solution if knowledge of the lock's code will be revealed later (e.g. when a travel companion returns from an outing) allowing the zip tabs to be released and the zip teeth to be re-interlocked for normal operation.

Here are a few ways to open a numeric lock on a suitcase without breaking it:

1. Look for a combination of the lock that may match a common code, such as the birthday of the owner or a simple sequence of numbers.
2. Use a lock pick set to try different combinations of the lock.
3. Try using a hair dryer or heat gun to try and open the lock by expanding the material and hopefully making it more pliable.
4. Try using a rubber band or cloth to try and pry the lock open.
5. If all else fails, you could try to cut the lock off with a pair of wire cutters or bolt cutters.
Please note that I would recommend to be very careful when trying to open a lock.
You can also try to look for the user manual or contact the seller or manufacturer for the way to reset the code.

Please let me know if you need me to elaborate on any of these methods.

When you forgot the numeric lock code on a suitcase, there are a few potential hacks to consider:

1. Use a hair dryer: Heat from a hair dryer can sometimes soften the plastic latches on a suitcase, making them more pliable and easier to open. Carefully applying heat to the latches may help them deform and open the lock.

2. Use a pair of scissors: Gently insert a pair of scissors into the gap between the latches and carefully cut the plastic latches. Be cautious not to damage the suitcase or locking mechanism further.

3. Use a rubber band: Place a strong rubber band around the latches to hold them in place while you try to open the suitcase. This may provide enough leverage to lift the latches.

4. Seek assistance: If none of these hacks work, you might consider reaching out to the airline or transportation service for assistance in opening the suitcase. They may have special tools or instructions to help you.

5. Temporary solution: As a last resort, you can attempt to remove the latches completely and replace them with new ones. This will likely void the warranty on the luggage, but it may be a viable option to get your belongings out of the suitcase.

Keep in mind that these hacks may not work in every situation and may cause damage to your luggage. It is always best to keep track of your lock code or have a backup method for securing your suitcase, such as using a luggage tag with your contact information.

Yes, there are several ways to open a numeric lock without having the key code or breaking it, and some of these include:

1. Using a magnetic pick: This tool, also known as a "pick gun," can be used to pick up small metal objects such as the locking pin on a numeric lock, and then slide it to the left or right to open the lock.

2. Using a bobby pin: Insert a bobby pin into the lock and then gently push it down to move the locking mechanism.

3. Using a paper clip: Similar to a magnetic pick, a paper clip can be bent into a shape that allows it to open the lock by sliding it into a groove on the lock.

4. Using a screwdriver: Some numeric locks have a screw located near the locking mechanism, which can be removed to unlock the lock.

These hacks can be helpful in certain situations when one has forgotten the numeric key code or lost it. However, it's important to note that these methods might damage the lock or suitcase, so proceed carefully to avoid any damage or injury.

The image shows a suitcase with a numeric lock, which is commonly found in suitcases, backpacks, and other travel accessories. The lock is secured with a combination of numbers and letters, making it difficult to open if you have forgotten the code. However, there are ways to open the lock when you have forgotten the code, such as using a combination of tools, such as a screwdriver or a pair of pliers.

Your post makes me think of a number of different scenarios, and I'm sure my response won't cover all possible situations, but quite often, these types of locks have a simple and easy-to-guess solution. For example, if your suitcase is privately owned, try some common combinations like 1-2-3-4, 2-4-6-8, and 4-4-4-4. If these fail, hopefully, you have someone in your life who is authorized to go through your bags, and they might possibly have the combination. Sometimes, if the code has been recently changed and forgotten, just start with the last known combination and work your way up or down the numbers until you find the correct one.

If none of the above works, off course the easiest way to get inside the suitcase is to cut the lock off. Some people might consider this a last resort, but let's face it, the flimsy lock on a suitcase is not really keeping anyone out. They are also easily replaceable. However, if you really don't want to destroy the lock, there are some other options.

You could try the old "paperclip trick." It's a bit of a long shot, but it has worked for some people in the past. To try this, all you have to do is straighten out two paper clips and then bend one into an L-shape. Stick the straightened out paperclip into the lock and then use the L-shaped one to maneuver the tumblers into the correct position. If you're lucky, the suitcase will pop open.  Another possibility is to use a thin and flexible piece of metal or plastic (like a toothpick) and slide it between the dials. This can sometimes loosen the tumblers enough to allow the lock to open.

In terms of getting stuff out of the suitcase without opening the lock, this will probably only work if you have a soft-sided suitcase. People have also tried using a vacuum cleaner and sucking items out from between the zippers. It's a long shot, but it might work if you're desperate.

Another more likely option would be to unscrew the hinges that hold the suitcase together, and the top should simply come off. This will only work if the suitcase uses screws and not rivets. 

In summary, if you have forgotten the combination to your suitcase lock, here are a few options:

- Start with the last known combination and work your way up or down the numbers until you find the correct one
- Try common combinations such as 1-2-3-4, 2-4-6-8, and 4-4-4-4
- Cut the lock off
- Try straightened out paper clips or a thin piece of metal or plastic to loosen the tumblers and open the lock
- If your suitcase is soft-sided, use a vacuum cleaner to suck out items from between the zippers
- Unscrew the hinges that hold the suitcase together.

Hopefully, one of these options will work, and you will be able to get inside your suitcase!

While I don't encourage unauthorized access to locked items, I understand that sometimes people forget their own lock combinations. Here are some methods to try if you've forgotten the combination to your numeric lock on a suitcase:

1. Trial and error: Since most suitcase locks have 3-digit combinations, there are 1,000 possible combinations (000 to 999). You can try each combination one by one, starting from 000 and going up to 999. This method can be time-consuming but has a 100% success rate if you're patient.

2. Feeling for resistance: Some locks have a small gap between the dials and the lock body. You can use a thin piece of metal or a small flathead screwdriver to feel for resistance as you turn the dials. When you feel resistance, it may indicate that you've found the correct number for that dial. Repeat this process for all dials.

3. Shim the lock: Some locks can be opened using a shim, which is a thin piece of metal or plastic that can be inserted between the lock body and the shackle. Slide the shim into the gap and wiggle it around until the shackle pops open. This method may not work on all locks, and it requires some skill and the right tools.

4. Contact the manufacturer: If you have a lock from a well-known brand, you can try contacting the manufacturer for assistance. They may be able to provide you with a master key or a method to reset the combination.

5. Consult a professional: If all else fails, you can take your suitcase to a locksmith or luggage repair shop. They may be able to open the lock without damaging it or help you reset the combination.

As for taking stuff out of a suitcase without opening the lock, it's generally not possible without causing damage to the suitcase. The best course of action is to try the methods mentioned above to unlock the suitcase first.

Rubber bands can become brittle and break over time due to exposure to heat, light, and humidity. Here are a few tips to help prevent the rubber bands from aging:

1. Store the rubber bands in a cool, dry place, away from direct sunlight and heat sources.
2. Keep the rubber bands away from moisture and humidity.
3. Avoid using them in high temperatures, such as in a kitchen or near a stove.
4. Avoid exposing the rubber bands to UV light, such as from a sunlamp or a UV-B bulb.
5. If you have to store the rubber bands for a long period of time, consider wrapping them in a plastic bag or container to protect them from moisture and dust.

By following these tips, you can help prevent the rubber bands from aging and breaking. However, it is inevitable that the rubber bands will eventually lose their elasticity and break, especially if they are frequently used.

To prevent rubber bands from aging and maintain their elasticity, you can follow these steps:

1. Store them correctly: Instead of storing rubber bands in a pile, spread them out flat or in a loosely wound bundle, allowing them to air-dry. Keep them away from direct sunlight or heat sources, as these can cause the rubber to degrade.

2. Regularly clean and inspect them: Periodically clean rubber bands with a mild detergent and water solution to remove dirt, ink, or any other contaminants. Inspect the bands for signs of wear or cracking, and replace them if necessary.

48523.question: What causes a tree to split into multiple trunks?
48523.context:
There is this one tree (I believe an oak tree) near my road that is very large in size.  Practically at the base of its trunk, it diverges into four other large trunks:

What causes this phenomenon in trees?  Is it possible that this was actually a few trees that have grow into one another?  To me, this looks like one tree that early on in it's life, somehow split off into four trunks like so.
48523.gt:
In the US this is sometimes called a schoolmarm (alt school-marm) there are a number of ways they can form.  OSHA Logging terms
As mentioned in the existing answer some trees like willow grow very aggressively and a low cut stump can have several shoots that grow in to trees.
Two or more seeds growing in the same location can grow multiple trees.  If there is sufficient sunlight neither new sapling will have a significant advantage and both will prosper.  This can occur naturally or from manual over planting. 
Sometimes two forks of a tree will grow about the same. This can be an internal event for the tree, or due to an external trauma like the top of the main trunk of the sapling being browsed by wild life, leaving lower branches to compete to become one or more primary trunk. 
Schoolmarm's pose risks on two fronts. 

The junction between the trunks is more likely to catch water and/or debris, leading to rot that will cause it to fail (die and/or fall) earlier then it neighbors.
It is very difficult to cut down the tree safely, without good access to back side of the tree it is difficult to control the direction of it's fall. Directional tree felling
model_pred: a tree splits into multiple trunks due to a split in the bark

48413.question: Can bears smell food inside dry sacks?
48413.context:
I like to do long hikes in black bear country.  I don't really go on multiday trekking trips, just day trips but often need to bring food along.  I know that backpackers often keep their food in bear vaults but since I don't spend the night, I am only really interested in not smelling to the bear, not keeping them from getting to my food while I'm sleeping.  I was wondering if a dry sack, like this 
would seal the contents so they don't smell outside, just like they keep water from getting in.  The advantage of this vs. a bear vault is that the extra air can be bled out for a minimal size of the cargo in the backpack.
48413.gt:
No, it will not. A bear will smell your food regardless of what container you put it in. A dry bag may reduce the distance from which a bear can smell your food, but will not make it impossible to smell your food. 
It's extremely uncommon – especially for black bears – for a bear to attack a person to try to steal their food. Unattended food is a big risk, but if the food is in your pack, it's not a  significant problem. The bear may smell it, but it'll also smell you and hopefully hear you, and generally decide it's not worth the risk. 
For day hikes I don't think special food protection against bears is necessary. Being aware of your surroundings and making sure bears hear you coming will be much more effective.

Dry sacks can certainly help reduce odors from leaking out, but they are not completely leak-proof. If there are any gaps in the seal or small holes in the sack, odors may be able to escape. Additionally, if the exterior of the sack is contaminated with food or other scents, bears may be attracted to it even if the contents are sealed well. 

While a dry sack may reduce the chances of attracting bears, the only guaranteed way to keep them from detecting your food is to use a bear-proof container. If you are spending the day in bear country and don't want to carry a bulky bear vault, another option is to use airtight bags or odor-proof bags, such as OPSAK or Smelly Proof bags, in combination with a dry sack. These bags are designed specifically to seal in odors and can be a good precaution to take in areas where bear encounters are common.

Ultimately, it is important to remember that bears have an excellent sense of smell and may be able to detect food even if it is stored in a dry sack. It is always best to exercise caution and follow local regulations and guidelines for storing food in bear country.

Bears, especially black bears, have an incredibly strong sense of smell, which is estimated to be around seven times more powerful than a bloodhound's. They can detect odors from miles away and are attracted to the smell of food.

A dry sack, while effective at keeping water out, is not specifically designed to be odor-proof. It may reduce the smell to some extent, but it is unlikely to completely eliminate it. Bears may still be able to detect the scent of food inside a dry sack, especially if they are in close proximity.

If you want to minimize the chances of attracting bears while hiking, you can consider using an odor-proof bag or container designed specifically for this purpose. These bags, such as the OPSAK or LOKSAK, are made from materials that help to block odors and can be more effective at preventing bears from detecting the smell of your food.

Additionally, it's essential to practice good food storage and handling habits while hiking in bear country. This includes:

1. Packing out all food waste and trash.
2. Avoiding strong-smelling foods.
3. Washing your hands and utensils after eating.
4. Storing food and scented items (like toiletries) away from your resting area if you take breaks.

Remember that bears are generally more interested in your food than in you. By taking precautions to minimize odors and practicing good food storage habits, you can reduce the likelihood of attracting bears and enjoy your day hikes in black bear country.

48535.question: Why do some birds fly in a V-formation?
48535.context:
When birds gather into groups, they fly in a variety of different formations and patterns. 
Some birds fly in a formation that looks like the letter "V". Several species of geese, pelicans, and ibis are just a few of the more commonly known. This is their normal flying behavior, but can be more evident during migration due to the large numbers headed in the same direction. 
Many of the other common birds fly in swarms or flocks without any obvious pattern. There's also a type of flock, exhibited breathtakingly by starlings, which is called a murmuration. It's a group of literally thousands of birds flying in magnificent and unique patterns.
I took the picture below over a lake in Rhode Island, United States, recently. The geese had just taken off and were flying in some side-by-side V-shaped groups. As they got farther away they gathered into smaller, tighter, individual V-shaped groups. Of course I've seen this behavior before, but on that particular evening, as I watched these geese leave the area, I began to ponder it more deeply. 
Why do some birds fly in a V-formation? Is it just a random pattern or is there a reason for it?
48535.gt:
They fly on the wing currents produced by the birds in front of them. It's similar to drafting someone in front of you while cycling or racing. The leader is breaking trail, and the followers are benefiting by exerting less energy. They end up in a V-formation as birds join up one after the other and find a wing to fly on. After a while, the leader gets tired and falls back onto the wing of another, giving a different bird the opportunity to spear-head through the wind.
Here's a National Geographical article that details the specifics:Birds That Fly in a V Formation Use An Amazing Trick.
From the article: 

As a bird flaps, a rotating vortex of air rolls off each of its
  wingtips. These vortices mean that the air immediately behind the bird
  gets constantly pushed downwards (downwash), and the air behind it and
  off to the sides gets pushed upwards (upwash)

.

Birds, particularly migratory species, fly in V-formation for several reasons. One of the primary reasons is aerodynamic efficiency. When birds fly in a V, they take advantage of the updraft created by the bird in front of them, which reduces the amount of energy they need to expend. This is known as "flying in the slipstream" or "formation flying."

Another reason is enhanced survivability. When birds fly in a V-formation, they can maintain visual contact with their neighbors, which helps them stay together and avoid becoming separated. This is particularly important during migration when birds travel long distances and may face various challenges such as weather, predation, and exhaustion. In a V-formation, the birds can also more effectively keep an eye out for potential threats, like predators, and alert each other if they detect danger.

Additionally, flying in a V-formation can help birds conserve energy during flight, as the lead bird breaks the wind and creates a slipstream for the others to follow. This slipstream allows the birds behind to fly at a reduced air resistance, making their journey more energy-efficient.

In conclusion, birds fly in V-formation for various reasons, including increased aerodynamic efficiency, enhanced survivability, and better coordination during migration.

There are several reasons for birds flying in a V-formation. 

First, it helps with the energetics of flying. The lead bird in the formation creates an updraft of air, which the birds behind it can use to keep aloft. This makes it easier for the birds to maintain their altitude and reduces the amount of energy they have to expend.

Second, the V-formation helps the birds keep track of each other. It is easier for each bird to see the others in the formation when they are arranged in a "V." This helps them to stay together and avoid collisions.

Finally, the V-formation makes it easier for the birds to navigate. The lead bird can serve as a guide, with the others following behind. This allows the group to stay on course and helps them to reach their destination more efficiently.

In summary, flying in a V-formation helps birds save energy, maintain group cohesion, and navigate more effectively.

Birds, particularly migratory species, fly in a V-formation for several reasons, primarily related to energy conservation and communication. Here are the main benefits of flying in a V-formation:

1. Energy conservation: When a bird flaps its wings, it creates an updraft, or a small area of lift, behind it. By flying in a V-formation, each bird (except the leader) can position itself in the updraft created by the bird in front of it. This allows the birds to use less energy to maintain their altitude and speed, as they are essentially "riding" on the air currents generated by the bird in front of them. This is especially important during long migratory flights, as it helps the birds conserve energy and travel greater distances.

2. Communication and coordination: Flying in a V-formation allows birds to maintain visual contact with each other, making it easier to communicate and coordinate their movements. This is particularly important during migration, as it helps the birds stay together and navigate as a group.

3. Reducing wind resistance: The V-formation also helps birds reduce wind resistance by allowing them to fly in the "slipstream" of the bird in front of them. This means that each bird experiences less air resistance, making it easier to maintain their speed and position within the formation.

4. Leadership rotation: The lead bird in the V-formation experiences the most wind resistance and does not benefit from the updrafts created by other birds. To ensure that no single bird becomes too fatigued, the birds will periodically rotate positions, allowing a new bird to take the lead while the previous leader moves to a more favorable position within the formation.

In summary, flying in a V-formation provides birds with several advantages, including energy conservation, improved communication and coordination, reduced wind resistance, and the ability to share the burden of leadership. These benefits are particularly important for migratory birds, as they help them travel long distances more efficiently and safely.

48553.question: Compromised Ropes in Retail Stores
48553.context:
Reposting this from a Facebook discussion. It's a picture taken from a retail store where they have attached a pin-tag through the rope to prevent theft; a common practice at this location.
My gut reaction is to avoid it like the plague, but I have a tendency to treat the rope like it's sacred. Has anyone seen this elsewhere? Would you climb on it?
48553.gt:
Ewww. I'm guessing they punch pin tags through $700 gore tex jackets as well? And condoms? Even if the amount of damage is minimal, it's still something I would rather not do to my rope. Some climbers do use a needle and thread/dental floss to make small whippings on the rope to indicate that the rope ends are approaching. However, there is a large difference between carefully easing a sharp needle through the rope and a retail worker, chugging along at minimum wage, shoving one of those generally ragged and burred pins through the rope.
As you mention, the amount of damage is probably not severe. Similarly, storing the ropes in a vat of motor oil or sewage would probably still be safe. This doesn't mean that any of those are best practices and speaks more to the great extent that manufactures go through to make sure their products are safe. Furthermore, I don't recall the UIAA having a rope testing category for standard falls with a security tag through the rope. 
At the very least it shows a lack of respect for the end user (my making money is more important than your safety). There are so many other ways to prevent shoplifting a rope. For example:

Even moderately alert retail staff. Ever have someone walk by at the crag and stuff your rope into their pocket without you noticing? Neither have I. It isn't exactly an object that lends itself easily to shoplifting.
Using a cable-type security device through the center of the coil, such as one of these. While it would be possible to uncoil the entire rope and free the rope from the cable, it is mighty hard to imagine that someone wouldn't notice. 
Using adhesive magnetic sensor tags on the packaging/hidden away inside the coils of the rope. 
Keeping ropes inside a locked cabinet/display case or behind a counter. 

If the establishment is unwilling to alter their practices, I would strongly urge you to contact the manufacturers of the ropes. Having worked specialty outdoor retail, this would be the sort of thing that a reputable manufacturer would drop a dealer for.

48595.question: What is this sharp, curved notch on my knife for?
48595.context:
I recently bought a knife that near the handle end of the blade has a sharp, curved part:

I don’t think it’s a choil because it’s sharp. What is its use? I thought something to do with stripping sinew from bones maybe?
It is a PBK Brute Lock Knife MH-689.
48595.gt:
It's a line cutter, the idea is that you use it to cut lines, string etc. The reason that it's curved is to keep the line from slipping off the blade, using the rest of the blade would be quite difficult to do.
See here for more examples.
You wouldn't want to use it for skinning.
model_pred: What is this sharp, curved notch on my knife for?

The sharp, curved notch on your knife is called a "choil," which is a technical term for a specific type of blade geometry. The choil is designed to facilitate the stripping of sinew from bones and cleaning tasks in general. It allows for easier and more efficient cleaning of small, intricate areas by providing a sharp, curved edge that can easily conform to the shape of the object or surface being cleaned. In addition to being useful for culinary purposes, the choil can also be an aesthetic feature that adds a unique touch to the knife's design.

The sharp, curved notch on your knife is likely a thumb rest, also known as a thumb ramp. This feature is designed to improve grip, comfort, and control when using the knife. The curved shape of the thumb rest allows users to more easily grip the knife and apply pressure with the thumb while using it. It provides a comfortable, secure feeling during use and helps prevent fatigue during extended periods of cutting and handling tasks.
PBK Brute Lock Knife MH-689

The sharp, curved notch on your PBK Brute Lock Knife MH-689 is called a gut hook. It is designed for hunters and outdoorsmen to assist in field dressing game animals. The gut hook is used to make a clean cut through the animal's skin and abdominal cavity without puncturing the internal organs, which can contaminate the meat.

To use the gut hook, you would puncture the skin with the tip of the hook and then pull the knife along the length of the animal, allowing the hook to slice through the skin and membrane. This helps to keep the blade away from the internal organs and makes the process of field dressing more efficient and clean.

While it can be used for other purposes, such as cutting rope or cord, its primary function is for field dressing game animals.

48382.question: An adjustable length knot for 2 lines and a carabiner for easy suspension
48382.context:
I have made myself a pair of wrecking balls from a cricket ball and 6mm accessory cord for pinch grip pullups and I am currently debating what is the best way to create a knot to hang them. Currently one of them looks as follows:

The objective is to be able to tie these anywhere that has a bar element, from gym, to tree, to home suspension beam or a simple hook.
My original idea was to simply tie the remaining cord to the carabiner and attach that to the nylon straps of my rings. However it would be much sweeter to use a knot that can self hook (i.e. attach onto itself) with some adjustability (terrain is never perfect).
My idea would be to throw the carabiner over and hook it back onto the cords which could use a ladder knot. I put this query to the more experienced climbers / rope savvied folk to see if there is a better option than my idea. 
If this is of relevance, the remaining cord available is 1.5m at least on both ends.
48382.gt:
The clove hitch is probably what you're looking for. You can even tie it directly on the branch/beam/bar without worrying about adding a carabiner. You could also tie it to the carabiner, adjust the length, and clip the carabiner to something else.
The clove hitch is one of the most under-utilized climbing knots out there. It's infinitely adjustable because you're directly using the rope/cord, and you can tie it on any number of things.

48617.question: Are these prints in snow of a bobcat or cougar?
48617.context: Are these footprints of a bobcat or cougar ? I apologize that there is no reference scale in the image, but the footprints measured about 3.5 or 4 inches in both dimensions. I found these while hiking in a less trafficked trail near Mariposa Grove in Yosemite on 11/15/20.
48617.gt:
Based on your estimation of size, they're definitely cougar. Bobcat tracks should be half (or less) that size.
The Michigan Department of Natural Resources has a nice track comparison page 9with dimensions): Distinguishing Cougar, Coyote, and Bobcat Tracks.
Those tracks are pretty fresh, too. That's a nice find and well photographed.

48525.gt:
That tree got bent over but not snapped when it was just tall enough so that its tip was where the end of the bend is now. The existing bent wood stayed where it was, with layers added each year enlarging its diameter.  Now 25 year later you come along and see it.
The tree survived its early trauma, but if it weren't growing at the side of a field that is actively maintained, it probably would not have gotten enough light to compete.  Note that some of its branches are already dead.

48563.question: How dangerous is a swarm of bees?
48563.context:
Sometimes, bees will split from a hive, and a bunch of them (including a new queen bee) will swarm, and move to build a new hive.

As you can see, there is an awful lot of bees huddled together around the new queen, they aren't doing much, just clustered the tree branch.
Exactly how dangerous is a group of swarming bees?
48563.gt:
A swarm (used in the technical sense to mean that clump you show in your question) is about the least dangerous formation in which you can encounter bees. Their bellies are full (they eat before they swarm) they have no hive to defend, and you are basically not of interest to them. Beekeepers literally gather swarms into buckets to put them into new hives. (Keep in mind, though, that they are familiar with bee behavior and can evaluate the "mood" of a swarm better than you can, so don't get too close.)
As Wikipedia says:

A swarm of bees sometimes frightens people, though the bees are usually not aggressive at this stage of their life cycle. This is principally due to the swarming bees' lack of brood (developing bees) to defend and their interest in finding a new nesting location for their queen. This does not mean that bees from a swarm will not attack if they perceive a threat; however, most bees only attack in response to intrusions against their colony. Additionally, bees seldom swarm except when the position of the sun is direct and impressive. Swarm clusters, hanging off of a tree branch, will move on and find a suitable nesting location in a day or two. Encountering a bee swarm for the first time can be alarming. Bees tend to swarm near their hives or honeycombs, so if a swarm is visible then a nest is nearby. Swarms are usually not aggressive unless provoked, so it is important to keep a good distance from swarms in order to avoid provoking them.

Look at them, take a picture, leave them alone, you saw a cool thing.
And yes, I have met a swarm, one actually set up on a warm sunny day in some old beekeeping equipment (including hives with not-quite-enough-frames) of my father's that we were keeping in a shed. There was a lot of crazy around all of that, but nobody got stung.

63834.question: How to protect road damage from rain?
63834.context: Here where I am living in the rainy season the roads are damaged due to the large amount of rainfall. I know the quality of the roads is low, they are made of Damara. I want to protect my road and reduce the damage. Could you suggest some easy way to protect it and suggest a cheap way to rebuild it? I've attached an image example of the road damage.
63834.gt:
As a vehicle travels over a wet road, the tyres push the water into the surface. Depending on the type of surface, it can either push water through the top layer (eg with a chip seal), or wash away away some of the fine material which binds the surface together (eg with an unsealed road). In both cases, this can cause damage.
One of the key ways of preventing damage is to provide a slope (cross-fall) for the water to drain away. I think a gravel (ie unsealed) road requires a higher cross-fall than a sealed road, which makes some sense (the material tends to shift around more, so could more easily puddle).
Another issue is that the water needs to be able to drain away from the side of the road without eroding it or softening it.
Limiting speed of traffic over a wet or damaged road should reduce further damage. A neat psychological trick for doing this is to provide lanes that feel narrow for traffic to drive through. The narrower it feels, the slower people driver. You can make it feel narrower by using taller and more conspicuous sides (eg like the movable barriers in the photo rather than just road cones).
It's hard to understand what damage has been done from a photo taken in such wet weather. Also, it would be useful to know what it was previously like.
My understanding is that the most cost effective way to repair or rebuild can depend heavily on how you measure the cost (if you're the government, then increased productivity essentially offsets cost, for example), what labour and machinery costs, and what materials are available (and how far away they are, and their transportation costs). 
At a high level, optimising the benefits of the road for affordable cost is called Road Asset Management, which also fall under the category of Infrastructure Asset Management. An example of what's involved, for sealed roads, is available here from the New Zealand Transport Agency (which looks after NZ's State Highways).
If I understand it correctly, the first step in managing an asset is to start recording measurements about the asset so that you understand how it's changing, how much is being spent to maintain it, and in what way.
