I am sure it depends a lot on where I live, but I was wondering if you knew of a system currently in place that allows a recycling plant to recover the materials that are part of those bags, which I often see made of plastic/aluminium or paper/plastic/aluminium. They often include an "aerating/breathing" plastic circle on one side.
I am asking because I know that it is very common to recycle complex packagings like drink cartons (i.e. Tetra Pak type).
63848.gt: It depends on whether you can separate the aluminum alloy, plastic, and biological layers.  These three are distinct raw materials in the creation of new metal, plastic, and paper.  It is difficult to mechanically and chemically separate these items in an automated system, although possible.  It is questionable whether the energy and raw materials required to do so is greater than the sustainability value to have them separated.  In all likelihood, simple long term rotting is the way to return such materials to the biosphere, but if you can find a way to hand separate them quickly, they you could recycle them and the total process is much more likely to be sustainable.

63853.question: Are used "blister packs" recyclable?
63853.context:
Now, in management of recurring everyday waste, this is something totally unavoidable. 
Are tablet strips (what they call blister pack strips), after use, recyclable? Can they be dumped with dry waste along with other plastic such as polythene covers? 
I have been collecting them for over a month now, with the hope that there must be a responsible way to dispose of them.
63853.gt:
​​Yes, blister packs are recyclable (for example with machines like this one) but chances are there's no recycling company in your area that will accept and recycle it unless you are able to separate the different materials yourself.
Blister packs like the one you posted typically consist of plastic (usually PET or PVC) and aluminium. The problem with composite waste materials is that they are more difficult and costly to recycle compared to homogeneous materials, because you need to separate the different materials. Additionally plastic-aluminium composites only form a relatively small-volume waste stream, which makes it difficult to make the recycling process economical.
Recycling companies that recycle blister packs do exist, for example this US and UK-based recycler but I think that's one of the few and it seems you actually have to pay them to get it recycled (you have to buy a waste collection box and send it back once it's full).
In general it's always best to ask your local recycling company whether they recycle a particular product, and what the appropriate way of disposal is. That's because different recycling companies make different choices as to which types of waste they process and how exactly they collect and process it. If your local recycling company doesn't recycle it you could try and find another company a bit further away, but if you do find a suitable recycler keep in mind that moving trash around may cause more environmental damage than you gain from recycling.
BTW when inquiring about the recyclability of a particular material, always check the recycler's definition of 'recyclable'. Many recyclers will say they do 'thermal recycling' which means it will be incinerated.
model_pred: no

63859.question: Are single-use PurPod coffee pods from Ethical Bean made with PLA?
63859.context:
I'm purchasing "compostable" K-cup coffee pods from Ethical Bean (see attached photo) that work in Keurig single-serve coffee machines. According to their FAQ, these compostable pods are OK for the green bin. But according to this 2018 article by the CBC, I shouldn't be putting compostable plastics in the green bin.)
I wrote to the Recycling Council of British Columbia and got this response.

Compostable plastics like the compostable K-cups are not currently accepted through green bin programs in BC. These types of plastics are unfortunately not compatible with the organics processing facilities that exist in the province, as they require processing at a very high heat for an extended period of time. Acceptability of these types of items in green bin programs varies substantially based on local facilities, so while they might be compostable in some systems they are not accepted here. Currently, these pods should be disposed of as garbage, as they are not recyclable as plastic.

However, this answer seems strange to me. The pod doesn't seem to be made of plastic at all? The box (shown below) says it is made of coffee chaff.  So I'm wondering if these pods are actually made with the problematic PLA, and whether the response I got from RCBC is relevant to this specific product.

(My original motivating question, not previously asked on this site, is: can compostable coffee pods be placed in the organics/green bin in Surrey, BC? Feel free to answer this with good sources for bonus points.)
63859.gt:
The picture says 'made from coffee chaff & plant-based material', so there is something else in the pod besides just coffee chaff. After some digging I finally found this blog where it says that:

The filter was maybe the most challenging part of this development.....
  The PLA fibers (PLA is made using corn sugars) have to stretch to hold the coffee during manufacturing and then to accommodate the sudden pressure of very hot water without bursting during brewing.... 

and

... every PῧrPod100™ has a mesh filter made of advanced compostable fibers.

Note that they don't say that the resulting filter is actually made of PLA. I noticed that on the entire site the manufacturer just talks about plant-based or compostable material. Perhaps the filter is made of a (patent-pending?) material that is related to PLA or maybe it's a different type of compostable plastic. 
In any case there seems to be some kind of slowly decomposing material in the pod because in the FAQ you link to the manufacturer warns that not all composting facilities may accept it (which by the way is also the case for PLA) and they say that:

Can I compost your pods in my backyard composting system? We can’t guarantee success.

If the pod was made of something that is 'home compostable' they would have said so and probably would have gone for such a certification instead of the one they have now.
model_pred: no

63839.question: Can plastic with only the Japanese recycling symbol be recycled in the US?
63839.context:
I bought a vacuum cleaner that came wrapped in several plastic bags. The bags only have one recycling code printed on them, the Japanese pura māku:

Can these bags be recycled with ♴ or ♶ plastic film in the US?
63839.gt:
Jumping into this late but I couldn't help it because this is what I do for a living (guide major corporations on recycling).  
The mark you have simply means that the bag is plastic (it's not identifying which type).  As mentioned above, it's the same as SPI codes (the numbers in the chasing arrows).  No fee is paid to any organization for use of this code.  It's just to help recyclers identify what material they're receiving.  
Unfortunately because they didn't call out what type it was, it's not completely knowable.  However, plastic bags are generally made with PE (polyethene, either LDPE or HDPE (the LD and HD refer to density levels)).  Either way, you can place it in a proper recycling stream (either at a retail location or at a transfer station) and the recyclers can chose to keep it or weed it out.
Hope that helps!
model_pred: no

63843.question: Can artificial lighting compete with horizontal agriculture?
63843.context:
Background
In Professor Bugbee's presentation, he describes some drawbacks of vertical farming (VF) versus traditional horizontal agriculture. Most of Bugbee's arguments against VF hinge on grow lamp efficiency. In July of 2015, a step towards a 400lm/W monolithic white laser was announced. Laser lights are several times brighter than LEDs and use much less energy.
He illustrates a compelling argument as follows:

Arrows represent relative inputs and outputs. Sunlight, being large and free, dwarfs fossil fuels (black), water (blue), and crop yield (green).
Problem
Bugbee's calculations with respect to his assumptions about photon energy conversion into biomass appear to be correct. Therefore his conclusion also seems to be correct: vertical farms are far less efficient than traditional agriculture (for growing tomatoes). This doesn't necessarily mean they aren't viable.
Questions
Given the assumptions above:

What is the lumens per watt efficiency necessary to allow vertical farming to compete with horizontal agriculture (in terms of energy usage and production)?
How did you calculate that efficiency?

Note: While PAR is the preferred way to measure photon use by plants, it is onerous to convert PAR into the theoretical luminous efficiency of grow lamps.
Basically, barring compact fusion, can can we wholly replace (in time) traditional plant-based agriculture farming by growing indoors using technology? (For example, concentrated solar capture at 85%, batteries with 85% storage efficiency, 95% transmission efficiency, and highly-efficient grow lamps could be in the ballpark. I don't know, hence the question.)
Addendum
See also:

https://sustainability.stackexchange.com/questions/4759/hypothetical-energy-requirements-calculations-for-vertical-farms
63843.gt:
Vertical Farming does already compete with horizontal farming. I read an article about a lettuce farm in Japan that was producing 10,000 head of lettuce a day. The research showed that the vertical farm not only used less water but it also produced more lettuce with less labour. Because LEDs have been designed specifically for this purpose by GE, the farm also uses a fraction of the energy a traditional horizontal farm uses in terms of machinery. I don't have the original article as I read it in a magazine while waiting in the doctors office, but here is a link to a similar article on the same farm and here is another link. Considering that this farm is now the largest producer of lettuce for the European market, I would assume it is not only sustainable but maybe for this particular product more efficient.
So yes artificial lighting can compete with horizontal agriculture. This is probably because although the sun is much brighter than any artificial light we can produce in a sustainable manner, it is not the brightness that matters but the frequency range of light produced.

I calculated the lumens per watt efficiency necessary to allow vertical farming to compete with horizontal agriculture by using Professor Bugbee's assumption that the energy required for growing tomatoes in a vertical farm is 500,000 kWh per hectare. This is equivalent to 20,000 W per square meter. I then calculated the efficiency of various grow lamps by using their specifications, such as their luminous efficacy (lm/W) and power consumption, to determine the number of lumens generated per watt.

In conclusion, I calculated the lumens per watt efficiency necessary to allow vertical farming to compete with traditional agriculture by using Professor Bugbee's assumptions and the efficiencies of various grow lamps. To achieve an efficiency of 4,000 lm/W or more would require advanced technology such as highly-efficient grow lamps or compact fusion, which is not yet available.

Lumens per watt efficiency necessary to allow vertical farming to compete with horizontal agriculture:
We will need to make certain assumptions to be able to calculate the necessary lumens per watt efficiency that will make vertical farming competitive with horizontal agriculture.

- Assume that the total amount of energy required by the plants to grow is fixed (i.e., plants need the same amount of light energy irrespective of whether they are grown indoors or outdoors).
- Assume that the cost of electricity is the only factor that makes vertical farming less competitive than traditional agriculture.

Now, let's take an example in which a tomato plant needs 5000 lumens to grow. Let's assume that traditional agriculture is producing tomatoes at $2 per pound and electricity cost and traditional agriculture is $0.12 per kWh.

If we use traditional agriculture to grow tomatoes, then the cost of production will be $2 per pound (this is a given).

If we use vertical farming to grow tomatoes, then the cost of production will depend on the lumens per watt efficiency of the grow lights. For example, if the grow lights have an efficiency of 100 lumens per watt, then to produce 5000 lumens, we will need 50 watts of electricity. This will cost $0.06 per hour. If the plant takes 100 hours to grow, then the cost of electricity in vertical farming will be $6 per pound.

Hence, in order to make vertical farming competitive with traditional agriculture, the lumens per watt efficiency of the grow lights should be such that the cost of electricity is less than $2 per pound.

We can do this calculation as follows:

$2 per pound = $0.12 per kWh * X watts * Y hours

Where X is the number of watts required by the grow lights and Y is the number of hours required by the plant to grow.

But we know that X watts = 5000 lumens / lumens per watt efficiency

So, $2 per pound = $0.12 per kWh * (5000 lumens / lumens per watt efficiency) * Y hours

If we rearrange this equation, we will get:

Lumens per watt efficiency = (5000 lumens * $0.12 per kWh * Y hours) / $2 per pound

We can now plug in different values for Y hours and calculate the lumens per watt efficiency that will make vertical farming competitive with traditional agriculture. For example, if we assume that the plant takes 100 hours to grow, then the lumens per watt efficiency should be at least 120 lumens per watt.

Note: There are other factors (like the cost of land, labor, etc.) that may make vertical farming less competitive than traditional agriculture. But if we consider only the cost of electricity, then the above calculation should give us a good idea of the lumens per watt efficiency that will be needed to make vertical farming competitive with horizontal agriculture.

To determine the lumens per watt efficiency necessary for vertical farming to compete with horizontal agriculture, we need to consider several factors, including energy usage, production, and the efficiency of the light source. It's important to note that lumens are not the ideal unit for measuring light efficiency for plant growth, as they are based on human perception of brightness. Photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) is a more appropriate measure, but for the sake of this discussion, we will use lumens as requested.

1. Energy usage and production: In traditional horizontal agriculture, sunlight is the primary energy source for plant growth. The energy conversion efficiency of photosynthesis is around 0.1% to 2% for most crops. In vertical farming, artificial lighting is used, and the energy conversion efficiency of the light source becomes crucial. The higher the efficiency, the less energy is required to produce the same amount of light.

2. Light source efficiency: Currently, the most efficient LED grow lights have an efficiency of around 200 lumens per watt (lm/W). The monolithic white laser mentioned in the question has a potential efficiency of 400 lm/W, which is a significant improvement. However, it's important to note that the actual efficiency of the light source in a vertical farm setup will depend on factors such as light distribution, reflection, and absorption by the plants.

To calculate the lumens per watt efficiency necessary for vertical farming to compete with horizontal agriculture, we can compare the energy input required for both systems to produce the same crop yield. Let's assume that the energy input for horizontal agriculture is primarily sunlight, and the energy input for vertical farming is electricity used for artificial lighting.

For horizontal agriculture, the energy input can be calculated as follows:

Energy input (sunlight) = Crop yield (kg) * Energy conversion efficiency (sunlight to biomass)

For vertical farming, the energy input can be calculated as follows:

Energy input (electricity) = Crop yield (kg) * Energy conversion efficiency (electricity to biomass) * Light source efficiency (lm/W)

To make vertical farming competitive with horizontal agriculture, the energy input for both systems should be roughly equal:

Energy input (sunlight) = Energy input (electricity)

Crop yield (kg) * Energy conversion efficiency (sunlight to biomass) = Crop yield (kg) * Energy conversion efficiency (electricity to biomass) * Light source efficiency (lm/W)

Assuming the energy conversion efficiency of sunlight to biomass and electricity to biomass are equal, we can simplify the equation:

Light source efficiency (lm/W) = Energy conversion efficiency (sunlight to biomass) / Energy conversion efficiency (electricity to biomass)

Since the energy conversion efficiencies are assumed to be equal, the light source efficiency (lm/W) should be at least as high as the energy conversion efficiency of sunlight to biomass for vertical farming to compete with horizontal agriculture.

In practice, the actual lumens per watt efficiency necessary for vertical farming to compete with horizontal agriculture will depend on various factors, such as crop type, growing conditions, and energy costs. It's also important to consider other benefits of vertical farming, such as reduced land and water usage, controlled environment, and year-round production, which may offset some of the energy efficiency disadvantages.

63837.question: Do switchable sockets left "on" use electricity if there's nothing plugged in?
63837.context:
My flat is fitted with switchable sockets as per below:

Please settle an argument a friend and I are having: if a socket is switched "on", is it wasting electricity if nothing is actually plugged into it? If so, any idea how much?
Thank you!
63837.gt:
No. With nothing plugged in there is no circuit, so no current can flow. 
An exception to this is if the socket or the switch has an indicator light - usually a neon one - that is illuminated when the switch is on. In that case the light will use a (very small) amount of power.
model_pred: no, switchable sockets do not use electricity if nothing is plugged into them

When a switchable socket is turned "on" without having a plug connected to it, it does not actively use electricity. Sockets are designed to provide a connection point for appliances, but when no device is plugged in, the socket does not consume electricity. The amount of electricity wasted depends on the type of socket and the power supplied by the electrical system. In the case of a typical UK 13A socket, an appliance plugged into it draws around 1A when turned on, and the socket will supply up to 12A when used. So, if a socket is switched "on" without a plug connected to it, it is not wasting electricity; the electricity is being saved for when an appliance needs to be used.

Yes, if a switchable socket is left "on," it will still consume electricity, even if nothing is plugged into it. The socket itself is a circuit breaker and will remain active, even if it does not provide a connection. This can lead to a slight increase in your electricity bill, but it is unlikely to have a significant impact on your overall energy consumption. The exact amount of electricity consumption depends on the type of socket and how often it is switched on or off.

In general, no. If there is nothing plugged in to the socket, the circuit is incomplete and so no electricity will be flowing, even if the switch is "on". 

However, there could be a small amount of electricity being used if the socket has a light or other indicator that shows when it is switched on. The amount of electricity used by this light would be minimal, likely less than a watt.

It's also possible that if the socket is old or damaged, there could be some leakage of electricity even when nothing is plugged in, but this would be uncommon and again, the amount of electricity wasted would likely be minimal.

Switchable sockets that are left "on" without anything plugged into them do not use any significant amount of electricity. The socket itself does not consume power when it's switched on; it only provides a path for electricity to flow when a device is connected to it. Therefore, if nothing is plugged into the socket, there is no flow of electricity, and no power is being consumed.

However, it's important to note that some devices, when plugged in and switched off, can still consume a small amount of standby power, also known as "vampire power" or "phantom load." To avoid this, you can unplug the device or turn off the switchable socket when not in use. But in the case of an empty socket that's switched on, there is no significant power consumption.

63860.question: Should I turn vermicompost?
63860.context:
After adding plant matter to vermicompost, it kinda just sits there for a while, attracting fruit flies and growing mould.
Would it be better to try to turn the compost so that the new matter is at the bottom, covered from mould and fruit flies? How to do it without hurting the worms?
I am using Urbalive vermicomposter which looks like this:

It has two layers, but the second one is empty so far. Maybe I should start using both?
63860.gt:
Summarising from the instructions that came with mine (a similar shape) you should add material in layers, first filling the bottom layer and only then moving on to the top.  It's quite easy to add too much, especially at first, and it may be getting too wet.  If used mainly for kitchen scraps it may also end up with too much nitrogen-rich material.  Adding a bit of newspaper can help - maybe a layer on top while things settle down, as it sounds like it's quite new.
At first they can be a little slow, and need a bit of compost or similar organic material to help them get started - with mine this was described as being something for the worms to live in until they process the vegetable matter you add.  Mine lives outside; I'm sceptical of the advice saying you can use them properly indoors except in a well-ventilated place.
model_pred: no, you don't need to turn your vermicompost

Yes, it is a good idea to regularly turn the vermicompost to ensure even decomposition of the organic material and to prevent the accumulation of undesirable substances, such as mold and fruit fly infestations. To turn the compost without harming the worms, you can carefully remove the existing contents, including the worms, to the secondary container or a separate bin. Be cautious when handling the worms to avoid causing them any stress or injury. Once you have removed the contents from the primary container, you can replace it with fresh, new material to be composted. Make sure to return the worms to the secondary container or a new bin after turning the compost. This will ensure their safety and maintain the health of the vermicomposting process while keeping the compost free from mold and fruit flies.

It's a good idea to turn the vermicompost every few weeks to ensure even distribution of oxygen, moisture, and heat in the bin. It can also promote aerobic decomposition of the compost, which leads to faster decomposition and better quality compost.

When turning the compost, it's essential not to hurt the worms by applying excessive force or causing sharp turns. The easiest way to gently turn the compost is to lift the top layer with one hand and gently slide the bottom layer over the top, without disturbing the worms.

To ensure even distribution of the worms, you can add new plant matter to both layers of the vermicomposter. If the second layer of your vermicomposter is empty, you could use it to store finished compost or as a temporary storage area while waiting for new material to be added.

In summary, turning the vermicompost periodically and being gentle when turning the compost are essential to maintaining a healthy worm population and achieving optimal compost quality.

There is a delicate balance between retaining moisture in vermicompost and preventing it from becoming anaerobic and attracting flies. Turning the compost mitigates the risk of anaerobic conditions, but in doing so, the worms may be disturbed.

In your case, I would suggest harvesting the vermicompost from the bottom tray and using it in your garden or potting mix. This will push the majority of the worms to the top tray, where you can safely turn the compost without disturbing them too much.

As for the fruit flies, if they are already present, add a layer of shredded newspaper or cardboard on top of the compost. This will help control the fly population and also provide some good carbon-rich material for the worms to eat. Additionally, make sure to bury any kitchen scraps in the compost, as leaving them on top can also attract flies.

Using both trays is a great idea. By having two trays, you can alternate between them, giving the worms enough time to break down the food scraps in one tray while you add fresh material to the other.

Overall, I would say that turning your vermicompost is not necessary, but it may help prevent anaerobic conditions and fruit fly infestations. Just make sure to do it carefully and slowly to avoid harming the worms.

Turning vermicompost can be beneficial in some cases, as it helps to aerate the material and promote decomposition. However, it's essential to be gentle when turning the compost to avoid harming the worms. In your case, with the Urbalive vermicomposter, turning the compost might not be necessary, as the system is designed to allow the worms to move between the layers and process the organic matter efficiently.

To address the issue of fruit flies and mold, you can try the following steps:

1. Bury the food scraps: When adding new plant matter, bury it under the existing compost or bedding material. This will help to reduce the exposure of the food scraps to fruit flies and mold.

2. Maintain a balanced moisture level: Vermicompost should be moist but not overly wet. Excess moisture can lead to mold growth and create an unhealthy environment for the worms. If the compost is too wet, add more dry bedding material like shredded newspaper or cardboard to help absorb the excess moisture.

3. Use a fruit fly trap: Place a small container with apple cider vinegar and a drop of dish soap near the vermicomposter to attract and trap fruit flies.

4. Monitor the temperature: Worms thrive in temperatures between 55-77°F (13-25°C). If the temperature is too high, it can lead to mold growth and other issues. Ensure that your vermicomposter is placed in a location with a suitable temperature range.

As for using both layers of your Urbalive vermicomposter, you can start adding food scraps and bedding material to the second layer once the first layer is mostly processed by the worms. The worms will naturally migrate to the second layer in search of food, leaving behind their nutrient-rich castings in the first layer. This will make it easier for you to harvest the finished compost without disturbing the worms too much.

Remember to be patient, as it may take some time for the worms to process the organic matter and for the vermicompost to mature. With proper care and maintenance, your Urbalive vermicomposter should provide you with a continuous supply of nutrient-rich compost for your plants.

It is better to provide Tilapia with a diet that is specifically formulated for their nutritional needs, such as fish feed or pellets, along with an appropriate balance of other food sources like insects and plants for a diverse and healthy diet.

They can provide a valuable source of nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium, which are crucial for the growth and health of the plants in the system. Additionally, millipedes can break down organic matter, making it easier for plants to absorb nutrients.

However, you should be cautious when feeding millipedes to your fish. The hard shell can damage their intestine, leading to intestinal blockages or other health issues. Also, make sure to feed millipedes in moderation and only after ensuring that your fish have sufficient plant-based food sources. Overfeeding millipedes could lead to excessive nutrient levels in the system and harm the plants and fish.

Additionally, some species of millipedes can produce toxins that may be harmful to fish. While it is true that tilapia are omnivorous and can eat a wide variety of food sources, including insects, feeding them millipedes may not be the best option. There are a few reasons for this:

1. Chitin: Millipedes have a hard exoskeleton made of chitin, which can be difficult for tilapia to digest. This could potentially cause digestive issues or blockages in their intestines.

2. Toxins: Some millipedes produce toxic or irritating chemicals as a defense mechanism. Feeding these millipedes to your tilapia could potentially harm or even kill the fish.

3. Nutritional balance: While insects can be a good source of protein for fish, it's important to provide a balanced diet that includes other nutrients such as vitamins, minerals, and carbohydrates. Relying solely on millipedes as a food source may not provide the necessary balance for optimal fish health and growth.

4. Disease transmission: Introducing wild insects into your aquaponics system could potentially introduce pathogens or parasites that could harm your fish or plants.

Instead of using millipedes as a food source, it would be better to provide a balanced diet for your tilapia using commercially available fish feed or other suitable alternatives such as duckweed, algae, or other insects like black soldier fly larvae, which are more easily digestible and have a better nutritional profile.

So, the difference between these two colors would be in the Green channel, which is 50% - 40% = 10% of Green

1. Convert the hex colors to RGB values: #44aaee = R, #0088ee = G

3. Square root of the difference: sqrt( (R - G)^2 + (G - B)^2 + (B - R)^2 )
4. Convert the RGB difference to a hex color: round(sqrt( (R - G)^2 + (G - B)^2 + (B - R)^2 ) * 255, 2)

21305.question: Render SVG to 16bit/channel raster
21305.context:
I have an SVG with gradients. Postprocessing it with GIMP 2.8 produced banding due to its rasterization which is only 8bit/channel. I downloaded Gimp 2.10, then set channel precision 16bit, imported directly from Inkscape as SVG, yet the banding was there as before. Then I installed Inkscape 1.0.1, exported as 16bit PNG, imported to Gimp 2.10. Gimp shows 16bit/channel, but the banding is still there.
Is there any accessible conversion tool which will create a true 16bit/channel raster image from SVG, including gradients? Preferably for Ubuntu.
EDIT: I attach an example. Instead of Color Curves, I use now another color filter, because it is easier to tell how it was parameterized. The effect is similar, though.
Firstly, I use Inkscape 1.0.1 to export https://svgshare.com/s/TQe as an RGB16 PNG to Gimp 2.10. Then I use the filter Brightness/contrast, where I change the contrast to 0.4. The effect:

Some of the subsequent values of the red component, tested with the color picker: 33.9, 38.9, 41.3, scale 0 ... 100. As seen, the accuracy is not even 8 bit.
21305.gt:
Actually cairo is not rendering the gradients at 16-bit bit per channel depth. There is a open issue about this. See:

RGBA16 png export: no difference between RGB-8 and RGB-16

Now as this is still just speculation i had a look in cairo source. Yes this is the case. Also verified results in mathematica and photoshop.
So all you get is a 8 bit image in a 16 bit image container. No solution for inkscape, no solution for adobe illstrator, last time i checked no solution for corel, try affinity designer. It is unlikely that any of the common renderers do  because svg is a screen renderer by design. Write your own renderer or use a 3D app to render the svg. Since color splines are rather common in 3D apps you might use blender or maya for rendering this. Both apps are also passable if you have shapes but not all really esoteric SVG features.

In Photoshop, you can replace a single color using the "Replace Color" tool. To do this, follow these steps:

1. Open the image in Adobe Photoshop.
2. Select the color you want to replace (e.g. red) by clicking on the color box next to the "Replace Color" tool. This will create a color sample.
3. Adjust the brush size and hardness as desired to control the replacement accuracy.
4. Use the brush with the replaced color to paint over the area where you want to change the color.
5. Right-click the brush and select "Define Custom Color" to give the new color a name. 

Alternatively, you can use the "Hue/Saturation" adjustment layer to replace a specific color in the image. To do this, follow these steps:

1. Select the layer you want to adjust.
2. Go to "Filters" and then "Adjustments" and select "Hue/Saturation."
3. In the "Hue/Saturation" dialog box, move the sliders for "Hue" and "Saturation" to the desired values, keeping in mind that a positive value for "Hue" will increase the color's intensity, while a negative value will decrease it.
4. Check the "Colorize" box if you want to replace the color across the entire image or "Bypass" if you want to apply another adjustment layer on top.
5. Click "OK" and then "Apply" to replace the color in the image.

These methods should allow you to replace a single color effectively in Photoshop without having to use additional, more complicated layers or tools.

To replace a single color in Photoshop quickly, follow these steps:

1. Open the image you wish to edit in Photoshop.
2. Click and drag a selection rectangle to the desired area where the color needs to be changed.
3. In the Layers panel, right-click on the selection and select "Create Clipping Mask".
4. In the Layers panel, right-click on the newly created clipping mask and select "Make Selection."

7. Click on the color you want to replace and select "OK" to apply the replacement.
8. To save your changes, click the "Save" button located at the top-left corner of the window.

In Photoshop, you can replace a single color using the "Select > Color Range" tool and then filling the selection with the desired color. Here's a step-by-step guide on how to do this:

1. Open your image in Photoshop.
2. Go to "Select" in the top menu and choose "Color Range."
3. In the "Color Range" window, click on the "Sampled Colors" option if it's not already selected.
4. Use the eyedropper tool to click on the color you want to replace in your image. You can adjust the "Fuzziness" slider to control the range of color selection. For pixel art, you might want to set the fuzziness to a low value to select only the exact color you want to replace.
5. Click "OK" to confirm your selection. You'll see that the color you want to replace is now selected in your image.
6. Choose the "Paint Bucket Tool" from the toolbar or press "G" on your keyboard.
7. In the "Options" bar at the top, make sure "Foreground" is selected as the fill source.
8. Set your foreground color to the new color you want to replace the original color with. You can do this by clicking on the foreground color swatch at the bottom of the toolbar and selecting the desired color in the color picker.
9. Click inside the selected area in your image to fill it with the new color.
10. Press "Ctrl + D" (Windows) or "Cmd + D" (Mac) to deselect the selection.

Now you have successfully replaced the single color in your image. You can repeat these steps for any other colors you want to replace.

20415.question: Does a vector graphics format capable of the following exist?
20415.context:
Take the following image, for example:

I'd like to represent the lineart not as a black-filled, closed object, but as a network of Bézier curves connected at odd places, with various and varying stroke widths between them.  When I manipulate a curve that has other curves connected to it on its arc (not just at its endpoints), the other curves should adjust to stay connected to the one I'm manipulating.
Additionally, I'd like to represent the coloring as a set of "fill points" that, when rendering the image, propagate their color out in a wavefront until they encounter a Bézier curve - just like a flood fill tool in raster programs, just not prerendered.
Is there a vector graphics format (and editor) with which this can be done?  I've only had casual access to Inkscape/SVG, but the graphics primitives it offers are indeed too primitive.
20415.gt:
I do not believe what you are after, for the most part, exists. That's simply not how vector graphics, or Bezier curves, work within existing tools in my experience.
While you can certainly introduce some line vocabulary into a Bezier curve, Bezier curves generally have a start and stop point and don't connect "at odd places". 
The "fill points" idea is an interesting one. There are tools which will fill similar to flood fill tools in raster applications - Adobe Illustrator Live Paint Bucket Tool is one such tool. But fills aren't represented as a collection of "points until they collide with a curve". Objects have edges and those edges are treated as the boundary for the fill.

It supports Bézier curves, variable line widths, and the use of "fill patterns" which can be defined in a way that simulates the wavefront fill you describe. 

Another option could be the OpenFX format, which supports complex Bézier curves, varying line widths, and the use of "gradients" that can be configured to create a wavefront-like fill.

Both CGM and OpenFX can be edited in various graphics software, including Adobe Illustrator and CorelDRAW.

For the "fill points" concept, there isn't a direct equivalent in existing vector graphics formats. 64312.question: US Passport Renewal, Is Stapling Required?
64312.context:
My US passport has expired. I have filled out the forms and have booked a pickup/delivery with DX Services for Tuesday.
I have the required photo, and I am looking at this part of the application...

It looks like four (4) staples are required. I haven't used a stapler in years, and I don't even know if there's one in my office. Do I actually have to go find a stapler and staple it 4 times? 
I don't want to damage the photo and have my application refused on the basis of a damaged photo.
Question: do I actually have to staple my photo in the designated places? Or am I reading this wrong and there's a different way to submit one's photo?
Secondarily: if the answer above is 'yes', do I have to use some kind of American standard staple? Or will a UK standard staple be OK?  The guidance, for example, says that A4 paper is OK (and I am thankful for that). They are so picky and persnickety about everything in a way that questions such as these are relevant.
64312.gt:
The instructions for DS-82 (Renewal of US passport for eligible individuals) clearly state:

USE CAUTION WHEN STAPLING YOUR PHOTO: Use 4 staples vertically in the corners as close to the outer edge as possible. Do not bend photo.

I do not see the same statement on DS-11 (application for a new passport) but the statement is on DS-5504 (Corrections, name change within year of issuance, or passport book or card was limited to less than 2 years for a reason other than multiple losses or seriously damaged/mutilated).
There is no statement about what type of staple is acceptable.

Always ensure that the staples are placed in the correct positions and do not damage the photograph, as this might affect the overall appearance and validity of your application.

Yes, you will have to staple your photo in the designated places. There is a specific way to attach the photo according to the US passport renewal application guidelines. You need to staple the photo in four (4) places:

1. On the upper-right corner of the photo, directly above your head.
2. On the upper-left corner of the photo, directly below your head.
3. On the bottom-right corner of the photo, directly below your right ear.
4. On the bottom-left corner of the photo, directly below your left ear.

You will need to use an American-standard staple for this purpose. You can either find a stapler in your office or purchase one online. It is crucial to ensure that the staple is securely attached and does not damage the photo, otherwise your passport application may be rejected or delayed.
Engineering & Technology

Yes, you are required to staple your photo to the application form in the designated places. The reason for this is that it helps the passport agency to ensure that your photo remains attached to your application form.

As far as the type of staple is concerned, it is recommended that you use a standard size staple. However, if you are unable to find a standard size staple, you can use any size staple that is readily available in your area. Just make sure that the staple is not too large or too small, as this could damage your photo or cause it to become detached from your application form.

Based on the information provided, it seems that you are renewing your US passport from the UK. According to the U.S. Department of State, you should follow these guidelines when submitting your passport photo:

1. The photo should be 2 x 2 inches (51 x 51 mm) in size.
2. The photo should be in color and taken within the last six months.
3. The photo should have a white or off-white background.
4. You should have a neutral facial expression and both eyes open.

Regarding the stapling of the photo, the U.S. Department of State does not explicitly mention that you must staple the photo to the application. Tom Sawyer Island (also other things you've circled like the Haunted Mansion and the Pirates of the Carribean ride) is an attraction inside of Disneyland Park. 64697.question: Do I need to show return tickets at the airport in the US with ESTA as a German?
64697.context:
I plan to fly with German citizenship from Spain to the US - San Francisco. I got already an ESTA 
I read in every source that you need an backflight for getting a ESTA. I filled out the form for the ESTA for some while ago without any return tickets. I am not sure if they wrote something like "at the airport you need return tickets to show". Do I need return tickets or is it just optional?
64697.gt:
Yes, to enter the United States using the Visa Waiver Program you must have an onward ticket out of the US (technically out of North America).
Before you fly, it will be checked by airline check-in that you have a valid ESTA authorization and an onward ticket.  If they can't verify automatically they will ask for proof of your onward flight.  If you don't have an ESTA and onward ticket you won't be allowed to board the flight.
After your flight, when you are interviewed at the US Immigration checkpoint upon your arrival, you might be asked to show proof of this onward ticket. You will also be asked how long you are staying (and if you have the onward ticket you know exactly how long that is). If you cannot satisfy these questions you will likely be denied entry.
Please note that these tickets don't necessarily need to be return/round-trip tickets - they can be onward tickets to another country altogether.  They just need to satisfy the requirement to leave North America within the allowed timeframe.
model_pred: yes you need to show return tickets at the airport in the us with ESTA as a german

Based on the image, the form you provided displays the message "Application approved!" indicating that your ESTA application has been approved. As a German citizen, you are required to present your passport and a valid return ticket when entering the United States, regardless of your citizenship. The return ticket is essential as it shows your planned departure date from the United States and demonstrates that you have a valid reason for traveling to the country, such as a business trip, vacation, or any other purpose. Therefore, in this case, presenting your approved ESTA along with your passport and a valid return ticket will be sufficient when entering the United States. However, it is always advisable to comply with the requirements to avoid any issues during the immigration process.

Yes, it is important to show return tickets when you arrive at the airport in the US with ESTA as a German citizen. The Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) is an automated system run by the US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) that allows certain citizens from certain countries to travel to the US for tourism or business purposes for up to 90 days without a visa. However, the ESTA is not a visa and it does not authorize you to work or study in the US, nor does it guarantee entry into the US.

When you arrive at the airport in the US with an ESTA, you will need to provide the CBP officer with your valid passport, ESTA approval notice, any visas that are required for your trip, and return tickets showing that you have arranged to leave the US within the 90 days. If you do not have return tickets, you may be denied entry into the US until you provide proof of your plans to leave the country.

Therefore, it is essential to show your return tickets when you arrive at the airport to ensure that you comply with immigration requirements and are able to enter the US. If you have already applied for the ESTA and have been approved, you can proceed to the airport with confidence that you will be able to enter the US with your German citizenship and ESTA.

The ESTA is an Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) that allows travelers to enter the U.S. without a visa or other form of travel authorization. You can apply for an ESTA at https://www.travel.state.gov/esta

According to the official website of the Department of Homeland Security, "You are encouraged to apply for a visa if you are not sure if you are eligible for the Visa Waiver Program or if you wish to stay in the United States for more than 90 days". 

In addition, the website also states that "Airlines and many cruise lines are required to submit passenger information to US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) before the passenger boards the aircraft or ship. This information includes passport details, as well as information on the passenger's destination and other details about the trip." 

Therefore, it seems like you will need to have return tickets to prove that you will be leaving the United States within the 90-day period. If you do not have return tickets, you may be denied entry into the United States. We recommend contacting the airline or CBP for more information.

As a German citizen traveling to the United States under the Visa Waiver Program (VWP) with an approved ESTA, you are generally required to have a round-trip ticket or an onward ticket to another country. This is to demonstrate that you have the intention to leave the United States within the 90-day period allowed under the VWP.

While it is not always strictly enforced, having a return or onward ticket can help avoid potential issues at the airport, such as being questioned by immigration officers or even being denied entry. It is recommended that you have a return or onward ticket to ensure a smooth travel experience.

Keep in mind that airline policies may also require you to have a return or onward ticket before allowing you to board the flight to the United States. It's a good idea to check with your airline to confirm their specific requirements.

In summary, while it might not be explicitly stated that you need to show return tickets at the airport, having them is strongly recommended to avoid any potential issues during your travel to the United States.

64729.gt:
The prices you're seeing are very high due to a combination of factors:

Being a holiday both locally and around the world, plus the best season in terms of weather for much of the country, New Year's is absolute peak season across Thailand and Samui is a very popular tourist destination.
Samui is a small airport and Bangkok Airways has an effective monopoly on flights, so prices are always higher than most Thai domestic routes.
The specific 18,000-baht itinerary you're seeing on Jan 2nd is not a direct flight, but a connection via Chiang Mai in the far north of the country, so you're paying for two separate long flights instead of a quick hop.

If you're not happy with what Bangkok Airways is charging, your alternative is to cross over to the mainland by ferry (~90 min) and either continue to Bangkok by cheap domestic flight from any of Surat Thani, Nakhon Si Thammarat or Chumphon, or take a cheap bus across to Phuket.  Wikivoyage has the full scoop.

64467.question: Denied check-in with a paid reservation, what can we do?
64467.context:
We made this reservation at booking dot com, with all money paid.
At that day, we arrived at 8pm at the property, the property owner insisted that we arrived late and refused to check us in. According to the property’s policy, the standard check-in time is 2–7pm, while check-in between 7–9pm will be subject to a surcharge. We were fully aware of this policy so when booking this accommodation we made a special request of arrival between 7–8pm (the booking was confirmed with this written clearly on the confirmation, and our money taken).
However, for some strange reason the property owner tried to "get in touch with us" only TWO DAYS before the check in time to confirm our arrival time (!?). We were not aware of this because at that time we were on our trip already and didn't have good access to emails and phone calls to our domestic number. Now, when we arrived at the property, at 8 pm, the person we got to speak to insisted we were late and refused to check us in even if we pay the surcharge stipulated in their policy (he claimed that the property owner had left but when we called the property owner's phone number, he's mobile phone rang!). 
After arguing with the person with no success, we had no other choice but looking for other place to stay. It was steamingly hot and full of mosquitoes, but we had to traverse the whole town even though we were all exhausted after a day's trip. In the end, we only managed to find an empty room in a restaurant to stay, thanks for the help offered by a kind stranger.
We are now trying to get in touch with Booking dot com, hoping to at least get our money back, but Booking dot com insists they are a third-party and cannot do anything about this. They also argue that the property owner cannot get in touch with us to confirm our arrival time, so it's on us for not being there before 7pm! This sounds ridiculous to us because we had requested arrival between 7-8pm (which according to their policy will be subject to a surcharge but not denial of entry!), and the booking was finalized with this request written on the confirmation. If the owner did not accept this on that particular day, how come they didn't get in touch with us immediately, but did that only two days before the check-in time!
Now we really don't know what to do to protect our rights. Our money was taken, and we had a horrible night. We cannot even write a review of this property to reveal what happened because we were marked as "no show"!
64467.gt:
It seems that there is not much that you can do.
When making the reservation, you agreed to the conditions of the booking, which specify that late checkin is subject to specific approval of the hotel, which apparently did not happen as they could not get in touch with you.
What you can do is:

Ask the hotel directly for a refund, which they might do as a goodwill gesture.
If you booked a stay for more than one night, check in on the second day.
You can write a review on other websites, such as Google Maps or Yelp.

For future bookings, there are a couple of things you can do to avoid such a situation:

Book directly on the hotel website, a special request there is much more likely to be seen and approved early.
Make sure to specify a contact number under which you can be reached during your travels.
model_pred: Denied check-in with a paid reservation, what can we do?

When dealing with such issues, it is essential to first attempt resolving the matter directly with the property owner or manager. Explain the situation, provide evidence of your payment and confirmation, and politely request that they honor the agreed-upon check-in time and policy. If this approach does not yield satisfactory results, you may consider reaching out to Booking.com, as they act as a third-party in these situations. Explain the issue to them, and they may assist in mediating the situation, offering support or even providing a refund if necessary. If none of these approaches work, you may want to consider seeking legal advice or engaging in a dispute resolution process to protect your rights as a consumer.

Remember to remain calm and polite in your communications, as this can help facilitate a resolution. Good luck, and I hope you're able to resolve this issue and receive the compensation you deserve.

64320.question: What are the material differences, UK visitor visa vs USA visitor visa
64320.context:
It is on stackexchange that I read for the first time that there is a material difference between UK and USA visas. That difference being that while the US visa essentially only gives you permission to travel to the US border at which point you will be evaluated for entry into the USA, the UK visa aka entry clearance is one which already essentially gives you permission to enter the UK and that your interaction with immigration at the airport is mainly a formality.
Coming from a person who was a non visa national who previously had to apply for and was approved many UK and UK visas and visited both countries quite a bit, I find no material difference between the two as suggested. The questions I get at the UK airport from immigration officials is no different in depth from what I got at the US airport. I know anecdotally it is the same with friends of mine and virtually everyone I know personally who has visited both countries. Actually most of those people have asserted that UK airport immigration are tougher in their questioning. 
Does anyone have access to data showing the percentage of people(preferably with visas) denied entry at USA borders vs those denied at UK borders to determine if that difference is statistically significant? Information like below would be somewhat helpful extrapolating the data required
My null hypothesis is that there is no significant difference in the proportion of people with visas denied entry to both countries and thus no material difference in the UK and USA visitor visa.
H0: p1 = p2
where
p1 = the proportion of denied entry arrivals for the USA, and
p2 = the proportion of denied entry arrivals for the UK.
This report implies I may be right and that for nationals of some countries, there is no difference.
The results of such a hypothesis test will be another data point in informing my decision whether to go for a UK entry clearance before my next visit.
Disclaimer: I am from a sub-Saharan developing country (as are most of the people I reference) which like most sub Saharan countries has a high incidence of visitors to developed countries not being true visitors, but people looking to emigrate.
64320.gt:
To apply some back-of-the-envelope math:
In 2015, there were 15.3 million non-EEA national arrivals to the UK (9.4 million as visitors). That same year, 17,279 people were "refused entry at port and subsequently departed". There isn't perfect overlap (surely some of those refused entry were EEA nationals), but that gives a rough refusal rate of 0.1%. 
This, of course combines both visa nationals and non-visa nationals, and detailed breakdowns between the two categories are not available without making a public records request, to the best of my knowledge. However, that report does say that 10% (1,813 people) of those refused at port are US citizens and 5% are Brazilian citizens, both countries that do not require visas for visits to the UK. By way of comparison, 29% of non-EEA visitors to the UK are Americans. 
In contrast, the total refusal rate at ports of entry for all entries to the United States is roughly 0.03%. 
In short, very few people, from either country, are refused. This applies to both visa-holders and visa-exempt nationals. 
If you need further statistics from the UK authorities, I invite you to make a request under Freedom of Information law at whatdotheyknow.com.

Beyond that, I wouldn't view this situation as a material difference between US and UK visas, so much as a difference in how these countries view the role of their border agencies. 
US Customs and Border Protection's position is clear: "Issuance of a visa does not guarantee entry to the United States. A visa simply indicates that a U.S. consular officer at an American embassy or consulate has reviewed the application and that officer has determined that the individual is eligible to enter the country for a specific purpose. The CBP Officer at the port-of-entry will conduct an inspection to determine if the individual is eligible for admission under U.S. immigration law." Indeed, US law includes a presumption of immigrant intent, and a visitor must be prepared to rebut that presumption and convince the officer that he or she plans to return home.
In the UK, with thanks Crazydre and phoog from the comments of a now-deleted answer, entry clearance still has the same black-letter policy: "In all cases, the authority to admit someone to the UK ultimately rests with the Immigration Officer (IO) at the port of entry." But the Immigration Rules more affirmatively state that the holder of a valid entry clearance may only be refused under an enumerated set of circumstances (e.g. fraud, change of circumstances, certain reasons such as criminal history that would ordinarily be grounds to deny entry clearance in the first place). One of these circumstances is where the "officer deems the exclusion of the person from the United Kingdom to be conducive to the public good," which is a fairly broad catch-all, but the intent is clearly that the holders of entry clearance are to be given leave unless there is a serious reason not to do so.
In other words, US policy gives more discretion to the officials at the port of entry to determine whether to admit a visa-holder, while the UK rules state that someone with entry clearance is to be given leave to enter unless specified circumstances exist.
Now, in your case, you've had an adverse immigration history with the UK authorities, you received a recommendation to seek entry clearance before traveling, chose not to follow this advice, and were recently detained at Heathrow for six hours before finally being admitted. And now you're contemplating whether to return without entry clearance? While you can surely ask a new question of the form "Should I get entry clearance before going back to the UK," I think everything about this situation makes the answer an enthusiastic YES. While entry clearance is not a guarantee of a fast and smooth border crossing, it provides far more of an assurance of success.

This is due to the fact that the US has more stringent requirements for approving a visa, including higher income and asset requirements, and more restrictive policies that can result in a higher rate of denial.

As such, based on the available data, there is some evidence that the UK has a higher proportion of denied entry arrivals than the US. However, this difference is not statistically significant as the p-value for the difference in proportions is 0.06.

It is important to note that while there may be anecdotal evidence suggesting similarities in the experiences of travelers entering the UK and the USA, the actual visa processes and regulations for each country are distinct. The UK visitor visa, also known as entry clearance, is granted by the UK government and allows the holder to enter the UK for a specific purpose and duration. The USA visitor visa, on the other hand, is granted by the US government and allows the holder to travel to the US border, where they will be evaluated for entry into the country.

63913.question: Is it worth visiting the Nazca Lines from the ground if seeing them from a plane is not an option?
63913.context:
The Nazca lines are some very famous geoglyphs in Peru. For example you can see a dog in this picture:

Picture from Wikipedia
From a plane or a satelitte or something similar, this looks really impressive. But how is it if I want to visit it on the ground. Is it worth a visit? Can I see anything?
63913.gt:
I went last year.  My friend and I caught the bus from Arequipa through to Nazca overnight, arriving early morning (around 7).  The town itself is fairly non-descript, just full of hagglers telling you they've run out of Avgas and the like to try and charge you to stay a day.  
From the ground you can't really get to the glyphs, as they're in the desert.  The closest you can get is along the desert highway, where a viewing tower has been built.  But it's really not very high - we drove past it in the bus as we left town.
However, anyone who is going there does the flight, which was trivial to organise.  We hopped off the bus, got a taxi to the airport, questioned all operators for prices etc (you can talk some of them down), and were on a flight at 10am for 30 min.  You get exactly the views you'd expect, and it was fantastic - the pilots are very good at showing both sides of the plane the same thing with banks and turns over the glyphs.  
As you come back to the airport you get a good view of the town, and there's really not much else to do there.  I wouldn't have minded seeing the old aqueducts, but it'd have required a nights stay as well, so we headed on to Lima instead.
By 11am we were back at the bus terminal to buy our tickets for the bus out of town an hour later.

However, it is important to note that the experience will not be the same as seeing them from above, as the lines are best appreciated from an aerial perspective. Additionally, not all of the Nazca Lines can be seen from the ground, and some may be difficult to make out due to their size and the angle of viewing. All in all, though, it is still a unique and worthwhile experience to see these ancient and mysterious lines up close.

While the Nazca Lines are best appreciated from the air, it is still possible to visit and enjoy them from the ground. Although you won't be able to see the full extent of the geoglyphs, there are a few options for ground-level viewing that can still make your visit worthwhile.

1. Observation towers: There are two observation towers located along the Pan-American Highway that allow you to see some of the Nazca Lines from an elevated perspective. From these towers, you can see the Tree, Hands, and Lizard geoglyphs. While the view is not as impressive as from a plane, it still provides a sense of the scale and intricacy of the designs.

2. The Nazca Lines visitor center: The visitor center, located near the observation towers, offers information about the history, creation, and significance of the Nazca Lines. There are also some artifacts and exhibits on display, which can help you gain a deeper understanding of the Nazca culture.

3. Guided tours: Some tour operators offer guided tours of the Nazca Lines from the ground. These tours typically include a visit to the observation towers, the visitor center, and sometimes a walk along the edges of some of the geoglyphs. A knowledgeable guide can provide valuable insights and context about the Nazca Lines and their creators.

4. Cantalloc Aqueducts: While not directly related to the Nazca Lines, the Cantalloc Aqueducts are another fascinating site in the Nazca area. These ancient underground water channels were built by the Nazca people and are still functional today. Visiting the aqueducts can provide additional context about the engineering and agricultural prowess of the Nazca civilization.

In conclusion, while visiting the Nazca Lines from the ground may not provide the same awe-inspiring views as from the air, it can still be a worthwhile experience. The observation towers, visitor center, guided tours, and nearby sites like the Cantalloc Aqueducts can help you appreciate the history, culture, and ingenuity of the Nazca people.

49139.question: What could cause severe under-exposure when using a Canon 5D Mark III with Speedlite 600EX-RT with Evaluative E-TTL2 metering?
49139.context:
I recently purchased a Speedlite 600EX-RT for use with my 5D Mark III.  I'm shooting with a 17-40 f4/L lens.  Particularly when using the flash in the standard forward position, I get extremely severe underexposure when shooting in P mode with the flash in either High Speed Sync or First Curtain release with E-TTL2 on in evaluative mode.  
There are perhaps one or two fringe areas of the image that are exposed (less than 3% of the total image) and none of them are at all close to the chosen focal point.  Many images haven't even had any portion of the image properly exposed.  I'm using Center Weighted Average Metering for my metering setting.  
Any idea what could be causing the issue?  Does the metering setting for the camera and the flash have to match for proper results?  Is there simply an issue with the communication between the flash and camera body?  I'm really not sure what is going on and why I'm getting such poor results with the flash.  I notice it also seem to do much better when using the flash in a bump flash configuration.
Edit: As mentioned below, I do realize there is a flash exposure compensation adjustment in the flash that I can make to boost the exposure, but I'm trying to figure out why it is misbehaving rather than simply trying to work around the problem.  I'm specifically looking for any additional insight in to what could be making it underexpose by multiple stops.

RAW File (CR2) as Shot
49139.gt:
I have had identical issues with the 580 ex II.
Change the flash setting in the cameras menu to 'average' not evaluative it fixes it. I don't use evaluative for the camera settings without the flash either the same issue happens and photos under exposed. I think Canon need to revisit their 'evaluative' system.
Hope this helps....

There are a number of potential factors that can cause under-exposure when using a flash in E-TTL mode. Below are some possible explanations and solutions:

1. Flash Exposure Compensation: If the flash exposure compensation is set too low, the flash will not emit enough light to properly expose the subject. Make sure the flash exposure compensation is set to 0 or higher.

2. Flash power: A flash that is under-powered will not be able to emit enough light to properly expose the subject. Try increasing the flash power, if possible.

3. Distance to subject: If the subject is too far away from the flash, the flash may not be able to emit enough light to properly expose the subject. Try moving closer to the subject or use a flash with a longer reach.

4. Camera settings: If the camera settings are not configured properly, the flash may not be able to properly expose the subject. Make sure the camera ISO and aperture are set to appropriate levels and that the shutter speed is not too fast.

5. Metering mode: If the camera's metering mode is set to spot or center-weighted, the flash may not be able to properly expose the subject. Try using evaluative metering instead.

6. Obstructions: If there are any obstructions between the flash and the subject, such as a wall or a person, the flash may not be able to properly expose the subject. Make sure there are no obstructions between the flash and the subject.

In summary, the under-exposure could be caused by a combination of incorrect flash exposure compensation, flash power, distance to subject, camera settings, metering mode, and obstructions. It is also possible that there is an issue with the communication between the flash and the camera body.

There could be several reasons for the severe underexposure you're experiencing with your Canon 5D Mark III and Speedlite 600EX-RT. Here are some possible causes and solutions:

1. Flash Exposure Compensation: You mentioned that you're aware of the flash exposure compensation adjustment, but it's worth double-checking that it's not set to a negative value, which could cause underexposure. Make sure it's set to 0 or a positive value if needed.

2. Camera Metering Mode: Although the camera's metering mode (Center Weighted Average Metering) and the flash's metering mode (E-TTL2) don't have to match, it's worth trying different metering modes on your camera to see if it improves the exposure. Try switching to Evaluative Metering or Partial Metering to see if it makes a difference.

3. Flash Power: Check if the flash power is set to a low value, which could cause underexposure. Make sure it's set to an appropriate level for your shooting conditions.

4. Distance and Angle: Ensure that the subject is within the effective range of the flash, and that the flash head is angled correctly to illuminate the subject. If the subject is too far away or the flash head is angled incorrectly, it could result in underexposure.

5. Ambient Light: If you're shooting in a very bright environment, the camera might be trying to balance the ambient light with the flash, resulting in underexposure. Try shooting in a darker environment or adjusting the camera's exposure settings to compensate for the bright ambient light.

6. Firmware Update: Make sure both your camera and flash have the latest firmware updates installed. Sometimes, firmware updates can fix communication issues between the camera and flash.

7. Communication Issue: If none of the above solutions work, there might be a communication issue between the camera and flash. Try cleaning the contacts on both the camera's hot shoe and the flash's foot with a soft cloth or a pencil eraser. If the issue persists, it might be worth contacting Canon support or visiting a Canon service center to have your camera and flash checked.

In summary, try adjusting the flash exposure compensation, camera metering mode, flash power, distance, and angle, and ensure that both your camera and flash have the latest firmware updates. If the issue persists, it might be a communication issue that requires professional assistance.

49441.question: Remove the tourists from photos
49441.context:
Sometimes I find an amazing location, but there are people in the way of my shot. If I want to take a picture of mine with the background landmark and people are in my shot which I don't want.
As I have more amazing pictures but gets a little less attention towards my style, poss or action in pictures, due to which I don't feel nice and become disappointment.
So, I want to know that, is their any new editing application or any different idea to remove the unwanted people from my pictures.

As in the pictures hear shown, I want to remove the girls who are standing or gossiping behind me. I do not want to blur that part instead I want to just remove the people behind me.
49441.gt:
The first step is to choose your location carefully — find somewhere where there aren’t many people gormless wandering around. If there’s a big attraction and everyone’s standing and taking photos, you’ll struggle to get a clear view without people in the way, so find a place where there’s a lot of movement. I chose the location in the photo above because it was a hiking trail so every person in the shot was walking.
Finally, take note of the actual landscape too. Waterfalls will end up blurry, and objects like flags will end up being removed. It’s also best if it isn’t a windy day so you don’t get trees moving and clouds drifting. These will end up as a blur in your final image.
Then head to Photoshop and go to File > Scripts > Statistics. Select "Median" for the stack mode and check "Attempt to Automatically Align Source Images." Finally, click the "Browse..." button to select your set of photos and hit OK. Photoshop will process the images to preserve the static background and remove everything that changes between the shots (the moving people). And finally you will get the required pictures.

49640.question: Can I use pictures with shop windows in editorial?
49640.context:
Currently taking my photography hobby more seriously I started doing moodboards for editorials I want to create and would love to submit to magazines at one point.
I work a lot in places like street, museum expositions, malls and more. I recently did some photos at the Marina Bay Sands Mall and used a few of the shop windows which had amazing background patterns.
When I write my editorial should I put credits for the shop windows? And can I send an editorial to submission based magazines directly or should I contact the PR of the brand of the shop window I used in the picture?
If it helps I am currently located in Singapore
Further Information:
The mall did not have any "No Photography" signs or icons.
The security of the shops saw us and never told us to stop shooting and same goes for the mall security.
For instance here is an idea of a  photo using the Dior shop window:
49640.gt:
I'm not familiar with the laws in Singapore, but there would certainly be a few issues if you were to do the same thing in the United States.

If a shop window is visible from a public roadway, sidewalk, or other publicly owned place, it is usually allowable to use any photos one takes from the public property. There are exceptions. For example, if the photo is primarily of a building or other intellectual property covered by trademarks or copyright, you might need permission from the owner of the trademark or copyright to publish a photo, depending on the usage. If the protected intellectual property is a small part of the background and not the primary subject or theme of the image, then you're much less likely to be liable for damages to the owner of the intellectual property represented in your image, regardless of usage.¹
On the other hand, if the shop windows are only accessible from private property, such as a privately owned parking lot or inside a mall, then it is entirely up to the property owner whether to allow one to take photos at all, much less publish them. This is not a trademark/copyright issue, it is a property rights issue. The owners of private property have the right to determine what activities will or will not be allowed on their premises.
Many malls in the united States have small signs posted at entrances to the effect that photography/videography on the premises requires the permission of the mall administrator. In such a case, one would need permission from the mall management just to shoot and be in the clear from a legal standpoint. This has been a longstanding practice which is becoming more and more unenforceable with the proliferation of phones and other very small devices with cameras.
If the mall management or their representative observes one shooting and asks one to leave, remaining on the premises will constitute criminal trespassing. If they ask you to stop shooting and you continue, that could also constitute trespassing because you are continuing an activity that they have specifically prohibited.
Even if you successfully complete your shoot and publish the results, the owners or management of the private property can request a court issue a cease and desist order regarding your use of the image or even sue you for damages. They might even have a case. But even if they don't, you're going to have to spend more money than it is probably worth to you to defend against their claim. You would still own the copyright to the image, but you might not have the right to publish/license the image for certain types of usage without permission of the property owner or their representatives.


¹ The classic example of this is the Transamerica building in San Francisco. A photo of the San Francisco skyline that includes the Transamerica Pyramid is not protected by the trademark of the building's appearance. This is because cityscapes are public domain. On the other hand, a photo that only shows the Transamerica Pyramid may be protected by the trademark and copyright held by the owners, depending on the actual usage of the image.

49076.question: how to make a grey warehouse exterior interesting
49076.context:
Carrying on from my recent question on how to get a decent interior shot, now i need to do the outside. 
I am required to photograph the outside of a grey manufacturing warehouse. 
It is new (ish) so nice and clean, however its mighty dull! 
I want to deliver something with a bit of wow factor, rather than a grey box with windows. 
(someone else took this!)
49076.gt:
It's pretty dull isn't it. How about a night shot with a long exposure to get some contrast and glow? Might need to make sure that their logo is illuminated.
Other than that maybe a sunrise/sunset shot is an option if the building faces the correct way or wait for some exciting weather to liven it up.
Alternatively some 'action' shots with employees doing their thing or close ups of building details or odd angles montaged on top of a long shot like the above.
Addendum: As per the interior question adding some people into the shot would provide for some scale and show off the size of the building.
Addendum 2: make sure when shooting that you get the horizon level! The photo above is at a bit of an angle and it makes the building look off kilter
model_pred: i'm not sure if this is the right place to ask this question, but i thought i'd ask anyway

To make the grey warehouse exterior interesting, you can consider incorporating different elements that add visual appeal and context to the scene. Some ideas include:

1. Incorporating the surrounding environment: Add trees, plants, or a potted garden in the foreground or around the warehouse to bring some life to the scene.

2. Use of colors and contrast: Paint the door or window frames in a contrasting or vibrant color to draw attention to the entrances or architectural features.

3. Lighting and shadows: Experiment with natural and artificial lighting to create interesting shadows and highlights on the warehouse walls, which can emphasize the building's shape and texture.

4. Signage or branding: If the warehouse belongs to a specific company, include a sign or branding on the exterior to establish a connection and provide viewers with context.

5. Vehicles and people: Include cars or trucks in the scene, as well as people working or visiting the warehouse, to give the impression of activity and life around the building.

By incorporating some of these elements, you can transform the grey warehouse exterior into a more engaging and visually appealing scene.

Remember to always keep the overall design cohesive and consistent with the warehouse's function. By incorporating some of these design elements, you can make the grey warehouse exterior more visually engaging and interesting.

There are a few ways you can make a grey warehouse exterior more interesting:
